Terror in Resonance:
MINDSET:
Explosions, derpy faces, amazing animation and overly hyped. Its devoid of realism and don't think outside the box...
REVIEW:
According to Collins dictionary terrorism is:
The systematic use of violence and intimidation to achieve political ends.
By using this evidence, do I remember any casualties from innocent civilians? No. Even if You may think that there were at least some deaths during the show, they never had the courtesy to at least show some death sequences or just anyone dying as if everyone was plot armoured, and when we do gotten to do the point when people are dying, it felt cheap as if the writers nevernoticed they should even have casualties.


So even the show that centres around “Terrorism” looks and centres more around just blowing sh*t up. It was obvious right from the get go that the two protagonists needed to launch a nuclear bomb at Tokyo, Consequently, right at the first few minutes of the Anime, we see them successfully stealing plutonium without getting caught and instead of even planning to create a nuclear bomb but all what they did was screw around with the police with riddles and demolishing a couple of skyscrapers without even killing anyone!


Character motives are just way too value or feels like it happened for no reason at all. Like why are these people terrorists in the first place? Seriously, You cannot really link up why and how this whole terrorism thing even started! Their were characters who barely get any fleshing out and feel like backdrop. Like the police force who seem to have an important role to the plot yet the show has never really felt that these supporting roles have a larger meaning or have good character exploration for us to even care! The side cast was completely forgettable as one guy only speaks English in the most Asian way possible and who even cares about such people or anyone in that matter?


Plot device characters are surprisingly everywhere in the Anime, but even if the role was there and the character is grasped well, how can we care? No one ever develops as if we were to show our sympathy at the end. Token girl of the two terrorists was unnecessary, she doesn’t have a role to the plot, she doesn’t even help out the characters emotionally or physically and we never even knew why she's so emo in the first place, since all what she does is look sad! Overall, the cast was an absolute train wreck.


Sure before the unholy revival of the 5th episode it did felt like a good show with how it handles the story. Of course society mass panicked from the extreme vandalism, the police was actually doing something. Though the riddles that the terrorists set up were just plain silly like trying to figure out some cryptic Greek myth to find some number that will lead the police force to enemy HQ  felt more hip and cool like a beta version of Death Note. Yes, characters were still terrible at that time, but it seem to contain more self-awareness any ways.


When the show attempts to create some epic revelation twist as a pathetic attempt to blow everyone’s mind, it feels more like stuff being made up along the spot rather than something that feels organic. In this one moment when we reveal the master mind whose behind through most of the weird causes in the show we instead found that it was just one of the detectives friend who committed suicide... Yeah, epic revelation guys I sure had an asthma attack after that one...


At this fifth episode we see the show completely collapsing  into itself when he reveal a psycho chick whose only personality is just to be a Yandere, but also: We some of the most asian and most downright cheesiest and the most unmoralistic use of “Engrish” in  a damn while! I know these people are meant to be American and this Asian Psycho has to speak English for them to understand, but its still a thousand times better just to leave all of those scenes in just Japanese; I can't help but to utterly face palm and feel ear raped every time I hear it! 


Though that is not the biggest of my issues, its when the show decided to hit the mind blow fest, and throw in a bunch of random details of the story that don't add up to anything, and even if it does somehow make sense, it still felt cheap or more importantly some random sh*t where supposed to care about, but ends up being pretentious. As if it was so cheap for the reason why psycho chick was psycho was because she was drugged in school. Can't I ever be more uncaring for such a plot device?


Overall, for something that is meant to be some intense mystery thriller, its horrible, since we don't care about the characters and too many of them feeling like a plot device or just there for absolutely f**k all. The show is classified as “GOOD” until you pass episode 5, and I did enjoy it for what its worth in a certain extent. Consequently, the show ends up not being bad, but another mediocrity because of that factor alone.


Since I never cared about the show, fans were trying to speak at how this show has a “Political Message” yes, even if its excactly true on whatever the show tries to conceptualise, like how making a school for uber smart people so they can farm their genes that will save the needless problems in Japanese society, was presented  too subtlety! Yes they somehow vaguely explained it, but even if it was obvious, the reasons just don't really feel natural, and is more of a pretentious arse pull! And even if the message was handled well enough for us to get it, I still cant help but to not care, due to badly directed characters and story.


MAPPA is one of those Animation companies that don't really make the best kind of Animation, well its either mediocre or above average, and they did Animated Hajime No Ippo for whatever that fighting show is worth. Any ways, it was very clear that MAPPA allowed there Animators some fun and creative freedom while still dumping cash bags of savings to make some of the most consistent and well made backgrounds. There is this feeling when there’s a lack of CGI, which is always a plus side and despite of them using a lot of greys, it does make a nift contradiction with some bright colours thrown in whenever someone is outside. The character designs still range to pretty good, or just plain cheap! Like one of the police men having massive eyes and how he's part of the supporting cast. However, most of them give this feeling to synchronize with the whole themes of the show regardless if it was presented badly. How the camera just moves a bit from time to time for no apparent reason is a nice touch, and there were moments like the Ferris Wheel scene when I just want to feel at least some emotion just because it was choreographed so well. Clearly, there has been a lot of thought put into this.


The OST has a strange vibe to it feeling rather unfitting for this kind of show, but it somehow blends well with the whole terrorist thing with crazy visuals. They do use mainstream instruments like the guitar and piano to an extent, but my main issue is that its just too ambitous for me to gladly listen to on a structured basis. It is an OST that feels very odd, it gives You this bizarre, yet somewhat emotional impact. It is clearly one of those OST's that You need to listen by Yourself to get the gist of what people say about it. The OP, does fit in well with the OST, and sure it doesn’t get me excited, but the visual choreography is just a creative use for us to get into a weird mood. The ED is skip worthy, but it is very calm if You'd like to listen to it.


LEGACY:

Its always going to be the Animation of how people will remember such an over hyped mediocrity. Its always going to be the damn budget that I will forever remember on how aesthetically  pleasing it was. Even if everyone says that its good, I believe it won't be long until more and more people will cough up to downgrade the overall score...


SCORES:

2.5/10 – The characters have nothing but to fill a one or two dimensional personality, and some of them are complete plot devices or just there or no reason.

4/10 – Its cool just to see the it until episode 5, when the story being on of the redeeming factors collapses into itself.

8.5/10 – A great mix of very creative choreography and a crazy budget that stays consistent.

7/10 – The music is refreshing from the common OST, but its a bit too bizarre for me.

FINALE: 5.5/10 – Its a lousy piece of sh*t if it wasn’t for the budget.

(Warning: Spoilers)
Zankyou no terror is the perfect example of a train wreck. Every episode of this show got worse and worse and the writing was completely terrible with bland characters and no sense of development in terms of the narrative or world building.
While the anime is very well directed featuring amazing artwork, animation and a great musical score that does a decent job at immersing you into its world, what is the point if the script is terrible? Its a shame too, since the first couple of episodes were generally interesting but never developed anything past that point and everything felt rushed. The main premiseof the show caught my attention, be it as it was about terrorism, an idea not really presented too much in anime and certainly stands out as an idea than your typical cute girls doing cute things shows, but many people gave the show a high score based solely on the premise rather than anything else.


Another reason for that was because of the highly influential director working on this anime too. He does a good job at directing the material he was given, and if this show does have something going for it, it probably was Watanabe Shinichiro's involvement. However, no good amount of great directing can save an ultimately broken narrative. 


The main two characters are both boring, dull and lack any kind of development. They both come across pretentious and stupid, both in their actions and in their goal as well, which they keep so god damn vague. Their actions and reasons for it just seemed too silly.  The whole thing felt like two children playing a game, sending riddles to the police and what not instead of any actual terrorism. There is no political statement behind the attacks and most of the people seem more so confused about the attacks rather than scared.


The riddles themselves seemed far too easy since they were all based on all ready existing myths and the such, but no one could figure them out aside from one detective. Even if this were the case, why not ask the population of Japan for help, or better yet the world, since the videos were uploaded onto YouTube. In this case, the riddles would be a breeze and they would be solved easily. Hell, people in the comments and such would be trying to figure it out themselves so it feels kind of unrealistic how the riddles keep throwing everyone off. The way the main cop comes to the discovery of the riddle is by dumb luck, and makes the entire show feel like a Saturday morning kid's cartoon. There is tones of lazy information dumping as if the audience is retared and can't interpret anything for ourselves, and most characters pull ideas from their asses.


Half way through the series they introduce a new villain who is called "Five" and god, it's been so long since I have seen such a badly written and pointless character. Every scene she was involved in felt like filler and none of it was ever interesting. She keeps on remarking about how she wishes to beat 9 but when she is able too, she kills herself instead. Why? Fuck knows. This character is given a terrible motivation which is never explained to us ever and never expanded on either. We waste so much on this character, which could of been used to flesh out the rest of the cast, but nope.


Lisa was simply a fucking plot device. Every action she took was just to advance the plot in the most laziest way possible. Her actions and decisions were stupid and dumb, making her feel less like a character and more so a cheap way to push the story forward whenever it was necessary. Her motivation to act as a terrorist were weak, the subplot with her being bullied and her mother becoming obsessed with her are never developed at all and the anime expects us to buy into the relationship between her and 12 but since both characters are boring, why should I give a fuck?


The only slightly interesting character was the main detective, but even then, he is nothing to write home about. I understand that both 12 and 9 are emotionally destroyed and that's why their characters act the way they do but they never do anything with these themes and ideas. Their motives are revealed to us far too late for the audience to care or to get invested in and their backstories are so boring and generic, I didn't care at all. You need to do more with your characters to get the audience to sympathise with them than a simple tragic backstory. They need to be appealing in some way. Lisa is given some characterisation in the fact that she can't cook, but this trait is so common in characters that it feels uninteresting. 


The ending was the most cheap and bullshit thing I have ever seen. We are presented with a three minute slide show of the three characters having fun together, playing and enjoying their friendship to try to make you feel something for these characters and pull at the heart strings before 12 is shot dead. What cheap, lazy writing. The fact that they try to make you feel something at the very end for these three characters they've barely spent developing and then relying on shock factor felt so lazy.


There were a few things I really did enjoy about the show however. Some of the scenes did a great job at conveying how the characters were feeling through the music and animation and these scenes (particularly the one with Lisa and 12 on the motorcycle) was great. Some of the animation could look pretty great too but that ultimatily means nothing if the script is so bad.


In conclusion, Zankoyu no terror was a disappointment. As someone who never watched it while it was airing and having people hail it as "the greatest show ever" for the past two years, Zankyou no terror felt boring and dull. Now, if you liked this anime, that's fine. I really don't care, more power to you. I just felt it was bad. Really bad.

(Please don't kill me)

It's 2014, and so, it's rather understandable to be doubtful of new anime.
Sadly enough, this one falls short of entering the ranks of the rare ones that are actually worth watching...
As the premise itself serves as an attractive bait hook, the final package greatly disappoints.
Initally, the first few episodes seduce the viewer through very pretty artwork, and confidently set the groundwork by showing just a tip of the mystery and motives at hand, yet it ultimately stumbles upon itself, leading to an unsatisfying conclusion.
While the cracks that slowly chip away at the script show themselves fairly early on, most of them represented by the introductionof two completely unfocused characters that awake undesirable conflict, there are brief hints of brilliance throughout as well, surpisingly, such as the intriguing but sporadic cat and mouse game, or the show's underdeveloped main leads, both of which should have been the series' main focus instead. \n\n
What could have followed in Death Note and Monster's footsteps, ended up being the wasted potential we all dislike gawking at in bitter wonder...\n\n\n

When i heard about this anime, i said to myself : Wow an anime about terrorism .. it must be great ! 
Firstly i was thinking about a population (Japan of course) being attacked by terrorists and we would see them experiencing it.. experiencing an terrorist attack. Well sorry but this anime isn´t about it. 
I really got disappointed with this show, somehow, with terrorism, they managed to pull off some clichês .. seriously .. There are things in this anime that seem a big waste of time.. 
Story: 7/10. The initial concept was fine. A nice idea actually.. but then .. well then thingshad to get worst. It starts doing some questionable things to the plot. One of them is how they manage to get in some places .. i would love to tell you but i won´t otherwise i would be spoiling, but the plot isn´t explained properly, a lot of questions were left without an answer plus some "fails" on the plot only makes it worst. 


They decided to do a whole thing with only 12 eps and it went wrong. Basically this anime is about a group of "terrorists" (who watched the anime will understand the quotation marks) who starts to attack Japan. After an attack, that group meets a girl who had serious troubles with her life.. 


Despite of those problems that i talked about, this anime is still engaging and fun to watch. There are some moments that can put you on the edge of your sit and that is really an important thing. 


Art: 8/10. The art is fine. Both the background and the character design are fine. Nothing really outstanding but still good enough. The pallet used is really interesting one. They made a mix between dark and bright colours which gave some sort of beauty to the anime overall. If there is a problem with the art, is the character design. They are good, but not great. The characters look flat. 


Sound: 7/10. The opening is nice but i couldn´t enjoy it. I skipped every single episode. Maybe is my personal taste but i really felt that this opening is not a big thing. The tracks used are fine. Nothing memorable or epic, just fine. I think that they don´t add anything to the anime, they are just there to fill in. 


Character: 7/10. The biggest problem was the decision making. Is not rare seeing a questionable choice here. I always asked myself : Why is she/he doing it? Would she/he really behave like that before such situation? I guess not .. it seemed not natural. 


The develop is weak. We can´t see much of them. Basically we only know their motives and what they wanted to do. I can´t describe you the characters because i just don´t know them. They are not original. Nothing new here, everything that I saw here I had already seen it elsewhere but better. 


Enjoyment: 8/10. Like i said, despite all of those problems, Zankyou no Terros is still a engaging anime. Personally i loved the end, really heart touching. Meanwhile, the middle episodes were boring at some point. I didn´t like them. 


Overall: 7/10. I reccomend this anime. Even though it has nothing new to show, the ending is good so I think it worth it's time.

First things first, out of all the anime that I've watched in 2k14, I found Zankyou no terror or Terror in resonance to be one of those excellently executed anime with a very  good plot, good character development, wonderful animation and great music (I personally really loved it). Now let's start with the individual ratings.
Story: Rebelling against a system and fighting for your rights is quite the common theme in a lot of anime, nothing new on that and a lot of anime have done justice to it, Zankyou no terror does the same. Wonderful take on the Governmental system of not only Japanbut also to a lot of systems from different parts of the world. The story gradually starts off with an act of terrorism, then turns out that it was done for the purpose of attention, for the reason of seeking salvation, now isn't that a good execution! The flow of the story is really nice, short and precise. All in all wonderful presentation so 8/10.


Art: The character designs are well done, the animation is of superb quality and the effects are excellently done. So 8/10 again.


Music: Another great album from Yoko Kanno, it's just so beautiful. The soundtracks ooze with serenity and peacefulness, except few tracks which were having a hip feeling to them which are quite nice too. So a solid 9/10.


Character: The character development of all the main and supporting characters flow at a smooth gradual phase, but could've been a bit more dynamic, there were a few dull moments but altogether the interaction between them is shown well. So, 7/10.


Enjoyment: I loved it. 9/10.


Overall: 8.2.

Do you like explosions? Do you like story? Do you like satisfying endings? Well then shit son this anime is just for you. 
Characters: Characters are well developed, you learn their back story, why they're doing what they're doing, and how they evolve over time.  For an 11 episode anime, this probably is a top tier example of how to introduce your characters.
Art: Looks good. Feels good. Mashes together well with every scene. Top-notch animation.
Sound: One of the better examples of great soundtracks for an anime. It uses orchestrated music, music from actual musicians, all with different flavors. Instead of those poorly edited MIDIsoundtracks you normally get, most of the music within the show is actually pretty standalone and sets the mood nicely within the show.\n\n
Story: Makes sense. Is realistic and it can apply to everybody so there is no "THIS HAPPENS BECAUSE THIS" shenanigans like most fiction oriented shows. Every character has their own motive, story, and reasons for their actions which all mashes up into a beautiful orgy of well directed plot.\n\n
Overall: Good shit. I loved the ending, but out of all the really well organized shots, and really no missteps with direction, I felt a little unsatisfied with it. The ending was fine, but it just missed a certain impact which would have left a better taste in my mouth.

"Are you going to destroy the world ?" 
- Lisa Mishima 
'Zankyou no Terror' or 'Terror in Resonance' is the epitome of modern thriller anime. It is clean cut off from any type of supernatural or fantasy seasoning. Zankyou no Terror revolves around the post events of a failed experiment that gathered intellectually gifted orphans from all around the Japan to make a medicine that would excel human brain further. With clever plot design and extraordinary voice acting, this anime is bound to grip you tight. It is one of the anime which will keep kicking you back to your seat either with its mixof cheeky and smart characters or mind blowing scenes. Compile all that with a good amount of thought provoking canon puzzles and blasts; you get a great anime.


I will not be exaggerating if I say characters from Zankyou no Terror are some of the most interesting ones not only from this season but maybe a past few. Two young smart rebels, Nine and Twelve, who happen to come across a rather airhead and slow-wit girl Lisa. I can't help but point out to her character she is just adorable, and I don't say that a lot. And of course no character list is complete without that one antagonist we all hate, Five, I wouldn't spoil much but damn it is fairly rare to come across an antagonist like her. 


All that with a great mix of original soundtrack and beautifully drawn art. You'll not feel the passage of time when you watch this anime. 


-HIGHLY RECOMMENDED-


Pros : 

+ Clever thought provoking plot

+ Bombs Bombs Bombs! 

+ Smart side-characters, smarter antagonist, smartest MCs

+ That ending.


Cons : 

 - A lot of scenes feel rushed 

 - That ending...

The anime has many positives and shortcomings, and I'll list a few (impossible to list all without spoiling the anime) in this short and spoiler free review.
First off, the things that I loved:
1. The soundtrack. Surprisingly beautiful.
2. The fact that his anime did not feel to go the ecchi, teenage rom-com or yaoi way (the most popular categories these days). Instead, it took head on a very serious topic.
3. Consistency. I mean, barring the plotholes, the anime was fairly consistent in its theme.
4. The time when 9 disarms a bomb. The music simply added to the beauty of the scene.
5. The pacing of the show,which picked up in the last 4 episodes. Had quite a few minor and major twists as well.\n
6. The ending. Sad, but beautiful. It made me up my score from 7 to 8.\n\n\n
The things that I didn't like:\n
1. 2 dimensional characters. All of them fit into a stereotypical character type. ALL of them.\n
2. Lisa. Why is she even in the anime? Her only job is to sob, cry, doubt herself, be a weakling, mutter sorry, be a hurdle and be completely useless. I don't see why the animators felt the need to add such a stupid character in this series. She was nothing more than a plot device and easily replaceable by someone more likeable.\n
3. Why Lisa thinks it's okay to spend time with terrorists. WHAT girl in her right mind would think that?\n
4. Why does the main detective have such an extensive knowledge of Greek mythology?\n
5. How the F was 5 allowed to go ahead with her very, very dangerous plan at the airport terminal?\n
6. The flashbacks - too little, too late. \n
7. 5's arc. I don't think anybody understood why she did what she did in the end.\n
8. Why did the boys have to resort to such *extreme* measures to do what they did?\n\n\n
All in all, though, this is a good anime to watch, provided you accept it has flaws. And to be honest, which anime doesn't?

From the very beginning, I thought that this anime was going to have one or two cool aspects in it and that would be it. A friend of mine even recommended this anime several times but I still didn't bother to watch it. Then I saw a certain review, pretty positive one actually, that stated that this would be a great candidate for best anime of the year. After seeing some footage I became interested in the anime and of course, gave it a watch.
Goddamn was I missing on something. Now I don't think that Zankyou No Terror is a masterpiece but it certainly issomething every anime enthusiast who would like something deep and highly entertaining, should watch. \n
Beginning with the story, I think is a really interesting one, with all the terrorism stuff and even some aspects that reminded me of Death Note, my all time favorite anime. The ending is something really special, I didn't see it coming and it was pretty heartwarming. \n
Let's talk about the characters here, starting with the protagonists, Nine and Twelve, which are actually the terrorists themselves. I didn't expect them to be so enjoyable. Now, I didn't found them to be the badass dudes that I though they were going to be, they are pretty badass but the human aspects of them were the ones I didn't expect from these two to be so enjoyable. So yeah, really good main leads.\n
There's this female character, named Lisa, which I didn't hate or anything but I didn't like her that much either. She's just… there the whole time. She could've been handled better. Another cool character here is this member of the police named Shibazaki, he is really damn smart and a lot of fun seeing him deduce sh*t. Overall, I found the characters really enjoyable and I liked every single one of them. Well, except a certain female character (not Lisa)…\n
I found the music really damn good, I wouldn't categorize it as memorable but it is really good at setting the tone for the scenes and all that. Though I'm not a fan of the opening song, I can say that the rest of the soundtrack is really good. The voice acting I found to be pretty good as well. Nothing else to say here.\n
The animation. Oh God the animation. The phrase fitting here is: "top notch". I mean, this looks like a motion picture! It was really impressive and of course, a lot of fun. The designs themselves, well… The environments look excellent, and the explosions and those kind of effects too. The character design… well is this kind of realistic design that I have to get used to but I'm sure that's just me.\n
Overall, Zankyou No Terror is a pretty awesome anime with a lot of cool and deep stuff. The characters were great, the story was good, the animation was awesome,... you should definitely give it a try. \n

Strikingly unique, the first thing one will immediately notice is just how absolutely fantastic the animation quality is. The quality of the animation easily trounces most every anime MOVIE, and among anime themselves it's hard to think of anything that even compares. 
The premise is likely to be the second - a thrillingly new idea in an age where such things are worth more than gold. Two teen-age terrorists, known only as Nine and Twelve, are the centre of this present-era Tokyo tale; the story quickly enchants as it tells of their insidious plots. The back-story of our two anti-heroes does, sadly, leave something tobe improved upon; one reaches the end of the anime without fully understanding just why Nine and Twelve are perpetuating this crime. \n\n
Despite this, Zankyou no Terror is absolutely phenomenal - anyone who enjoys a darker plot with excellent pacing will love this anime.

Honestly, this is another anime that does so well in the first few episodes, then disregards everything, turning in to something entirely different.
I'm going to keep this review short to avoid spoilers, not that there are many.
Frankly, the entire anime bar episodes 1 and 2 is just poor, the fact that the only character that isn't one dimensional or a plot device is a background character is just poor.
 It leaves the other characters as obvious anime cliche's, from generic cold serious glasses guy to happy go lucky has no idea about social interaction teen. They're either bland and boring or so over the topthat it destroys the 'realism' in the anime, this for me is one of the biggest problems, such a fresh and good idea for a story to be paired with such unrealistic cookie cutter characters. There is no one to connect with, to feel for, to even like!


Of course it's not just the characters that let the anime down, almost everything involved let's the anime down. 


EDIT:

Turns out I was wrong about the motives, they are revealed and wow...whilst the motive isn't particularily bad it's the fact that the motive is dependent on another character, if he wasn't involved then it never would've been found.

I feel they could've done a lot better with this, leaving references for the society would've done but instead it's done in a ridiculous way. I'd like to write a lot more about the motives but it's hard without spoiling anything


The more it tries to do, the messier it gets and soon enough, you're not even watching an anime about Terrorism.

This is only made worse by sub-plots that are set up and never resolved or even seen again, they begin and...they begin, nothing more to them aside from unanswered questions.


There are some good points though! The music is all round decent, there's nothing particularily catchy or memorable but it helps to set the mood and does a far better job of it than the characters do.

The art style is fantastic as well, whilst the personalities and types of characters are dreadful their actual designs are very realistic, and characters actually change clothes as well! The world they're in is highly detailed as well, from the roads and parks to the government buildings, it's all done well and looks real.


 I feel 'Zankyou No Terror' has tried to do too much, the best way to summarize it is 'Jack of all trades, master of none'. Everything in the anime is a huge contrast of something else, real world with a real problem coupled with over the top and unrealistic characters. An interesting premise with downright awful story telling unfinished sub-plots. Attempts to portray and battle real world issues are met with no resolve, climax or reasoning.


Honestly, it could've been good but much like the society and government it attempts to portray, you go a little deeper and realise how bad it is.

In a word, ZnT was disappointing. There was a lot of hype surrounding it, but it fell very short of my expectations. I did like the sound and art, but ZnT did not have either developed characters or a developed story. 
ZnT had an interesting concept, but it's not novel. It's basically a newer and far less thrilling version of Urasawa Naoki's "Monster" (which, by the way, is excellent). ZnT is about mysterious teenagers with 'evil' plans for the rest of the world and the super-smart, fallen-from-grace adult who is trying to catch them. It could have been an excellent story, but the anime isunfortunately so riddled with cliches and 'surprising twists' that it lacks any real suspense. ZnT also only has 11 episodes, which may not seem like a lot, but each season of "Free!" only had 13 and each still managed to have a solid plot independent of the other.


These characters are incredibly superficial. You are introduced to one facet of their personality and never get to see more than that. I could probably forgive that for Nine and Twelve, because they, as the main characters, are given more screen time, but absolutely not for Five, and Lisa, to a lesser extent. Five was a completely useless character. To me, she added absolutely nothing to the overall plot and only served to extend the series to 11 episodes - without her, this anime could easily have been like 6 episodes. I didn't see her final plot twist coming, and not in a good way - I was so disappointed with her exit because she could have been a good supplement to the existing characters, but instead, she appeared and disappeared and nothing about the story changed. At all. I also would have liked to see more from and about Lisa (personal favourite, because she's the most 'human' to me). Shibazaki was decent, but he was like a more cliched version of Tenma (from Monster). Also, I refuse to believe that the police are as incompetent/arrogant/stubborn as they are portrayed to be. Really, you're going to keep ignoring this genius detective, multiple times, even though he's clearly proven himself to be very intelligent about these things? Yeah, no.


Overall, ZnT is just very flat. There is nothing extraordinary about it; indeed, there are many, far superior manga and anime of the same genre. There are too many cliches, too many 'plot twists', too many dimensionless characters... That said, it's not awful. I think it could be the prototype, if you will, of a longer series that expands on the plot and characters, which could end up being interesting. So, if you're looking to kill a bit of time (each episode ~25 min) and don't particularly care about watching something amazing, then you'd probably enjoy this.

This anime...was so beautiful...must I continue? Yes, according to the guidelines, I must. For one, I picked up this anime and completed it within a couple of hours. 
Story: 10/10
The plot was captivating from beginning to end, with absolutely no filler or gray areas. I want to say more, but I'm not sure I should. All I will say is that if your into the "Psychological Game-play" genre, this is definitely worth a watch. Also, as I've noticed others have mentioned, this really isn't all about terrorism. But I'm sure you'll discover that for yourself when the time comes. 
Art: 10/10
The artwork was phenomenal. Therewere little to no areas that I could point out where the art was lazy, and the intentional  use of dark shading and pale colors for the characters was well played. Only specific scenes and objects (the sky, for example) were given vivid colorization, and with an underlying purpose. Additionally, it uses those gradients that animators love so much to throw in nowadays (usually into shoujo/comedy anime) but again, only in very specific situations, like in the characters irises, which I found interesting.\n
Sound: 10/10\n
I'm listening right now to the OST.  It's really nice, and the animation in the ending that goes with the ending song is just...sugoi. My favorite part about the soundtrack, though, is that when songs with lyrics are used, they aren't only Japanese--they're English and WAIT FOR IT--Icelandic! Which also ties into the plot (just made a revelation). This just keeps getting better and better.\n
Character: 9/10\n
Okay, to be honest, I didn't really pick up on this until reading other reviews, but the certain characters really aren't developed much at all. The reason why this didn't occur to me/why I don't care, is because it really wasn't relevant AT ALL to the story. \n
SOME SPOILERS, KINDA:\n
The only characters whose backgrounds really mattered were Lisa (minimally), Twelve, Nine, and Five, and they were explained to an extent that made sense--at first, you know hardly anything about them, but that was how much the world knew about them. Their pasts were meant to be concealed. The only character that could have used more of a backstory was Shibazaki. They started to say things about his past, and just sort of dropped it.\n
Enjoyment: 10/10\n
No explanation. See above for details. (I mean, honestly, I enjoyed it to the extent that a series like this should be enjoyed, which is why I give it a 10/10)\n
Overall:\n
10/10. Despite the tiny character development flaw, I found this to be so enjoyable and well made.

Honestly, I predicted some events that where going to occur next but that doesn't mean that the story does not have a great concept. This anime should have been extended - even a little - because of (Characters' relations & interactions). Noticeably, 12 and Lisa's because they just seem to connect out of the blue.
This show had potential to be a masterpiece...
Story: When Chess/Shogi is involved I thought i was in for tactical and surprising play. That was mostly the case; terrorism cleverly carried out. Sphinx (9 & 12), who are exceptionally gifted, set the first act of terrorism with an endgame ready in mind. They're intentions - bad or good - are tried to be parried by detective Shibazaki who is also smart. But is he smart enough? \n\n
Character: Shibazaki - The detective (Shogi player) who risks his job to get to the bottom of facts and risks his life to uncover the shades of the past. He seems to be the only one who can answer the Sphinx's riddles, thinking ahead he stays ahead of his peers. How close will he get to Sphinx's' identity? \n
9 - Best chess player in the anime... The cool, ladies' man but he's really calm and goal-oriented. He know it's best to have less friends because of the endgame.\n
12- Cheerful lad. He wears a smile as much as he wears his clothes- no this is not that kind of anime, you freak.\n
5 - She is a rival, but to whom? Hint: she is hearing the same noise as 9... I like her, she left me thinking Why? But if you really think about it her actions are not confusing.\n
Lisa - A shy, oppressed girl. She doesn't exist until a few episodes in- Yes, I know she's in the 1st episode. It feels like she's just chucked in the batch to simply give problems to the real main characters- 9 & 12.\n\n
Rate: 7

This was an ambitious show and it tottered a little, but I enjoyed it. I promise, there's a reason why the protagonists are blowing stuff up. 
Story: 
- This is the struggle of young people who want to leave a bang on the world. I find such sentiments to be somewhat relatable, like something fished out of a half-lucid dream. The presentation of this message however, is a bit too melodramatic for me. The story feels immature, and I can almost feel the heartbeat of a young writer behind it (ie, is like me and hasn't experienced or reflected too much on the world). Ithink the story does a decent job considering how it is not an adaptation of a novel, light novel, or manga of previous renown. 

- I didn't find the story very engaging; there are other shows that had me hooked from the first episode. I actually struggled to finish this show, and luckily it sped up a little around the 7th episode (or maybe that was just me. At some point I started to fast forward a few seconds at a time past the slower scenes). 

- There was youthful struggle and political struggle; trials of friendship, trust, and morals. There were also many cultural references (or they're questionably implemented plot devices if you think too much about it). Like I said, ambitious, and it actually does an OK job of it. It definitely could have been less straightforward.

- Note: I'm a US kid speaking on a show targeting Japanese audiences, but I would say that US intervention is again being used as a major plot device. 


Art:

- Backgrounds and props were mostly amazing! Bright, vivid, extremely detailed. No cardboard sets to be found here, nope nope. That said, there are sometimes rather awkward transitions; I've seen better. The animation of the characters is not nearly at the same caliber as the set, and there are goofy moments here and there, but this is all to be expected from a show. 


Sound:

- Ok some weird backstory: Personally I took up a recommendation, watched the first episode, took a break, found the soundtrack, ended up listening to it often, and then forced myself to finish the show. I have no regrets watching Zankyou no Terror; the use of music in the plot helped me to better appreciate the soundtrack.

- The point is, the soundtrack is nice ambiance as a standalone and is even more beautiful sitting in the laurels of a minimal plot and luscious images. For me, it held the show together and was crucial in making it palatable. The ending theme is definitely in my list of favorites. There's a conspicuous lack of the usual suspects in jrock and progrock; unusual for a thriller blow-stuff-up type show but it added to its deeper appeal. 

- Note: it's unfair to be a native English speaker judging a show aimed at Japanese audiences, but I think there was pretentious overuse of heavily accented and choppy English, totaling to entire minutes of the show. (the only kudos goes to Clarence)


Characters:

- I wish the show did more to have us feel empathy for 9 and 12 through their history and upbringing. Where's the terror that gives birth to these little terrors? The show ends and does its job in tying up loose ends of motivations and such, but I still struggled to feel for why these crazy kids did what they did. 

- And then there was a particularly questionable seeming character design cough five. She's a necessary plot twist, and plot twist again, but she was a bit of a prop (and an outrageously dressed one at that). 

- And there's also someone who seemed to be totally out of the loop for the majority of the show cough cough Lisa. (idk, the moe factor doesn't really in here, aka, a 1 cours that has a lot to do and not a lot of time to do it)

- There's been better and there's been worse, though I would say that overall this show does a good job for the time it has to branch its characters. 

- I was disappointed in the how the show addressed barriers between the younger and older generations, it's such a universal problem and the show suggested such a rift. I was also expecting more due to 9 and 12's lack of parent figures, and the in-depth and time consuming references to the stories of Oedipus.

- I've been watching enough anime to not really care (and American media villifies other cultures all the time), but the Big Baddie USA is again, a barely developed and conveniently placed set of characters and motivations.  


Enjoyment: 

- This show did make me cry, but I'm a bit of a crybaby anyhow so this isn't the "stamp of tearworthy" for all.

- Again, the show strikes a memory of passionately/manically/half-lucidly desiring to make an impact on the world. You know, like after waking up from a nap and finding that you're crying with the fading recollection of an existential confrontation in dreamland. I will be brooding over the show for a bit (and I'll think of the story and think about it some more when I listen to the soundtrack).

- Fact: I marathoned episodes 6-11. 

- but I don't think this is has much rewatch value, and anyhow, the story already has faded/abridged itself into a long music video in my head. 


Overall:

I felt enough to write home about it seems, since I rarely write reviews.

Art and sound definitely a strong point of this show. This means that this is something to watch with the usual advice of ignorance is bliss: don't read too much into the meanings and feasibility of things if you want to simply enjoy it. 


I really wish there could have been more character development (or more efficient of such), because I'm left with a strong desire to love the characters but not enough experiences with them to do so. But if it made me feel this way, it seems to be be a success for the 1 cours.

I was very excited at the prospect of a terrorism-themed show, considering how taboo and controversial a topic it is. However, while "ZnT" may have been fun to watch, it certainly didn't deliver on all aspects.
The Art and Sound are, honestly, the best thing about this show. The visuals, especially in the first episode, are stunning, and it's apparent there's a very large budget. The OST by Yoko Kanno is wonderful. OP is nice, ED is alright.
Characters are one of the two biggest problems with this show. THEY LACK BACKING AND DEVELOPMENT... While you can somewhat feel attached to them, due to us not totallyknowing WHY they are doing what they're doing (and then giving a shitty, under-developed reason as to why at the end -- but that's a story problem) certainly bogs down the steam. ...and then we have Five and Lisa: utterly simple (and/or useless) characters that are rather 2-dimensional. It's a shame the female characters are the ones that hurt the series the most... Only the detective seemed to really develop or get anything out of this entire story.


Setting was your usual Japan... except under attack (and somewhat fleshed out).


Episodic value was good. I was excited to come back and see the show every week, but the episodes (especially the middle ones) had some pretty big holes that were never closed. Pacing was awkward near the middle as well. All this content backed into only 11 episodes... it really shows that they left stuff out that was important.


The story was a HUGE mess. While these actions are cool and daring, we never really learn of ANY [REALLY GOOD] reason they are being taken. I understand the premise that the writers were going for, but the lack of development on Nine and Twelve's backstory really made the ending reveal have a minimal impact. I want there to be MORE.


Overall, "Zankyou no Terror" could have been a LOT better if there were more episodes in which they could flesh out full and complete character backstory and story development. It was fun to watch, but really wasn't that wonderful.

Story: 
The story of ZnT is quite a serious one, with terrorists and all that. When you first start watching, you expect some sensitiveness toward the topic...well, you won't get it. ZnT starts off mysterious and right into the action and then slowly unravels all the secrets and mysteries. 
I really liked the background story and they managed, even though some parts are complicated, to keep it short, compact and entertaining with just the right balance between action and talking.
Art: 
Maybe it didn't deserve the full 10 points...there were some parts which weren't drawn that good, but this is a score with priority to mylikes. I really like this kind of art so it's 10 points for me.

The backgrounds are detailed enough and the characters are drawn well too. What I noticed: ZnT is an anime where the characters actually do change their everyday clothes...:D


Sound:

Soundtracks are always about what you like and dislike...I wasn't a big fan of the opening and ending, but that may just be me. The music and sounds during the anime were great though because it is not your usual Japanese songs or just some background sounds. They play with different songs and with this give different feelings to the anime. 


Character:

Here I can just congratulate. The staff of ZnT really managed to make you feel for the characters in just 11 episodes which in my opinion is quite amazing.


Enjoyment:

I really enjoyed watching but I do have to say, this anime is probably not the right thing for everyone. Still I recommend it :D Also I didn't like some of the events in the story, so I just give it a 9.


Overall: 

10 points because it's not that often that I'm so mesmerized by an anime. ZnT isn't the typical anime and shows some new topics or perspectives. It also gives you interesting characters and enough action to not fall asleep, ever. 


I really recommend watching. If you like it after 2 to 3 episodes then it is something for you :D

Zankyou no terror is an anime that mixes thriller and drama. After looking at the reviews here and after seeing the design of it, I decided to give it a try. 
It was a good anime. I think it had a great potential which was unfortunately hardly availed. It could have been a great anime, however it lacks of something.
On the positive side there is the enjoyable design. Each character has its own characteristics and not a single one looks like another one. Each character has a special aura that corresponds to their personality. Even better, the animation is really fluent. 
On another plan, thedark atmosphere that englobes the anime from beginning to end suits the story really well and nothing is out of place in that sense. 

On the negative side, the story was good but wasn't profound enough. It isn't detailed enough. It seems that we are just rushing from one action to another with little phases of sentimentalism and reflection. 

To begin with I think that this anime should have been much longer and could at least have had 5 more episodes. It would have given more time to analyse and maybe better explanations on some things. In fact after seeing the whole thing I was quite disappointed since I waited for something much more deeper with such a story line. It now just looks like an empty story. The effects are great but the story and the characters lack of deepness. At the end there is no real message and the story in itself is really messy and we keep loosing track. There is no real direction which can be really confusing. There is no focus on anything and at some points second characters seem to be as important as main characters. 

Finally, I was really disappointed by the end because it underscored its lack of real meaning. It didn't reach my expectatives and didn't give me the "more" I was hoping for. 

However, I must say that I enjoyed watching this anime. For me it is a fair anime that is good if you don't have anything else to see and is actually really entertaining. 



(My english might not be perfect, sorry for that)

Terror in Resonance was a short but thrilling ride that managed to tell a complete story in just 11 episodes. In fact, it almost tried to do too much, as I liked the way the show was going in the first four episodes more than I liked the middle section, but for sure this is a modern, fresh, original anime you should absolutely take a peek at.
Art-
Modern and gorgeous, period. Great animation, smooth, colorful and vibrant and doesn't look dated at all. It looks like something that could come out tomorrow even though it's five years old as of this writing. The character designs ofthe two leads were actually kind of ordinary and didn't overly stand out to me- and perhaps that was done purposely- but other characters such as Five and Shibazaki stood out as being a bit more unique in their visual design.


Sound-


The voice acting for the leads felt, again, just kind of ordinary. There wasn't anything wrong with it at all, but it never stood out either. In fact, I don't know that anyone had a voice performance that really blew me away, but I want to clarify that does not mean that anyone had a poor performance either- they didn't. The voice acting was simply good and fine but nothing beyond that.


The music felt like a weak point of the show for me. It simply didn't stand out at all. Very average and forgettable opening and closing songs and no background songs- even in the plethora of tense and emotional moments this anime offers up- really stood out to me and hit me in the gut the way a great soundtrack should. The sound aspect of this show, while never terrible, felt very ordinary for me.


Character/Story-


In a world where every anime concept and cliche has been done, redone and redone again Terror in Resonance brings something unique to the table and that is refreshing and lovely. For the first several episodes it was a true thriller and really had me on the edge of my seat. I was getting serious Death Note vibes from these episodes, in the best way, and was thoroughly enjoying the cat and mouse game between the evil entity and the highly intelligent detective who knows better than everyone else, not too dissimilar from the classic Kira vs L battle.


I wish they'd stayed with this, honestly, and I didn't particularly care for where they took it instead. The character Five, while uniquely designed, complex and kind of badass- simply felt unnecessary and sometimes highly convenient. There isn't actually anything wrong with her as a character at all- it was just a trying to do too much/too many cooks in the kitchen kind of situation. A lot of her backstory and how she ties into the present situation really, really stretches plausibility/believability even more so than the show, which definitely requires you to suspend your disbelief to a certain degree, already does on its own.


The character Lisa, while I feel she added more than nothing to the show, was also arguably convenient and unnecessary. My wife really hated this character as she's simply really dumb and there were definitely times when it felt like she was in the anime for the sole purpose of messing with the leads or giving them someone to save. I think she was intended to add emotional depth, and maybe near the end she did a little tiny bit, but the execution here could have been better and she probably could have been at least a little bit, despite her circumstances, less helpless and pathetic.


Enjoyment-


The first four episodes were excellent and thrilling and had me really into the show. I don't love the middle section for a number of reasons, specifically, it got away from what it was doing when it simply didn't need to (if it ain't broke don't fix it), it became a lot more convenient and less believable and as a whole it just felt tough to take seriously, but then it finishes fairly strong, though not as good as the beginning, and somewhat redeems itself. There were definitely a few moments littered throughout the show where things worked in a way I have a hard time understanding or believing, but other than those annoyances it was a largely positive experience.


Overall-


I concluded this series with a far more positive than negative impression. With its very short running length of just 11 episodes- which is quite easy to bang out in just a night or two- I'd definitely say give it a watch if you're a fan of the genre. The ending was satisfying and had emotional depth to it and overall it's a very good show worthy of your time.


+Fresh, original premise

+Very modern looking and feeling

+Visually beautiful

+Emotional depth

+Thrilling/suspenseful moments


-Forgettable soundtrack

-Large stretches of plausibility/believability

-Conveniences

-Tried to do too much/unnecessary characters


OBJECTIVE RATING- 8

PERSONAL ENJOYMENT RATING- 8

Zankyou no Terror is easily a contender for best anime of 2014, hands down. Just finishing the show and looking back over it I do not regret watching this whatsoever.
Story:
This was directed by the person who wrote the script and directed Cowboy Bebop. COWBOY BEBOP. To be expected the story was fantastic. Terrorism is a very touchy subject and is often avoided in a story. Zankyou no Terror however, does not care. It puts the threat right in your face, and shows you the reality and devastation a terrorist attack has. Following the story of Nine and Twelve and they attempt to achieve their unknowngoal while leaving clues behind about their past. For originality and going beyond the regular standard of stories 10/10


Art:

Studio MAPPA has utterly exceeded my expectations with the art and animation. The art was beautiful, giving off a very realistic color pallet, adding to the realism and realization that this could happen in real life, maybe just not to this extent. Animation was very fluid and helped make scenes 10 times more intense than they should have been. The dark colors used throughout add to the ambiance of the show and set the mood of suspense and mystery. 10/10


Sound: 

The music was done by Yoko Kanno, who also did music for Cowboy Bebop. The background music was absolutely amazing. Every song perfectly set the mood for scenes and fit in perfectly. The opening and ending were amazing and really gave you a taste of how this show was gonna be. Honestly, this was to be expected of Kanno, and of boy did she deliver. 10/10


Characters:

Other shows, take note of how to develop characters in 11 episodes. The characters in this show were not forgettable to the slightest and you would constantly be cheering for both sides. Nine and Twelve are 2 teens who are also the Terrorist duo known as Sphinx, and create great moments of suspense. Being terrorists you'd expect them to be all bad, but in reality, they aren't. Shibizaki is a detective who is on the case of trying to catch Sphinx, and is very, VERY, intelligent. He is the one able to decipher Nine and Twelve's riddles. The interaction between both sides creates a great mystery. And finally, the most hated character of the show, Lisa. TO be honest, I think character is a amazingly developed character. Annoying does not mean bad, and that is the case for her. Being a hostage/accomplice of Nine and Twelve, she makes decisions in a very realistic way for her situation. Irrationally. In her mind there is always the over-looming though that she could be killed at any moment by Nine and Twelve if she does something they don't like, and that leads her to make these bad decisions. She has nowhere to go and must try not to get herself killed. Being a normal citizen put into a situation like hers ruins her rational psychological state. Sure some people consider her a plot device, but she clearly has her place as a good character. 10/10


Enjoyment:

By now you should tell that I absolutely adored this anime. It's been quite a while since a psychological thriller mystery like this came out and it sure feels amazing to have one again. 10/10


Overall:

Please, do yourself a favor and watch this as soon as possible, because this a just amazing. Even if you're not a huge fan of the psychological, mystery, or thriller genre, give this one a try. You will not be disappointed. Sure the show may not be absolutely perfect, but no anime is really. It's close enough to a 10 for me to give it one. If you want to nitpick at the show then be my guest, but if you don't you should extremely enjoy it.  


If there any grammatical errors, I apologize, my English is not perfect.

“Neither of us was needed by anyone before. I’m glad I met you.”
Two boys named Nine and Twelve are complete opposites; one has a warm smile and the other has a cold gaze. Zankyou no Terror is about the boys' acts of terrorism. Along the way, they meet Lisa Mishima, a girl who is bullied by her peers and lives with a paranoid mother. The plot is intriguing because the audience has to ask themselves: Why? For two boys around the age of seventeen, terrorism is no silly matter. As the story unravels, the viewers find out about their ultimate goal as well as theirpasts that led them to their unyielding decision.


The overall animation of the anime is not typical and is far from the norm of a slice-of-life. The depiction of the characters leans toward a more realistic interpretation and are not those "big-eyed, colorful hair" art. The colors are not vibrant but rather a dark, ominous tone, fitting for a psychological, thriller type anime such as ZnT.


The music choice was nothing particularly outstanding but it certainly did fill its roll. I still get chills down my spine whenever a flashback plays with the electric guitar riffs. With actual songs, I found it interesting that this anime chose multiple with English lyrics, not something you hear in your typical anime. Something that bugged me, however, was that the characters who spoke in English were all good except for one minor, slightly major (?), character named Five - although, it did give me a few chuckles here and there.


The main protagonists, Nine and Twelve, are well-developed. The audience may find it difficult to relate to them but it is easy to sympathize with them. They are practically foils of each other; also, despite the difficult road that lies ahead of them, they are as close as can be. Lisa, no matter how much trouble she causes, moves the plot forward. However, Lisa does constantly seem like a nuissance and does not seem to do anything but be a paperweight to the Nine and Twelve duo. Next we have Detective Shibazaki, a central key to the story. Through his clever and shrewd critical thinking, he is able to play the terrorists' game. He goes as far as opposing orders to accomplish what he believes is truly righteous. As for Five, I have many questions about this character. Because of her unique personality (and odd English pronunciation) she was eccentric and sometimes just plain creepy. There were many things that were not clearly explained about Five and that left me feeling a bit disappointed. 


I can't say I am completely satisfied with the ending, but it was definitely wrapped up nicely. This show is rated R and I can understand it. The central theme of this anime is serious and should be handled with maturity. I Hope this review has cleared your thoughts on this anime and if you intend to dive into this journey, I wish you: Von voyage!

Zankyou No Terror was hyped to be one of the most unique anime this season. It has a unique premise and famous names attached to it. During the first five episodes, I was hyped so much that I thought to myself "This is the feeling watching Bebop tier anime while its airing". 
But 5 episodes in, my this expectations was crushed. What could be a classic anime became a trainwreck And by the time I was ended, I realized that this was one of the most wasted potentials in any media that I saw.
Art/Animation: 10
The art is astounding. Zankyou tries to be different from yourtypical anime. The art is not "cute" and "bright" but gives the sense of "seriousness" and being "gloomy". Mappa's animation in this show is film quality. Even the CGI looks so good. 


Sound and Direction: 10


Yoko Kanno and Watanabe is in charge of this. And you know its good. The music is memorable and the application of these music on these scenes (First episode, flashback scenes, the bike and ferris wheel scenes) were amazing.


The technical aspects are god tier right? Nothing could go wrong right? However, the 


Characters: 6

Story: 4


This sections are related in reviewing Zankyou. Why? The story did not permit for character development. Yes the scenes, soundtrack, animation is great. But what you get is only eye candy and eargasms. Yes, the themes of Militarization, Illegal Government- Sanctioned Experiments, Misplaced Nationalism and the Coming of Age of troubled (Very troubled) teenagers as was touched. But I felt I was watching a soul less series, without any characters I could cheer on or story to become interested to. 


Nine and Twelve: They seemed so interesting during the early episodes, building a sense of mystery around them as they build up the "Sphinx", their public persona as a terrorist duo. However, as the story continues, we nothing about their motivations and we couldn't even sympathize with their morally ambiguous actions. 


Liza: MOE BAIT? She really does nothing to the story, except FUCK THINGS UP. Does she humanize Nine and Five? No. As they reveal nothing to her about their origins nor motivations. Twelve just relates to her as she is a social outcast while Nine sees her as a baggage holding Twelve back.


Five: Is Five even a character? She's seems just a plot device to make someone equal to the protags. Her actions seems poorly justified and unrealistic, breaking the realistic vibes the series attempted hardly during the earlier episodes. 


The only character that I could relate with is SHIBAZAKI. Shibazaki is your detective who was demoted for being too brilliant. This gives him motivation during the whole story to try to uncover the root cause and the motivations of the protags. He wants to prove to himself and others that the things he did before the story was right. 


Enjoyment: 10


Although the story and characterization were shit, I really enjoyed the series. Zankyou was a breathe of fresh air- it was different and promising. I was excited for every Thursday in anticipation for each episode. Without any original manga or light novel, discussing it with friends or in the internet speculating the next episodes or the characters motivation was enjoyable for me. I really really want to import the OST and Volume 1, as I really enjoyed out the hell of it and was the most played songs in my playlist and the early episodes as god tier episodes 


When I watched Rail Wars this seasons, I knew its a low budget anime and set my expectations low. Glasslip was my disappointment of this season as it made really no sense coming from a respectable animation studio. 


But Zankyou is different. Its frustrating to watch how an anime that could easily be a timeless classic with its animation, soundtrack, direction and art , rate 10/10 and became the Cowboy Bebop our generation coming from the same people (Watanabe and Kanno) became a wasted potential. They could have made it at least 20 episodes for more room of character development or a good anime film removing unnecessary subplots summarizing Eps 1-4 and 10-11 and Zankyou could have been a timeless classic.

I started to watch this anime at the age when i sometimes think that I am too old for animes since I dropped a good amount of animes recently. But no, I was wrong. Zankyou no Terror is a complete masterpiece for people who like a bit of thriller and a bit of mysteries. Personally I would put this anime at Psycho Pass level.
Story: 10/10
The anime's story is great and consistent. *Minor spoiler: To those who complained, the first part about school where the duo attended is only the mean for Sphinx to mix in the visit at the government tower for the first (orsecond if you count the one at the prologue) incident to happen. The theme of children locked in an institution later on go revenge may not be that new, but the terror part is very creative and should get credit for that. 


Art: 10/10

No complain here. The art is not mind blowingly great, but it is perfect. I love how most eps are covered in a mildly dark theme (or disturbingly bright) that gives viewers some uneasiness. I would give art a 9 but seeing how much lofi MVs on youtube using scenes from this anime, it deserves a 10.


Sound: 10/10

The sound is actually what I like the most about this anime. OP and ED are good, but the songs in between the anime are great. Music in Zankyou no Terror mostly gives viewers a melancholy vibe. But for the one of the only shooting scene in the anime, the music and the shooting sound (as well as the art) are so great it feels like watching a hollywood movie.


Characters: 9/10

For an anime that is plot heavy and lasts only 11 eps, characters in Zankyou no Terror are quite decent. Nine and Twelve are well executed with Nine acts as the leader and the head of the duo, cool, calm and collected but still able to act if the situation requires him to. The two act just like what we should expect from where they came from, Nine as the motionless, inhuman, brain-like part and Twelve as the heart part, love, has fun, makes joke,.... that sometimes the brain, or Nine couldnt control. If there is something I dont like about the casts, it's about the girls. Five actions were quite questionable, that in the end her motive missed me. I also found Lisa quite annoying since she mostly contributed to the story by got caught and created a mess for the duo.


Enjoyment: it's been quite a while since I enjoyed a mystery anime this much, I think about more than a years ago when I watched Shinsekai Yori. Definitely a 10/10

Let me tell you why I give this a 7, but before that right now haven't seen it since 4+ month.

Anyways there is some romantic type thing going on with one other supporting girl and main pro-tag. This type of anime I really, but towards the end it just wasn't really going how I liked. The ending kinda sucked (for me). Copter came out of nowhere. I thought there was going to be an ending I liked, but I guess justice was deserved.\n

One last note the Protagonists are the actual "heroes" in their own way, but trying to get justice because life is screwed up.
