This anime greatly disappointed me. At the start, it nearly perfectly executed its background and exposition, revolving around a mystery-past theme commonly found in many anime. I think this anime really could have been near Death Note's level and it had the potential to, but it just failed everything. Everything episode 3 and beyond was a fail. The rival was a force character introduction with repetitive events that had no meaning. As the series continued it was plain boring repetition, and the series had no goal in mind. Then there is the most useless character in the series, Mishima Lisa. I think you should dropit and not be tricked by the first two episodes but it really is your choice on whether you want to be disappointed in the end...

*sighs deeply*
Words can barely describe how much I enjoyed this anime. I went into watching this glorious show without knowing much about it other than fact it was about 2 teenage boys who acted as terrorists. But just knowing that alone was enough to interest me, but little did I know I was in for a bigger ride than I had expected. 
Story: 8.5+/10
A very good plot line, I must admit. It was sophisticated, one that got you thinking and wondering about why things played out the way they did throughout the entire series, right until the end. This was probably a really big experiencefor me because I thoroughly enjoy animes that cause you to think and backtrack sometimes, it keeps the watching experience much more enjoyable and much less boring. Examples of such are Steins Gate, Psycho-Pass, and FMA, but I'll save those for another time. Branching back to ZnT, I cant tell you how intrigued I was by every little detail and niche that kept popping up as the story progressed, while still coinciding wonderfully with the overall plot line of the story. Honestly, for anyone who is looking for a well thought out story with great supporting details, accompanied by astonishing mysteries, this is a show well worth considering. 


Art/Visuals: 9/10


Two letters. H. D. It was a struggle trying to find all the downloadable episodes in such high quality, but the painstaking labor of finally finding all of them was extremely worth it. Watching it on my HD plasma screen... well... everything looked so damn beautiful, especially the explosions, those lovely, luminescent explosions. But not only that, the art style of the show was also very nice, not particularly unique per-say, but it had a style that fat quite nicely with the show. Actually, I believe I instantly fell in love with the visuals of this anime during the very first episode, as they were escaping from the plutonium facility. A very nice use of semi-3D animation in my honest opinion.


Sound: 9/10


*cranks up the stereo*

Lovely, LOVELY, soundtrack. My word, is it even legal to have such beautiful music in an anime about terrorism (loosely speaking)? I mean, I thought the visuals were great, but this is just ridiculous. As I was watching the anime, I found myself paying alittle more attention to the music playing than what was actually going on in the show, no lie. Each one had beautiful mix of bittersweet feelings to it, which was great because the anime itself was the most bittersweet masterpiece I have seen in ages. My favorite track, though, was definitely "Walt". Beauty. At its finest. 


Characters: 9/10


Each and every main character was exceptionally portrayed throughout the series, and I enjoyed watching every scene that had them in it. None of them were useless to the story or had unsatisfying back stories, they were all equipped with great personalities and usefulness. So basically, I fell in love with the cast, simple as that.


Nine

The cool and sophisticated hacker mastermind behind it all. His character personality was alittle on the generic side, but that little detailed failed to undermine how well thought out his overall character really was. He had a heart that was usually hidden behind his heavily serious demeanor, which proved to be an exceptional character trait that gradually showed it's true colors thought out the series, especially towards the end. Sadly, he suffered from panic attacks and increasingly worsening headaches that only proved fatally detrimental later on, but even with that, he stayed true to his goal until the end.


Twelve

The ecstatic, mysterious little optimist in charge of constructing the bombs and carrying out other duties Nine wasn't able to. An extremely lovable character that complimented nicely with Nine's bitter attitude. I'll admit, however, he had the most fluctuating personality out of all the characters, but it was probably because he had a heart even bigger than Nine's, hence why he sincerely fell for Lisa, even when he knew doing so would prove extremely problematic for both of them (and Nine), in the end. He also had a very interesting symptom called synesthesia, which allows a person to see colors in sound, according to the anime (there's a much more complicated definition to it).


Lisa

The shy and rather quiet girl who suffered from both domestic and social problems. She was honest, and also had a very big heart for those she cared about, and there was never a time in the series I disliked this character. I found her very important to the story, especially in regards to the unintentional relationship she gradually developed with Twelve. Yes, she was weak in many areas Nine and Twelve excelled in, but being with the two began to influence her exponentially in a positive way that allowed her to become a good character (we can thank Twelve for this). Yes, she was also the damsel in distress a few times, but damn, she played the part so well, honestly. It fueled alittle more needed material into the story, which I didn't find bad at all. And that fact that she was mature enough to admit she may have screwed up rather big a few times, only made me credit her more as a character. In many cases, distressed damsels become very irritating for me when it comes to shows, but in this one, it was a different story.


Shibazaki

The badass detective. This guy... he deserved some kind of medal for his services, not the bullsh*t the higher ups gave him, but that's besides the point. The intelligence of this man was exceptional, mainly because he was able to crack  Sphinx's riddles so acutely, grabbing and processing the little details many of his other co-workers failed to even notice. Like all the other cast members did, he had heart of gold. I understand that at the start of the series, he was strictly hell-bent on bringing down Sphinx, but when he starting seeing the full picture of what Nine and Twelve's motives really were, he began to calm down, even as far as telling one of the army men who was ready to strike them down aerially not to shoot the two boys, thinking it was more sane to put them through a trial. Basically, the man knew his sh*t, which is why he was such an enjoyable character to see in action while watching the show. Not only that, his past was just as chilling and interesting as the other main characters of the show.  


Five

The sadistic little demon child with rad looking hair. I don't exactly know why, but I liked her addition to the story. An extremely vague character at first, as you ventured through the show, her personality and character development really begins to grow on you. I'll admit, I wasn't too keen on as to why she was so concerned with defeating Nine, and still isn't completely sure, but whatever the case might've been, I was genuinely intrigued with her actions during the last couple episodes. It was quite surprising, and I enjoyed every minute of it. And not only that, she managed to come extremely close to destroying everything Sphinx was meant to accomplish, a very worthy opponent to the story, I'd have to conclude. Additionally, I found it interesting that she also shared similar symptoms to Nine.


Enjoyment: 9/10


Safe to say, I enjoyed every minute of this wonderfully rendered show. It got me thinking about so much I had never known before. I've always been a fan of Greek mythology and ancient gods, so watching this anime was also loads of fun. Every time it was time for the detective agency (mainly Shibazaki) to start cracking the riddles, it was like getting ready to begin an ancient mythology class, it was just that intriguing to me, especially since some of the things they talked about I had no knowledge about prior to watching the series. 


Overall: 8.5+ (It wasn't perfect, but it was damn well good enough)


This anime was very good. Much better and emotionally nerve-wrecking than I had ever imagined, which only made me love it more. Everything that went into this anime, from the story to the knowledge it provided, highly including everything that came in between, was amazing and brilliantly played out in a way that would draw anyone looking for a sophisticated, one of a kind AND well executed show. Oh, and keep in mind, no fillers. I've witnessed short anime series who actually had the audacity to squeeze in a filler. Never a good thing. Which is why this one is just precious in every way imaginable. Zankyou no Terror is a must, really. If your looking for an anime with some serious finesse, this is the one to watch, you won't regret it, and if you do, well... lets hope you don't.



*I apologize for any typos/grammatical errors by the way*

Zankyou no Terror is a toboggan ride that whisks you into its world immediately, with every minute of its 11-episode run speeding you down its intricate plot until you, completely satisfied and yet still yearning for more, reach its end. Though it’s an anime, it has none of the characteristics which turn away casual viewers of the genre—no fanservice, no awkward situations involving siblings, no overly forced comedy relief. It’s a show that takes itself seriously throughout its entire run, and doesn’t suffer for it. I would recommend it to anyone who enjoys shows with a gripping plot, a phenomenal soundtrack, and a cast ofwell-written and dynamic characters. Oh, and I forgot to mention: the art is excellent in both direction and execution. It’s easier to explain if you just watch the anime.


	Let’s begin with the plot. To pare it down to its most basic form, Zankyou no Terror is an action drama that focuses mainly on two young terrorists from Japan. The premise itself is quite novel, though the anti-hero protagonist has been done in other popular shows like Death Note. As the first episode finishes, you’re left with numerous questions regarding who the two teens are and why they’re blowing up building. And after each successive episode, the director Shinichiro Watanabe leaves you with more questions. When the show ends, it’s a very satisfying ending. It makes sense, and yet you’re still clamoring for more. At least, I was. So yes, the plot is VERY interesting, though I don’t wish to spoil it for anyone who may watch.


	As for the soundtrack, I’ll say this: not only does it have incredible production quality, but it also fits the atmosphere of the show EXTREMELY well. This is especially true for the tracks that play during emotional scenes. The OST as a whole has an unreal feel to it that mirrors the world that Watanabe builds. Though the show is ostensibly set in present day Japan, the main characters and their actions make the events that unfold seem impossible in our world. The OST fits this scenario extremely well.


	The characters, oh, the characters. The show has a relatively small cast, and I admire this choice because it allowed Watanabe to develop each character well with only 11 episodes. Nine, or Sphinx Number 1, is very serious about what they (Nine and Twelve) set out to do. His precision and cautiousness balance out Twelve’s (Sphinx Number Two) carefree playfulness, and the dynamic between the two is beautiful to see. The two grow as they accomplish their mission, though in subtle ways. Lisa Mishima is more of a flat character, being clumsy until the very end, but she doesn’t get annoying often. Now, the main detective who is on the Sphinx case, Shibazaki, is a veritable badass. Just search up a picture of him and admire that facial hair. Aesthetics aside, Shibazaki is the epitome of the hard-eyed detective who puts his life and salary on the line to pursue the truth. 


	The art is beautiful. Enough said there. Well, not really. Character designs are wonderful. Settings fit the atmosphere. Everything is very solid.


	I would give the show a 10/10, because it’s a complete package that fits into 11 episodes. It’s a relatively short watch, but is extremely worthwhile.

Zankyou No Terror is the story of the “why”, the “what”, the “when”… “How”, and so on.
I wasn’t particularly interested in the series, I mean I make the custom of watching the series that came out in such block, but I never really got into it… until the first episode. The damn thing is so attractive to the senses and in general much more solid than the average series that is not something I could just ignore, then I never really imagined the mediocrity that came after.
The plot revolves around two young terrorists that go in a rampage so they can expose some secret plansmade by the usual suspects, plans that involved some degree of human experimentation and secrecy juicy enough to feed the needy. After that the series focuses in the intrigue behind the terrorist attacks made by the group, and the police efforts to catch them.


You might except some interesting back-story and some intense development to the characters, after all the secrecy seems to have some dark history, so why not?… well you are left stranded as there’s no solid or interesting character or story development whatsoever, not of their origin story, their relationship as survivors and avengers, their motives which seem to be so important to them, etc. you name it, this series is as arid as your favorite desert (not the wet ones).


And that’s the main issue with this one, it’s full of potential yet lacking so much in the content department. It seems they thought the whole terrorist attack thing would stretch far enough to fill the whole series… but it doesn’t, the whole thing just feels incomplete as not even the apparent star of the series, this being the “detectivesque” story that fills most of the chapters, is overly scripted and unexciting as the plot itself lowers the tension behind them via its less than intense characters.


I could go on and on, as to wonder why there is not more development between the protagonists and the enemy featured later, why aren’t more back stories to characters such as Lisa which supposedly play a contrasting role to the protagonists (you are left in the let’s assume this thing as the obvious stereotypical answer), how far does the secrecy goes so we can feel the intensity and urgency of the plot, an a long etc. which is not worth the time… since the thing already ended along with every chance of this being something more.


Anyway, good idea, good visual quality, a definitive letdown… it didn’t particularly pique my interest, as I said, but it’s worth the warning.

Don't watch it. 
*possible spoilers*
This anime started well, for the first few episodes it really had me intrigued but all my questions remained unanswered episode after episode and then half way through they add an antagonist who was frankly, really crap, she trys to kill hundreds of people after a game of airport chess (really? how do they expect us to even imagine that?) all to kiss one of the main characters. 
Speaking of which, the characters, there was just nothing that made you feel for them or relate to them, nothing, for a moment in the last episode I thought that everything was plannedjust so he could see the northen lights before he died (I don't really think you can in Japan anyways..........) but it was less then a second and pff... just nothing. The girl could have just not existed, she does NOTHING in the whole series, like the antagonist says, she's just in the way all the time. \n\n
The only thing I liked was the animation and the music and the intrigue in the first few episodes. But I wouldn't recommend it to anybody at all.

[THIS REVIEW IS SPOILER-FREE]
After watching the last episode of Zankyou no Terror two days ago, I think I can finally come to a suitable conclusion for my mixed-up thoughts. Let's see if I can organize them into a coherent review, ahah. 
Story: 5/10 
I enjoyed the first couple of episodes, I really did. The story seemed interesting enough, and everything was so cleverly done (seriously, I felt like a dumbass pretty much the entire time T_T) that it was hard to NOT get hooked. I mean, terrorists! In Tokyo! With explosions! 
I think I got my hopes up too high, though.
After episode 8, with stilllittle to no explanations, I was beginning to wonder how everything would end up because there were only three more episodes left to reveal Nine's and Twelve's pasts, as well as their reasons for wanting to leave bombs that didn't actually hurt anyone all over the city. And my fears were right. I felt that their reasons, while touching (my heart is already in a fragile state thanks to Tokyo Ghoul), were a little bit too petty for my liking, and I found it hard to believe that the two of them would go through SO MUCH trouble just because of THAT. (< being purposely vague because spoilers suck.) 


In the end, ZnT had a pretty mediocre story that didn't live up to the suspense it had built up from the beginning.


Characters: 6/10 


So maybe I was a little unrealistic in my expectations for character development. Nine and Twelve were interesting for me in the beginning, but they quickly became boring after Ep. 8. I don't know, I wanted more from Nine (I have a soft spot for him... he's kind of hot, okay), though I did sort of like his smart-silence personality. And Twelve... WHAT HAPPENED TO MY CREEPY BABY? He had SO much potential in being a crazy but lovable psycho, but nope, after meeting Lisa he became Mr. Sweetie Hero. 


Which brings me to Lisa. Frankly, Lisa was a disappointment. I wanted more character development in her, because she remained pretty much the same throughout the entire anime: dull, one-dimensional, and weak. Look, I *don't* have a thing against weak characters -- but I want them to be properly done so that I can sympathize with them. For Lisa, apart from giving us a brief background of her family, that was pretty much it. I don't see what was so charming about her, or why Twelve risked his long-standing friendship with Nine for her in the first place. 


It's not to say that I hate the Twelve + Lisa ship, because I don't. I just feel that Lisa could have been crafted into a much more interesting character, even if she was weak, and maybe then it might have better justified Twelve's actions in Ep. 8. 


As for Five... talk about a drama queen. She was another character I found super badass when she first appeared (that hairdo, though), but after what she did in Ep. 10? I'm just-- I can't understand it. I can't understand why a girl with such a brilliant mind would choose to do that because it doesn't fit in with her character at all. 


---


I seem to be the black sheep here, though, so maybe I'm being a little too picky with an anime that's only 11 episodes long. Still, I do think that Zankyou no Terror could have been a lot better done if some things hadn't happened. *cough* Anyway, I still did enjoy myself while watching this, so my overall score is 7/10. I'm just crying for the lost potential. 


But, uh, on the bright side, at least the music is beautiful? YOKO KANNO, EVERYONE. Go search up "Walt" and prepare to have your mind blown.

I literally had to come to this website, which convinced me to watch the anime, so that I could let off my anger about how much I hate the girl Lisa. Literally more than the bad guys at this point.
I just want to punch her weak ass in the face, she is so annoying and only vaguely useful once or twice. I mean, I don't think she ever thought a single thing through through out the entire process, and honestly while I understand her relevance to the plot and the story, and her position as foil and her character as written basically to help withthe character development of the boys and to bare witness to their story, but I don't understand why she is there.


Like, why is she included, why was the story made to fit her in it, why was she made important. There seem to be people who watched this show and didn't mind her, but to me she was so consistently stupid, it was like watching "The Girl Who Leapt Through Time" all over again. 


Like, I realize she was a bullied, depressed, shrinking violet who was only just alive enough inside to not be suicidal, but there was never one part in the show where I feel like she actually realized the situation she was in. And not in a, "I don't want to think about my situation" way, but in a "I'm too stupid and have no common sense" way. God, she is definitely the kind of person who would get pulled into a cult.


I'm sorry for bitching like this, but she was honestly ruining the show for me the entire time. And it wasn't cute or even that much of a comedic relief. It was just super annoying.


Good show, awesome art and cinematography, all characters were at least servicable, but her, (and maybe that overly enthusiastic and emotional police officer character that every anime seems to need,). I can't enjoy shows completely if I can't enjoy the characters, so she almost single-handedly brought it down for me every time we focused on her. Honestly, she was just a damsel constantly in distressed who continuously made everything worse. 


Of course, none of this was really her fault, and 12 was the one who made contact, and she was desperate for contact, which was why she never turned it down. Still. It made it seem like it was her story, like we were seeing it through her eyes for the purpose of her development which is a common method of story telling, but I didn't like her enough to care that she "grew" as a person.


So, so, so stupid all of the time and always realizing things too late.


Ugh.

In my humble opinion "Masterpiece" would be one word to -probably- describe this anime, regretfully I won't use that word.
The story is amazingly well driven, it captivates you, the problem is that it isn't the most original story in the world, which is one of the reasons why I can't call this a masterpiece. The second reason why I can't it's because it's predictable. From the moment it starts you know how it will end, after all morality will always prevail against evil... Right?. So why did I rate "Story" with a 10? Well, because even though you know how it will end the journeymight surprise you, and the "journey" in this story is superb.


The art is beautiful, the way the scenarios are presented are breathtaking. Enough said.


The sound would be one of the "problems". Don't misunderstand me the end "mix" of sounds it's amazing, the music, the ambient sounds etc are really great, but in my opinion -and not just in this anime- when an American, European (etc, etc) appears in the anime let an American or European speak or the -lets call it- magic of the character vanishes away and the character becomes something that you can't "believe". Yes I know that this isn't an American production but trying a little harder doesn't hurt.


Characters, it's probably the best of this anime. Some might look useless but most of the time some of those "useless" character are important for they're "triggers" for the main ones. Ex. Lissa.


For a closure this anime was enjoyable, every episode leaves you hanging and guessing what's going to happen next -even though you already know how this will end-.

~ ~ Story 7/10 ~ ~
The story sucks you in from the very first stunningly animated heist scene and it stays fast-paced from there. It slows down only for us to get a little glimpse of the characters but not for long because the mystery behind Sphinx is what's driving the show. While I have to admit that there's an arc (about 3-4 episodes long) that felt kind of pointless in the grand scheme of things, the clever puzzles that are solved in each episode contribute to a heart-wrenching overarching tale of vengeance (or not, depending on how you see it). The grand payoff inthe end isn't as grand as I hoped it would be but it does leave you with much moral-questioning.


~ ~ Characters 7/10 ~ ~


Nine and Twelve were really interesting even though I knew next to nothing about them. Their interactions, the easygoing casualness of Twelve and the ice-cold rationalizing of Nine, balanced each other out. Lisa, the awkward highschooler with a troubled family background, paled in comparison because although her confusion was relatable, she didn't matter to the plot aside from being the occasional damsel in distress. On the other side of the table, the character of Five was like Lisa's more crafty and badass counterpart aka she also seems pretty useless too if you think of her role in the whole context of the story. Her reluctant rival/ally, Detective Shibazaki, was a brilliant character with an understandable backstory but he was by no means the most memorable anime detective.


~ ~ Art 10/10 ~ ~


It's realistic, fluid and has beautiful camera angling. The colors change according to the mood but overall it sticks to the realism (except for Five who has silver hair and purple eyes for no flipping reason).


~ ~ Sound 10/10 ~ ~


Yoko Kanno bless your soul, just bless you to heaven and beyond. Everything from the gorgeous opening sequence to that serene motorcycle scene ("Is feat. POP ETC") to the unique Icelandic song ("Von feat. Arnór Dan") was perfect at conveying all the feels.


~ ~ Enjoyment 7/10 ~ ~


Full of suspense in some moments, peace in others, WTFery in some scenes and "what's the point of all this?" in others. 


~ ~ Overall 8/10 ~ ~

A must-watch for anyone who's thirsting for strategic mindgames, likable morally ambiguous characters, and elegantly animated action sequences.

As an anime fan, at some point in the past or the future, we must explain an anime to a fellow otaku. Be it the religious symbolism behind Evangelion, or what makes Clannad one of the saddest anime ever, or why is Sword Art Online such a crowd splitter. But there are those few shows that can’t be explained so easily in full. Zankyou no Terror is one of these shows, a psychological masterpiece that deals with a topic hardly seen in anime, terrorism.
If you aren’t prepared going into this series, your brain will get thrown around the inside of your skull like a pinball,while you try to figure out who are the bad guys, and why they’re doing what they’re doing. Throw in governmental secrets and conspiracies, ancient mythology, modern society, the weakness of reality, and you got yourself a deadly mix. No worries though, everything gets explained in the end. And holy cow, the ride there is amazing.


STORY


(Before I say anything, I’d just like to point out, the director of this anime is Shinichiro Watanabe, yes, the same man who engineered the classic masterpiece, Cowboy Bebop. That said, moving on!)

Tokyo has just been hit by a terrorist attack and as the nation tries to look for the criminals, they come to light themselves. Through an internet video site they reveal themselves to the public; two masked teenagers that call themselves Sphinx. Their real names? 

Nine and Twelve.

The  meaning behind their names is explained in the series. 

They are hell bent on wreaking havoc on Tokyo, destroy buildings and blow up trains, yet the puzzling thing behind their schemes is that they never kill anyone.

Ever. 

Why would they plan everything so perfectly, give difficult riddles to the police to solve, blow up something yet not kill a single person? And so, we see acts of terrorism through the eyes of these two boys, and an innocent girl, thrown into this mess against her own will.


CHARACTERS

To start off with the main duo, Nine is a cool, collective and very intelligent boy, and from the outside, looks like a typical student genius. In the anime he is seen as the mastermind of Sphinx's operations. Almost a mirror image of Nine, Twelve is a loud and cheerful individual who helps Nine carry out his acts of terror. His cheerful attitude may be a bit off sometimes, like when he's throwing around a grenade like a tennis ball, or when he's on his motorbike flying past traffic down a highway. Together the two are a very interesting pair. From the outset, you may not know how to feel towards them. Are they good? Are they the bad guys? And because of the fact that they never kill, as viewers, we are drawn into the anime, trying to find out more and more about these two. 

The previously mentioned girl, Lisa Mishima, is a very shy and reserved character who is a frequent victim of bullying. To add to that, she has a mother who is insanely overprotective, to a dangerous level, so it's clear that she will find it extremely difficult to cope with the fact that she has no choice but to be an accomplice to terrorists. Even just her presence alone is enough to add a really dark tone to the show. Her clumsiness and inability to deal with dangerous situations makes this anime appear more dismal and sombre than it really is, and it makes the show even better. Yeah that's one of the parts that are hard to explain. Watch the anime and you'll see what I'm on about... 

Lastly, from the initial characters, we have Shibazeki. Shibazeki is an older police detective who has been thrown out from Investigations to Archives, due to an old case that went wrong. He is brought back because he's the only person who can solve Sphinx's riddles, and because he's the best detective that the police has. If you take Shibazeki, and mix him in with the rest, you may get a feeling of a similarity to Death Note in there somewhere. There is one more character that is important, however that is a big spoiler. 


ANIMATION & SOUND

The animation was done by a studio called MAPPA, a studio I've never heard of. 

I'll just say it the way it is, the animation is beautiful. Looking from the outside in, it doesn't look like much, but the animation greatly adds to the show, much more than any average anime would. The anime uses vivid colours, but it is dark at the same time, does that make sense? The show was made in 2014, and some scenes from it look like real life photographs. I mean, the detail used in some scenes is just spectacular. Also the art styles used for the characters are quite unique. For some reason, whenever I see Mishima's eyes, I think of Kurisu from Steins;Gate.

The soundtrack....

Um...okay. Two words. 

Yoko. Kanno. 

That is all. Yoko Kanno is one of the best composers for anime of all time. Known mostly for the epic soundtracks from Cowboy Bebop and Ghost in the Shell : SAC, she yet again uses her talent to create one of the best soundtracks I've ever heard. A mix of musical genres, with some excellent piano tracks, but where the soundtrack shines the most (and I mean, SHINES) are the vocal tracks. The most notable track in my opinion is the Icelandic song called "Von", sung by Anór Dan. This six minute wonder is just beautiful, a soft repeated motif on piano, with a gentle vocal and flowing orchestral strings...it's just, wow. 

The opening is also worth a mention. "Trigger" by Yuuki Ozaki (the guy who sang the Anohana opening) is as amazing as the rest of the soundtrack. In terms of visuals, I cannot describe it. It reminds me of the Steins Gate opening....with its shaking images and use of filters....


FINAL EVALUATION

Wow.... What an anime. Like I said, the only way to understand what kind of anime this is, is to go and watch it.

I find it difficult to believe that all of this fit into ELEVEN EPISODES. I know, right?!?! The only anime I've seen that had a short amount of episodes and worked so well was Anohana. 

Zankyou no Terror has so many unique elements to it, it has dealt with topics that are hardly touched in anime. It broke itself off the chain of typical animes, and oh boy, did it work well!

10/10 

A masterpiece.

I Really was surprised to see how well it was made. I watched the whole thing from start to finish in about six hours, and enjoyed every minute of it.

Why SHOULD you watch Zankyou no Terror? 

- gripping story

- unique story elements 

- excellent characters 

- amazing animation 

- oh the soundtrack.... 

- VERY interesting approach to the topic.

Why should you NOT watch Zankyou no Terror? 

- it is not a relaxation anime

- you may not like the characters

~thobiazz~

I'm going to be honest, I was really excited for Zankyou No Terror. You have my favorite director, Shinichiro Watanabe, teaming back up with my favorite composer, Yoko Kanno, to produce an anime with studio Mappa. Cowboy Bebop and Kids On The Slope are two of my absolute favorite series. It would be sacrilege for me not be excited especially with the trailer they showed off before it aired, but the important question is, did it live up to my expectations. Well, yes and no. Let me explain
Story
It's not often that you see for a thriller anime this grounded in reality like. There's no superpowers, magical girls, demons or shinigami. Zankyou No Terror manages to be unique and engaging without trying to get ridiculous like a lot of other series tend to do. It also doesn't treat the audience like a bunch of kids. Just because it's about terrorism doesn't mean that it's nothing but explosions and military style gunfights but it does have a couple of action scenes, it's a thriller after all. This series is pretty much all about mind games and it pulls it off very well but it has it's fair share of issues. There are a few plot points that happen after a new antagonist is introduced in the latter half of the series that just felt... dumb. To avoid spoilers, I won't actually talk about them to avoid spoilers but you'll know them when you see them. There's also the issue of the ending. Don't get me wrong, the ending itself wasn't actually bad but it's presentation felt a bit rushed. It's like 3/4 into the last episode, the producers just said "oh wait, this is the last episode" and then sent a frenzy of plot points your way and it all feels anti-climatic. To restate myself, the ending isn't actually bad, it's just the presentation. It could of really benefited from another episode.


Dispite a few short comings, Zankyou No Terror had a very solid and well presented story. 8/10


Art

Mappa did a fantastic job with the series. The animation reaches Five Centimeters Per Second level of quality on multiple occasions. It's incredibly crisp, detailed and consistent. The incredibly detailed animation  is also accompanied by some gorgeous lighting and great cinematography that showcases everything at creative and interesting angles. All this is also accompanied by some good character designs. Everybody actually looks realistic. You don't see the regular anime designs with big eyes and outrageous hair. I really like the designs.


The animation in Zankyou No Terror is absolutely stunning.  10/10


Sound

Yoko Kanno is the composer. Need I say more? She brings her A game here and it's some of her best work yet. Each composition fits the mood perfectly. The voice acting carries this same level of polish. Despite there being no english dub, the voice acting here is incredible. The actors really know how to potray the characters


Just like the animation, the sound is executed flawlessly. 10/10


Character

The characters are easily the most disappointing aspect of Zankyou No Terror. They never get any real development and the little they do get just feels pointless. The main character, Nine, is just soooooo boring. Twelve is a lot more interesting and actually gets developed but it's just so they can shove a pseudo romance thing where it's really not needed. Lisa is easily the worst of the bunch. She's a useless klutz. That's the beginning and end of her character and despite a lot happening to her in the series, she never develops. There's only one character I can say I actually like and that's Shibuzaki. He actually has an interesting back story, good development and expresses genuine emotion.


The characters are so mediocre with only one exception. They're easily the worst part of the show 6/10


Verdict

Zankyou No Terror might suffer a few pacing and character issues but this is still a very well done show that you shouldn't miss. 9/10

An outstanding story that was amazing for half of the series, and was ruined just because one character. 
Story 9 I Art 8 I Sound 7 I Character 7 I Enjoyment 7 I Overall: 7.6

Terror in Resonance has an air of mystery surrounding it, and the story progresses with more and more intrigue, attempting to capture the attention of the watcher and at last serving either stale or no answers. To be fair, I enjoyed the art and the music of the show. The opening is quite moving. We endeavour to learn more about Nine and Twelve and are handed out an explanation for their actions and the anime promptly ends two episodes later. Another season would have helped the characters be more fleshed out and make us more sympathetic towards them. The riddles make the anime seem moreprofound, though the reasons they're posed is once again unclear. Five is simply a terrible character with no motives but an intellectual competitor and the chess game she orchestrates in the airport was perplexing. The worst part was the answer to which all of the audience awaits: Why become a terrorist? To gain attention. To shed light on a morbid facility for orphans of which there were three survivors. There are a thousand less reckless ways of doing so. I did like Shibazaki, though he's your standard detective character. Overall, I enjoyed watching the show, though several aspects of it were disappointing. A dose of clarity and rationale would have done wonders. But there you go.

Zankyou no Terror, or Terror's Echo as I like to call it in English, is an action thriller anime about two young men and the terrorist acts they commit in Tokyo. Their names are Nine and Twelve, both names being numbers since they are never given proper names at any point in the show's run. Terror's Echo primarily focuses on them and what they wish to achieve through their acts of terrorism, although their intentions aren't entirely known until a bit later on. Other characters featured throughout the series are Mishima Lisa, a high school girl who is constantly bulliedby her peers and coddled by her overbearing mother. Kenjiro Shibazaki, a detective who is quickly caught up in the riddling schemes of Nine and Twelve. And lastly Five, an American FBI agent who appears later in the series and is somehow connected to Nine and Twelve. 


The main cast gets the most character development here, which is good given the series rather short length of 11 episodes. Some may be disappointed that it doesn't continue longer, but I believe it has just the right number of episodes so as to not overstay its welcome. The pacing is quick and tight, and the blend of action, character development, and story are perfect all the way up to the final episode. 


The visuals and audio are no slouches either. The animation is fantastic throughout, with good animation during the action sequences and fantastic art when things are a bit calmer. Even minor characters with little screen time are drawn incredibly well, and you'll never feel taken aback by side characters who look overly generic. The music is composed by Yoko Kanno, perhaps best known for creating the soundtrack to Ghost in the Shell: Standalone Complex. Her work is truly excellent here as well, giving the series a very modern feeling soundtrack that manages to be exciting, somber, and haunting all within the span of a single episode. The opening and ending theme also deserve praise, boasting beautiful animation and featuring excellent music to accompany them. I never once felt like skipping the opening or ending because of how good they are, and it really helps set the tone for each episode both going in and finishing it.


     If you're looking for a good thriller series with interesting themes and excellent writing, Terror's Echo may just be what you're looking for. It may be a bit heavy for some, but it is incredibly rewarding and highly entertaining, and as such gets my highest recommendation. Watch it, you won't regret it.

This anime was something I haven't seen in a long time.  Just by reading the story plot, made me want to jump right onto the 1st episode.  I really loved the idea the author had when making this anime/manga and he really developed the characters very well throughout the whole story.  
The art was very, how would i put it, up to date (?) And had really convincing sound effects for explosions, background, etc...  However there would be on flaw to this anime which kind of ruined it, was that towards the half end of the series, the story seemed tobe rushed.  I was not really pleased with how they developed their ending and it could have been written differently.\n\n
Overall the art, sound, and character were really top notch, and the story was a very interesting one.  I would recommend this anime to anyone who loves suspense, action, and a little bit of romance i guess.
