Zankyou no Terror (English title "Terror in Resonance") is an 11-episode anime directed by Shinichirō Watanabe (Cowboy Bebop, Space Dandy) that aired during the Summer of 2014. It is a mystery/thriller series with animation done by the studio MAPPA. 
  ~Story~
    I think my favorite thing about this series' story and plot is the topics it deals with. It discusses topics not dealt with commonly in anime, such as terrorism and social interactions. While terrorism is a main theme in this particular anime,  it also focuses on how people react in dire situations. However, I do believe there were afew plot holes. The series never truly explores the relationship between Lisa and her mother. While it is hinted on several occasions that her mother is possibly overbearing, it never explains why. Is her mother emotionally or physically abusive? Where is Lisa's father? Overall, I give the story a 9/10. I applaud the unconventional topics it focuses on, but I think a few things should have been explored more. 



   ~Art~

The animation was done by the studio MAPPA (Kids on the Slope) and character designs were done by Kazuto Nakazawa (Samurai Champloo). The animation for this series was very well done. The colors are all very sharp, and the character movements are extremely smooth. The quality of animation is consistent throughout the series, and the backgrounds and scenery are all very detailed and clean. The character designs, while not bad by any means, I feel could have been done a little better. No character's design is bland, but no character has any defining features either. The only thing that really stood out to me was Five's white hair. Overall, I give art an 8/10. Excellent animation, but the character designs could have been more detailed and/or interesting. 



 ~Sound~

The soundtrack for this series was composed by Yoko Kanno, who is very well known for doing the soundtracks to animes such as Cowboy Bebop, and frequently collaborates with the director of this series. The soundtrack for this anime is simply incredible. Every single track sounds different and interesting. Each song fits well with the mysterious tone of the series. My personal favorite tracks are "lolol", "von", and "fugl". The voice acting was also very good. The opening and ending are, to put it simply, perfect. They fit extremely well with the series, and are unique and unforgettable. There is no official English dub, but I hope when one is released it does justice to the Japanese voice acting, which is quite good.

Overall, I give sound a 9/10.  Incredible soundtrack and voice acting.



~Character~

The characters I think were the weakest part of the series. I had a particular problem with the main female character, Lisa. She has little to no character development whatsoever, and her back story is nearly unexplained. Moreover, her motives for her actions and tagging along with Nine and Twelve are only explored on a very small amount. 


Nine and Twelve are the overall main characters of the series. Although they also had very little character development, their back story was explained and explored upon, which I appreciated. Both are shrouded in mystery that is never fully revealed, but I believe that is what made their characters so interesting. Overall, I give characters a 7/10. Both Nine and Twelve are likable and well-written characters, but the lack of character development and Lisa's weak character are a problem. 


~Enjoyment~

Zankyou no Terror is not a series everyone will enjoy. It also explored topics such as riddles and puzzles, which may turn off many people. However, despite these things, I was completely engrossed and mesmerized by this series. Never once while watching it was I bored. If it suits your taste, it is a very compelling show. 


~Overall~

Zankyou no Terror by no means is a perfect series. Every show has its flaws, whether they are big or small. However, this series as a whole, in my opinion was a masterpiece. Yes, it has problems with character development, but the  unique story and brilliant sountrack make up for it. It is a haunting series which will leave you thinking hours after finishing it.

THIS REVIEW CONTAINS A POTENTIAL SPOILER IN THE PENULTIMATE (second last) PARAGRAPH.
Zankyou no Terror is a good anime. It's not the best Anime in the world, but it doesn't need to be. It might not be full of dramatic and jaw opening scenes like Death Note or investigative action scenes like Psycho-Pass, but it has its own flavor of story telling that may or may not seem clichéd to you (depending on how much anime you have seen).
The story is about two friends who are more like brothers. Nine and Twelve are on a mission to reveal to the world the deep, dark secrets thata country's government can contain. While they might be branded as terrorists initially, it is clear to the viewers that they are much more than that.


When it comes to story, this anime starts off a little slow, and doesn't reveal much until further on. But all of this simply adds to the moment and allows us to form a relationship to the 2 protagonists similar to the one Lisa Mishima develops. This all pays off towards the end (more on that later).


The art style was pleasant and light on the eyes. Depending on your tastes you might find it a common design. Sounds were good too, though I have heard more catchy jingles.


The characters, while mysterious for the most part, become a little relatable as they start to interact with the various other characters in the anime. While they may not be the most memorable characters (Nine and Twelve fit the category of "Super-smart kids that are beyond the 'system'"), they certainly did have their own charms.


All in all, the overall score and enjoyment go hand in hand for this anime simply because the finale managed to turn what was a seemingly good anime into a very good anime (in my opinion, of course). The shock plot twist at the very end left a bitter taste in my mouth after what seemed liked an almost happy ending. It was at this moment that we could sympathize with all the other characters who had just now begun to truly understand Nine and Twelve. A plot twist like this, that rattles our core and causes us to shake our heads in disbelief, is what makes the story of Zankyou no Terror one to definitely watch if you have some spare time on your hands.


The way the plot never became too dull, coupled with the great finale and interesting story is what made this anime an enjoyable one. If you're thinking of checking this out, you won't be disappointed.

A tragic story with both action and mystery, all leading to the unveiling of a dark truth. Despite how many people seem to think, this is truly not all that original of a concept. Of course, originality isn't really necessary for a good anime, so let's see what other aspects this one is lacking in.
The one issue that seems to destroy the story before it even gets started is that it's trying too hard. I still don't know at what, but the apparent originality of the concept is definitely a part of it. At times it did provide me a fair amount of enjoyment, butI can't honestly say I felt like it was actually trying to entertain me. The humor of the show was extremely weak, a complete afterthought, the action scenes were all filled with an opressive need for dramatic effect.


What was all the more apparent for that was that it wished to instill awe in the audience. It wanted to be deep, touching the viewers beyond the mere notion of 'entertainment'. That's not wrong, in fact it's enjoyable for me personally. But that's where it really falls apart; it's not plausible at all, thus failing to be 'deep' in any way at all. The suspension of disbelief is all about circumstance after all. If one wishes to tell a fantastical tale they need only take it into a fantastical setting. However, the setting of this story is the very real world with its very real problems. It is not impossible to tap into these problems for inspiration, but if you actually stage your story in such a completely established setting you need to be able to reflect the nature of that setting in your story. This anime didn't for a moment truly manage that. It hoped to depict tragedy but also hope on a massive scale; without death. Death in our world isn't a mystical thing reserved only for great occasions like the anime depicts it, bizarrely while including the legacy of the destruction in Japan following the second world war.


The issue of inplausibility goes beyond just the specifics of what happens in the story. It's the greatest blight of the characters of the story. In this of a supposedly the realistic world the characters can almost all be split into two categories of unbelievable. There's the ones that aren't really a part of the story, just filling in there to make it feel alive without having any purpose of their own. But more important are the core characters of the story; people that have one and all experienced tragedy that defines their roles in the story. And yet those tragedies are all just completely out of this world ridiculous or just normal things taken to stupid extents. I wish I could have related to the main characters, I really do, but that would have required a plausible explanation for what happened to them beyond 'humans are bad'.


The one thing that partly saves the story for me is Shibazaki; the single believable and relatable character in the story. One with real problems for which he looks real solutions, unlike the rest of the cast. A fine character, but not really great, he kept up the believability of the story long enough for me to enjoy most of it before I started actually thinking. Problem is, I started thinking before the end; which made the conclusion of the series fall completely flat.


The technical aspects of the show were more successful, though they suffer partly for the same problem as the story, of trying to be more than they are. The art quality was good, and fitting for the story that the show tried to depict, and animation were also very solid. Yet the way it's implemented reeks of attempted artistic signifigance where there was none. As such, the 'dreamy' feel that it attempts ends up simply a weak distortion of reality like the rest of the show.


Sound quality was overall good as well. The music were perhaps even better than that, but on the other hand the attempted English voice acting broke the immersion on more than one occasion. I'd like to give credit for the fact that the 'engrish' wasn't as terrible as it could be, but I can't ignore the fact that it's also far from how native speakers that they tried to depict actually sound.


The combination of all these aspects ends up with a completely unmemorable show where it clearly looked to be a dramatic and memorable story. Despite this I can't say I didn't find the show enjoyable to an extent, to start with at least. It was a fair bit of fun as long as I didn't apply any critical thinking to it. In the case of a show that hopes to be intelligent this really isn't praise, but there's at least the fact that the show wasn't memorable for being particularly bad either.


*sigh*


This is the kind of anime that offered me a decent amount of enjoyment as I watched it, but left me thoroughly unimpressed after the end. It kept up the appearances of intellect, but the more you actually look at it the more it really falls apart. And in the end, even as it clearly doesn't fall in the 'category' of intelligent, it still in fact believes it does. Further it takes itself deadly serious no matter how unbelievable the things it depicts. This is what I'd call pretentious - and I love a lot of stories that many others would call that.

This anime is just.. completely legendary. It brought out some new emotions that I've never felt before. At first, I never was interested in this anime AT ALL, but then I saw some wicked edits of it on Vine and the animation seemed pretty unique so I thought I should try it out. Woah boy, I did NOT expect the emotional train ride I just signed myself up for.
Story: The story really is quite captivating, I could not stop watching each episode and finished this whole series in one sitting. As you can see from the summary of the animation, it is based on thecorruption of the world's government. Though it may seem like a boring subject to base anime on, do not be fooled because as you watch more and more of it, you realize that there is much more that goes on, but I won't spoil it for you.


Art: Well, the art is just absolutely gorgeous. For an animation, it really made me feel like these things were realistic because of how precise all the character's facial expressions were and how the bombings turned out. It felt like I was watching a true situation being laid out before me.


Sound: I can only describe it in one word and that is: Indie. The soundtrack consisted of songs that are not popular in today's music industry and consisted of a lot of instruments, especially the acoustics in sentimental scenes. Although it's a new sensation to anime, it does not fail to compliment and enhance the emotion of each scene. But then, oh lordy, THE VOICE ACTORS. Big round of applause to those talented people. Their voices were just perfect, I have no complaint because they were mostly the reason why I cried and felt a rush of new emotions because of the passion they have in making their characters come to life.


Character: Although you do not get into too much background of where they came from, what they do in their current time just completely shapes their character and you get a good feel of how demented some characters' pasts were. None of the characters are the ones that you typically come by, these characters have far more sides to them than come to the eye, and that's what makes them so fascinating and captivating.


Enjoyment: As you can see, I have no complaints whatsoever and although I experienced quite some depressing emotions, I absolutely have not regrets over it. 


Overall: So the basics of what I'm saying is that YES. I DEFINITEY RECOMMEND YOU TO WATCH THIS. Coming from a person that's been strictly Shoujo for 8 years, that's really a lot as this anime is way out of my league but nevertheless did not fail to make an impression on me. I'd definitely want to watch this over and over and over again.

Zankyou no Terror is one of those rare short series (at only 11 episodes) that clearly conveys its plot and message clearly with little divergence from the main story line and contains a fulfilling ending. I can honestly say there are only a few series less than 15 episodes that have left me as satisfied as this one. Would I call it a masterpiece? No, but there’s a reason why it got such a good reception. It’s well executed and stays within its limits. What I mean by this is that it doesn’t try to develop into some convoluted plot that leaves the story withholes. 


Story:

In a few sentences, Zankyou no Terror follows two terrorists known as Nine and Twelve who release videos to the public containing a riddle, which, if solved, reveals the location of the bomb they planted. Little does everyone know, these terrorists have an ulterior motive that ties their mysterious past to their actions. 


The series is clean in its execution (aside from a few minor issues, which are discussed later), which is as plainly as I can put it. It’s well paced and stays loyal to the main plotline without overdramatizing each character’s past. Where many series struggle is by either over-analyzing each character’s past to the point where it becomes filler or leaving characters in the dark. In my opinion, finding the proper balance is no easy feat and many shows fail in this respect, but Zankyou no Terror did a good job of staying poised by unraveling the protagonists’ pasts steadily during each episode. 


The first few episodes are a little repetitive and caused the show to lose some of its luster. The terrorists post a video, the police try to decipher it, and then they go on a scavenger hunt for the bomb. However, I didn’t find each subsequent episode more boring than the previous because of this. The tension remains stable until after episode 4 when the main antagonist comes into play and builds all the way to the finale. The last episode is definitely one to remember. It ties everything together nicely and leaves the viewer with something to remember. 


Overall, the plot wasn’t predictable even during the repetitive episodes. There were always minor twists that caught me off guard. The story was revealed without being too vague or too obvious and it had me gripping my seat with the anticipation of not knowing what would happen next. The story is definitely what viewers will commit to memory after watching. 


Characters:

The cast features a nice variety of characters, but none of them were particularly memorable. I feel that most viewers will remember this series for its plot rather than the characters. However, the show did a great job of creating a cast with personalities that weren’t too overbearing or ridiculous. Each character plays an important role even if it is a subtle one. What I enjoyed most about the characters was their development as the story progressed. Each character had a specific goal or desire in mind that inspired their actions. By the end of the series, each character had matured to some degree, which was reflected by their actions. 


*Skip to “Art” if you don’t want character summaries


Nine and Twelve are fun to watch. Nine is generally the brains behind each bombing and is incredibly insightful while Twelve is the comic relief and spontaneous character. Although opposite in personality, they fit together perfectly. 


There is a lot of intellectual combat between the characters. For the first half, Nine and Twelve primarily face against Shibazaki (secondary antagonist), a gifted investigator over-dedicated to his work and was recently demoted for a previous case. He’s the only one who can decipher their riddles, at first. He plays a vital role in revealing the protagonist’s true intentions behind their attacks. 


A sudden change of events occurs with the introduction of the main antagonist and old “friend” of the protagonists, Five, an American FBI agent. I felt her role was somewhat wasted or, to put it more lightly, anticlimactic. I wouldn’t call her presence overbearing, but her process of thinking is highly erratic and causes quite an interesting twist in the story because she does everything in her power to thwart Nine and Twelve’s plans. Her personal motives (aside from her job) for pursuing the protagonists, specifically Nine, were still somewhat unclear to me by the end of the series. I can’t say anymore without spoiling one of the most climactic parts of the series, but her role in the show could have definitely been better. Even so, she certainly made the show more exciting. 


Lisa is another side character that is present through most of the show. She plays a “subtle” role and is, to say the least, pretty useless, often getting in the way of Nine and Twelve. However, I didn’t feel that her presence was unnecessary or annoying. Her friendship with the two, mostly Twelve, provides some of the only genuinely happy moments in the series and, although secluded from society in different ways, find common ground because of their alienation. 


Even saying this, viewers just starting the show will probably dislike Five and Lisa, but I felt that they added to the show to make it more fulfilling. 


Art:

There were some impressive action scenes that were enjoyable to watch, but the animation was nothing outstanding or revolutionary. It’s simply good and suits the characters and story. One thing I thoroughly enjoyed about how the show was animated was that the character’s emotions were somewhat complimented by their environment. When the characters were faced with confusion or despair, the scene was often dark and secluded. Conversely, times of contemplation and happiness were complimented by brighter and livelier scenery. I felt this amplified the emotions of each character and made them more realistic. 


Sound:

The directors compiled a good list of songs. The OT “Trigger” sung by Yuuki Ozaki from Galileo Galilei captures the nature of the show. The OST consisted of a variety of genres that complimented each scene very well, but, overall, nothing to create a lasting impression. 


~~~


To reiterate, this show stands out because of its well executed plot that continues to build tension without faltering or revealing too much, all the way up to the heart-gripping conclusion. The show certainly had its flaws including a somewhat repetitive plot early on and a few underwhelming characters. However, the show says something about human nature and where true terrorism lies. I found it to be a thrilling watch with riddles, bombs, and a pair of ambiguous protagonists for added unpredictability. It’s a pretty straight forward show with no confounding philosophical themes to confuse the viewer. It was one of my personal favorites of the year and I feel that most people will find it worth watching. 


I recommend this show for people who like Death Note or Tokyo Magnitude 8.0 because of the similar dark, serious nature in them. 


Hope this helped!

(This review does not focus on any segment and is more of a reasoning of why I gave ZnT a 5, I do list good points but I mainly point out the bad things, this is still a review and structures like one.)
Shinchiro Watanabe has made some goddamn memroble ass series', in the year of 2014, the first one which aired in Winter was Space Dandy, a fun and enjoyable show which got good response from audience, a second season came out in Summer, during summer, this show also was airing, and it got massive amounts of praise, but in reality, it didn't really needall of it, this didn't really feel like Watanabe's works. His other works feel free to do anything, for example, in Cowboy Bebop, the plot and characters were given to us in about 8 episodes and from there on, the story could do what it wants, it could focus on any topic. Here it just feels strict and forced, 11 episodes really isn't enough to spread the story here. Cause of this it makes characters feel less memroble and have less time to develop, now I'm not saying that 11 episodes is way too little for a show, there's amazing shows that are only 11 episodes such as The Tatami Galaxy. The developements needs more time and the plot needs more explaining and the explaining done in this show is rushed and needs to take its time.


Now I sound like i'm saying way too many bad things about this show and sound like I'm just gonna shit all over this show. Well not really, some key points to this show is the music and animation, this is not the only good things about the show but I do want to get it out of the way. The music is general is goddamn beautiful, its OST is filled with vibrant and calm moods, its a OST I'd actually pay money for. The OP is creative and inutitive with its vibrant animation and great concept of its music. The ED is a sad tune to really make you feel sympathy for some of the characters and the one it focuses on. the voice acting is solid and performed well by the characters. I could go on a whole paragrah or two saying how beautiful the music is, but this is a review, not a music analyzation. The animation is well done, everything seems hyper-realistic, people actually drew all this shit! The character designs are drawn well and look realistic as animation forms. This leads to the next good couple of things about this show.


The realism of this show is a whole 'nother level compared to other anime's worlds, it makes slice of life look like a puppy. Yes you heard me, a thriller's world makes a slice of life's look childish. The world is what you'd expect in modern society, the show even shows you some civillians lives when something happens and their reactions, it really shows you this isn't some place where anything can happen out of nowhere. This just sucks you into the show, even the technology used by the main MCs fr

or bombing and hacking are actual things from the real world such as Apple products, Sony, even out of that. Now I'm only mentioning this to show its realism, not, 'the MCs use Apple, the MCs have shit taste, why aren't they using [insert non-apple thing here]? Take a note of that.


The only way I was able to watch this show was cause of this world alone, other than that, it seems, meh. There isn't really much else from that. The characters are intriguing at first but as you learn about them, by the last couple of episodes, the only entertainment is the tense scenes, music and beautiful scenery. The world is pretty much how it would act in panic mode which has been done before in anime. So really, the beautiful world just becomes something frail.


Now for the only thing i haven't mentioned, the characters, the glue between Story and Enjoyment. We have Nine and Twelve, Both these are the MCs and are terrorists, the interesting thing about them is that they don't kill anyone when doing their attacks. By the end of this show, even when we know all about their pasts, we still don't know why they don't kill people during their bombings. Now their personalities (no pun intended) are average at best, Nine is smart, brutal and poker face all the time man while Twelve is happy, clumsy and smiling all the time man. Their bond is strong, they both act as if they're brother of sympathy and pain. Later on in about episode 4 or 5, Lisa joins in on 9 and 12. As much as I don't wanna say it, she's more of a plot-device than anything and is goddamn useless to the plot. We don't know shit about her past, she gets bullied for some reason and she runs away from here mom cause she's overprotective, why she runs away? What does her mother really do? Sure we see her call and text her daughter (Lisa) more than usual but we don't know much about her. She has a bond with 12 yet why we need this bond? We don't really know, probably added for fanservice and pointless shipping. What I'm saying in this long paragraph in summary is that these characters have their ups and downs but in reality they feel rushed and leave plotholes.


Story: 5

Art: 10

Sound: 10

Character: 6

Enjoyment: 5


Zankyou no Terror has so much potential yet dosen't have enough episodes nor time to space it out. Its a good idea done poorly. I like the idea of the terrorism. I like how smart 9 and 12 are. I like how they plan out their bombs. I like how they trick the police. I love the fuck out of the world, music and animation. This show could have been something amazing, if it had 22 episodes and had more time to flesh out things, this show could be a deep message about terrorism. Do I reccomend this show? Well not really, but as time to waste, go ahead, its only 11 eps and can easily be finished in one sitting. ZnT is good ideas wasted.

Zankyou no Terror, an anime that basis it's story on acts of terrorism caused by two very intelligent individuals, as well as some random girl that was taken as an accomplice.
I first want to start this review off by stating the premise of Zankyou. We are first shown with these two teenagers infiltrating a nuclear facility. This is where we are introduced to the characters personalities. One being ecstatic and carefree, while the other one is calm and collected whilst accomplishing their mission. Through this we can see the establishment of this dichotomy of personality between the two protagonists. This difference usually ends up withinteresting dialogue as well as a good variety to the upcoming moods of the show. Not only that, but it also ends up leading to some problems between the two.


Now that that has been said, I want to talk about the story, or the main plot of this anime. These two individuals, the main protagonists, are refugees from a government funded settlement. Without spoiling anything, I wish to say that throughout the anime, they start to slowly uncover the secrets of this settlement, which in fact leads to the main reason for the actions of the terrorists. Now the terrorists, named Nine and Twelve, commit a series of bombing attacks. The twist here is, before the terrorist attack occurs, these two put themselves out in social media (in this case a parody of youtube) behind a mask (literally and figuratively), to which they are called Sphinx 1 and 2. They then propose a riddle, solving the riddle will allow for information related to the coordinates of the bomb. As the show progresses, the riddle goes from the targeted audience of the main public, to the police. Publicity is something that they require, something that is essential to their overall plan, therefore messages directly towards the police would not suffice, rather they broadcast the video to the general public. The reason being that they chose the police, is because there is someone there that they require in order for the plan to follow through. 


The characters bring forth an interesting variety of emotions. As mentioned previously, we have Nine, the calm and collected of the two, and Twelve, the carefree, ecstatic one. As I've also mentioned this dichotomy is important. Because of Twelves personality, we've come across another character (episode one) who becomes a burden to the two. Note that I said earlier than his personality would bring them trouble, and it sure did. The addition of Lisa was a pain for me, she hurt more than she helped them, but she was a key figure in character development within Twelve. 


To wrap things up i want to say that I truly enjoyed watching this anime. they did a fantastic job with the art, the story was something that easily hooked me, and the sound, the OST really stuck out in those dire situations, rather than just some noise in the background. Overall I would give this a 9/10.

Having watched this based solely on a recommendation I didn't hold high hopes and thought I would give 1 episode a try. I now sit here 6 hours later having finished the anime trying to find words that do it justice.
We all have that one day in our lives that we lived, that felt real and will be remembered, it may not have been a big day such as a wedding but could have been as simple as a day off work or the perfect date. This is exactly what Zankyou no Terror feels like. It doesn't rely on one big shock factor to sealthe deal it paces everything perfectly, leaving you satisfied, not wanting more or less. every element did their part to bring this masterpiece together. While it may not contain a big twist or shock factor it feels like a show that has been shown love and affection by the animators.


Each and every character feels like they are reaching out to the audience, the story feels real and the soundtrack reaches right into your heart. The message is constant throughout and changes as the narrative progresses, leaving you asking "if you had the chance, could you do it?".


I was on the edge of my seat the whole time with this anime, it was as though I was a part of it and for once I'm not upset that a journey has come to an end. Rather I feel better having seen it and knowing I can do it justice through recommending it to others. 


I don't think there will be an anime that will immerse me as much as this one did.

Terrorism is a very touchy subject. Everyone has their own opinion about the concept as a whole and what should be done about it. Truthfully, terrorism is an awful thing that plagues the world today and is not something that should be taken lightly. But Zankyou no Terror (or Terror in Resonance as some know it) takes the idea behind terrorism and handles it, well, beautifully. The 'terrorists' in the show aren't out to destroy because they can or just because they feel like it, but instead they have a very deep purpose behind their acts of violence...or rather, nonviolence. While the two boys, 9and 12, do destroy property, they plan out their attacks so carefully that no one gets more than a little scrape during the commotion. They manage this by hacking into computers or setting off alarms or even getting the police involved in the case. They want to commit these crimes, but no one needs to get hurt.


Now as for the show itself, it's rather standard. Terrorists make a plot, police try to bring them down, one side stands victorious at the end of the day, repeat. It would get very dull or standard if not for the characters. The characters are truly what make this show (well, them and the opening, "Trigger", which is a beautiful song). Characters range from being light-hearted and kind terrorists to a shy, reclusive girl who wants nothing more than to be bolder, and washed-up cop that is striving to take the terrorists down, no matter what the cost. The characters are truly the greatest aspect of this show and without them, it wouldn't be worth the watch.


As stated, terrorism is a very sensitive subject for many people and that may turn them away from the show. But here's the thing: this show handles such a horrid subject so well that it's almost perfectly done. The creators don't try to make light of the topic and many times even the terrorists know what they're doing is wrong, but it's all they can do in order to fulfill their wishes. There aren't plot holes left at the end of everything and the whole story is wrapped up nicely. In fact, this show may have one of the most emotional endings and it's so perfect for the show, but I won't say more in case I spoil anything. Bottom line is that you shouldn't miss this show.


Positives:

+"Trigger" is a beautiful opening

+Characters and character development are near flawless and it really makes the show

+The topic of terrorism is handled perfectly

+You will experience quite a range of emotions from watching this show

+Ending is amazing and fits the show very well

+Animation is very solid the whole way through

+Soundtrack is beautiful and well composed


Negatives:

-Only 12 episodes (though, I'm not sure this is such a bad thing in this case)

-Some characters behave very unrealistically. I'm sorry but when you're a terrorist, you can't afford those kinds of liabilities

-A few aspects of the main story aren't full explained or are not explained well


As I sit here, I can't think of many negative aspects for this show. Even the ones above are slightly half-assed. Yet, I know it wasn't flawless at all. Perhaps it just didn't sit well with me. But, overall, Zankyou no Terror is a beautiful show that handles a touchy issue very well and is one of the more unique anime experiences I have seen. 

And that is why Zankyou no Terror AKA Terror in Resonance gets an 8/10

Zankyuu no Terror was undoubtedly one of the highly anticipated anime of the 2014 summer season. Besides other high profile anime like Akame Ga Kill, Aldnoah Zero, Tokyo Ghoul that honestly didn't meet my expectations, Zankyuu no Terror was next on line. From the same directors, Watanabe Shinichiro with Yokko Kanno, that produced Cowboy Bebop, Zankyuu no terror was yet another great anime
Story 9/10
The story kicks off on a present day of Japan,Tokyo, Tokyo Metropolitan Government building becomes a victim of a terrorist attack led by only 2 genius teenage  student causing the power to shut down temporarily . From this point on,its like seeing Yagami Light and L from DeathNote working together again. The 2 boys refer themselves as Sphinx, Nine and Twelve. During the process of the first "terrorist attack" a young girl, Lisa Mishima, was unlucky to be inside the building and found Twelve planting a bomb. Twelve gave her a decision to die or saved by us but has to become an accomplice in the group. As bomb were exploding the building she decides to join them and later was saved by Twelve. After the big incident, they wasn't any fatalities. Fire alarms conveniently starts up and the police were able to safely guide the people inside without any trouble whatsoever. 


Art/Animation 8.7/10


Art was visually stunning on the get-go. The shading and coloring were made as realistic as possible.The attention detail on the whole city of Tokyo was superbly done as it brings modern like city area. 


The whole animation was absolutely breathtaking. There wasn't any dropped quality on all of the episodes and i highly recommend to watch the show on HD. The animation of the character was fluid and manage to capture actual human movements as possible. 


Soundtrack  9.7/10


All the beautiful soundtrack, oh my gosh. The soundtrack was so great to the point i often lose track of the show as the soundtrack start playing EACH time. From the series title. Zankyuu No Terror, most audience would expect the soundtrack would be filled with mostly dark and action music genre. But it's not all that


https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6GZWhAdqHys


Listen to the whole video at least to the whole chorus part. 

(Don't worry its SPOILER FREE)


Character 9.5/10


The two main protagonist, Nine and Twelve, has complete opposite of  personality. 


Nine, the calm and collected personality but also cold eyes as in not a friendly type. He does have a caring heart, being together with Twelve the entire time. His determination on having his plan succeed is shown as he is willing to take risk. Nine skills is shown to be more of a master hacking and planning their next attack. Able to hack the Police Department official list of criminals with ease and giving tricky riddles


Twelve, the cheerful and happy personality. He has one of the most interesting personality as he is more than a just lovable person. Never judge a book by it's cover truly states what he is like deep down. He is shown to handle task other than Nine's task. Prefers to drive at high speed on a traffic and sets up bombs. He is also shown be sneaky as he is able to avoid the security camera vision on complicated angles.


Lisa Mishima, the female protagonist who has suffered both domestic and social problems in her life. As the story progress, she starts to form a bond between the two male protagonist that literally saved her problems and also her life. She's also shown to help on the "terrorist attack". This shows that she isn't the typical damsel in distress.


Shibazaki, the former detective that got his job back because of the terrorist attack. So far out of the whole police department, he is the only one that is able to understands and solve Nine's tricky riddles. This is also due to his past cases connecting to the terrorist attack.


Five, the female genius tactician that focus entirely on defeating Nine. A rival of Nine since at a young age, Five comes back and plans to destroy Nine and Twelve plans. The rivalry between them, i enjoyed every minute of it. Always thinking ahead of their opponent is simply thrilling.


Overall/ Enjoyment - 9.5/10


If you have not noticed yet, I enjoyed every minute of it and would say this i series is as close as masterpiece. It certainly gives the vibe from DeathNote, another masterpiece. The reason why is said is only close to masterpiece is, personally i would like to see a little bit more depth of Nine and Twelve background story. Like how did they end up on the whole project thingy when they were kids. Five should also be given much more in depth of her character, maybe explaining why was she so concerned on defeating Nine,maybe Five had a bad past issue on Nine or simply jealous. who knows 


Nevertheless, this series is truly amazing

The story revolves around young children who were wronged and how they come to terms with their grief to ensure their voices are heard.
Zankyou no terror is a show that can burn a hole through your heart. The show portrays a pain that feels so real, even if it's not yours to bear.
The underlying romance depicted adds wonders to the story. It's restrained but profound. At one point of time, you feel your heart cry out to the possibilities that could have existed.
The music adds on beautifully to the feel of the anime. The Icelandic tunes mixed in with the Japanese tracks and with anEnglish OST appeals not only to the Japanese audience but to a greater population.


The art – one word – spectacular


The characters could have been developed if the show was longer than 11 episodes (which I wish it was).


Definitely a must watch. It’s not a feel good show but gives a reality check.

Zankyou no Terror may be worth watching if you’re a fan of Death Note and/or similar anime. However, while the art is fantastic, the story seriously drops off at the half-way point with the introduction of a certain character. The premise that is revealed later in the show, along with Five, feels quite tacky and really undermined what I thought could have been a really interesting and cool show. Zankyou no Terror has the looks but not much of a personality.
The show has some decent characters, personally I liked Nine and the dynamic that 9 and 12 had with both the detective and schoolgirl. Overallthough, I felt like Zankyou could have been so much better if it went into a different direction plot-wise that supported its themes better. The things they want to say were left half-done it felt like. Certain other plot elements felt weak and underdeveloped as well(the ‘game’, for example). I ‘get’ it, but the manner in which they go about their mission seems pretty ineffective at actually accomplishing their goal…something that turned me off of the series when I was finally done. All in all it felt very…postmodern, if I had to use one word to describe it.

-This review is spoiler free-
Story (10/10) 
Yes, I know. You're going to start seething in fury. You're going to start rampaging throughout the streets because you think that I'm overrating this anime in every shape and form. Now, this is the part where I completely and utterly disagree with you. This is where I allow you to understand my outlook on this anime and share my opinions. 
Yes, this story deals with terrorism. However, it is completely on a different scale. The depth of their reason allows our mind to go beyond the boundary. It is almost similar to Tokyo Ghoul. There are two sides,but each side has no "good" or "evil." They follow their own path and choose what they seem is right. You could also say that the terrorists are the "ghouls" and the police are well... the police. 


Furthermore, the way the clues follow through the story is completely outstanding. They even add hints of other interesting facts. They mentioned the story of "Oedipus." A little twist of riddles that make you sit through and think. Completely mind-boggling. 


Art (9/10)


Ahh, what can I say about the art? It's original and unique. The characters are so exquisitely drawn. It's like an eloquent brush of black ink that traces alongside the shades and corners of their skin. It's realistic but imaginative. It's marvelous. 


Sound 10/10


Very dramatic scenes when it comes down to the voice acting and sounds. The suspenseful music makes you question about the next outcome. That little mint in the corner? Yeah, that's a bomb in disguise. The voice acting is beautifully done.


Characters (10/10)


They are distinct and have individuality. They have their past and secrets, and there's these questions that keep bubbling up inside of you whenever you look at their faces. Remarkable. Absolutely remarkable. Nine and Twelve are complete opposite, but are the complete same. They cannot live without each other. Their puzzles that are side by side, but are not allowed to entwine. 


Enjoyment (9/10)


At first, it was steady. I kept stalling and multi-tasked throughout the first few moments of the episode. However, when I finally got right down to it - I never regretted the decision. It was a stunning experience. The way the whole idea was formed and created. The way they made the viewers actually VIEW the story - and to make it even better, you get to see both sides. I enjoyed it very much.


Overall (9/10)


This anime may not be for anyone. The ending did make me shed a bit of tears - but I knew it was coming (I kind of spoiled myself. Whoops.) If you have a weak heart, just keep reminding yourself that the story isn't real. However, I enjoyed every ounce of it. Lisa is such an adorable woman. Her heart is set at the right place, and she never fades into darkness. 


To conclude, this anime is not a very "fictional" anime. Its originality and realistic aspects is the thing that drew me in, and made me hooked. Therefore; if you aren't that type that sits down and enjoy psychological situations, and prefer a much more idealistic tone, you may want to lay this one down. However, if you do try it, you won't be disappointed!

Zankyou no Terror hooked me with the amazing music in the preview.  What will keep me watching is the amazing animation and captivating plot.
The plot is so captivating simply because there’s so little that’s actually revealed in this first episode.  We know that Nine and Twelve are terrorists of some kind based on their actions... but we know little more than that. 
Zankyou no Terror also has top-notch animation.  There were several times during the episode's that I had to remind myself that I wasn’t watching a live-action show but rather something animated.  A lot of time and energy clearly wentinto animating the scenery, in particular. \n\n
On top of the amazing animation is the excellent soundtrack.  The opening song is what hooked me on the series, but the ending song and the soundtrack are just as good.  The soundtrack is very understated unless you’re listening for it (which I often do), but it definitely highlights the action on screen.\n\n
Zankyou no Terror has the potential to be the best anime I've seen thus far, and it’s definitely one too remember...

Where do I go from here? I literally found myself trying to think about what to do after finishing this show.
It's one where after you're done, you just have to sit there and consider what you just watched. Usually, I say, well, that was a good show, onto the next. In this case, I don't know if I should watch anything right now, because I don't think I'll be able to enjoy it as much. For a first time reviewer, I'm not going into depth about each aspect, more vague, so you can enjoy it yourself. It's a show that I'd recommend going into itwith the least you can know.


As for the STORY, I'd say it was something pretty interesting, it really did keep me interested, without gaps. There were times when I could not wait to find out about different aspects of the characters, or different pieces that I would put together. Put simply, the story was fun to follow along with, and intriguing, not often do you get a show about Terrorism that does it in such a bright way.


I can't say that the ART stood out way too much, it was definitely something I enjoyed, but it wasn't anything as outstanding as the rest of the show. In no way does it hold it back though. The art style was done quite well in certain scenes to bring out more emotion, which was beautifully done.


Now for the SOUND of the show. Yoko Kano's work here was amazing with pieces that could not have fit the scenes better in my opinion. I'm a simple man, with simple tastes, but not only were the intro, and ending songs spectacular, but in certain minimalistic parts of the show, where it's more focused on the emotions being brought out, the sound track only amplifies it... This is an OST I will most likely find myself listening to for a long while. This music is highly in my taste, so of course this could be more swayed towards my personal opinions, but in some parts of this show, I feel like the sound track stood out so highly.


Another great aspect I liked about the show was that the CHARACTERS were easy to follow in major aspects, but you still did have to do some piecing of the puzzle out. The majority of this, features 5 people who are very memorable in each of their aspects. There are some very obvious troupes that a certain character falls into, which isn't necessarily a bad thing, but while in many aspects he feels like a cool or interesting character, you almost feel everything he is going to do coming. Either way, this is a strong point of the show as well, because each character's motives, and development are strongly etched into me after this show. 


Moving to ENJOYMENT, I'd say this was a show I can't wait to give a few months, so I can get myself to watch it again. I may have literally just finished watching it, but I can't wait to watch it again. I want to relive those moments where the OST makes me fall in love. There are always shows you wish you could forget and watch all over again, because you know you'll never be able to experience what you have, and for me, this is one of them. I'm hoping the show has good re-watch-ability (which is totally a word). 


Finally, I come to the end of my first review, calmed a bit, still trying to consider if I will be able to go back and watch more GTO... The impact this show left on me was enough to really leave an impact, and I may be a simple man with simple tastes, but I'm honestly glad I watched this show, and hope for more shows that can try and combine such a melancholic sound track, and beautiful story, with characters that are enjoyable.

Zankyou no Terror is not so much an anime about terrorism, so if you are looking for an anime completely centered and about terrorism, then I would not personally recommend this Anime. 
Zankyou no Terror is about 2 people who were put in a test lab and lived out their childhood there. The 2 escaped and lived on together after that becoming very close, almost like brothers. Another character is soon after introduced called Lisa. Her mother became depressed and insane after her husband left her, and went crazy whenever Lisa left the house, because she feels as though she will walk out of herlife too, so she sends text messages constantly to her, and even at home harasses her, saying things like "please don't leave me like your father". Anyways, she runs away and stays with the two others.


Throughout the Anime we learn more and more about the childhoods of 9 and 12 (the 2 close friends lab names), and get closer to the characters.


The Anime has an outstanding story, some of the best art you will ever see in Anime and great characters that you will come to love. However, the voice acting for the Americans was quite poor and came across as stupid at times.


Over all, this is my favorite Anime that I have seen to this day, and I have seen over 50. I highly recommend watching it.

Shinichiro Watanabe is considered by many as the best anime director of all time. With works such as Cowboy Bebop, Samurai Champloo, Kids on The Slope, and Space Dandy, one might agree that he is. So when Zankyou no Terror was first announced, a lot was really happy and excited for it. Not a big fan of Watanabe myself, I was quiet when the whole thing was happening. At the back of my mind I thought it was going to be the same old episodic stuff again. But once the first episode was released… *boom*. So, a simple question to find out in this reviewwould be: Does it live to the hype or was it ruined by it? Hopefully, by the end, we can come up with the same answer.


Story:


	I’ll be honest, when I first heard about this show; I wasn’t really that much excited about it. Having seen only two shows directed by Shinichiro Watanabe (Cowboy Bebop and Space Dandy), I thought I knew what to expect: “an episodic anime with new stand-alone stories every episode” like Bebop and Dandy. Boy, how wrong I was. Though ZnT is a bit episodic (at least during the first episodes), it is not like Bebop and Dandy in storytelling. It doesn’t really follow a weekly “stand-alone” episode formula but a rather interesting story with an overarching plot. It was rather surprising for me because it’s a fresh new thing in which Watanabe’s name was attached to. After the first episode, I was immediately hooked and I continued watching it from then on. Though I would never rank it higher than Bebop because I would get a lot of hate from the old fags (well, I’m one of them), I would say that it is “up there”. For the first show that fully tackles the aspects of terrorism, it surely deserves praise. The closest shows I’ve seen with terrorism aspect in it are Code Geass and Guilty Crown. And terrorism was just like a statement in both series. It was like “these groups are terrorists.” And that’s about it. 


Though the story may not be that fleshed out, I think it is one of the few recent anime that will stand against the test of time and 10 years from now, it will still be talked about just like how Bebop is still being talked about today 17 years after it first aired.


 Characters:


	The characters are a bit hard for me to talk about. I don’t really know how I feel about them. I like them but I know that they have a lot of problems. Though some of them might be likeable for the most part, they all share a ton of problems that one might just ask why. I refuse to talk about Nine and Twelve because they’re fine (at least for me) so let’s just talk about the 2 obvious ones.


	First is Mishima Lisa. Though Lisa is a dunce, I liked her character. Not because she was a well written character but because she was just fun to watch because of her role/curse. It’s as if her role in the series is to be a disaster magnet. Throughout the series, she has been in dozens of close calls and unfortunate events. It’s as if every day in her life is Friday the 13th (I’m actually writing this on Friday the 13th. What a coincidence). Every time she goes out, something bad happens. Let’s take a little peek at the life of Lisa Mishima, shall we? She was bullied at school, she became an accomplice for terrorists, her mom is so protective that it’s so scary, she almost died every episode since Five showed up, and finally, the guy she kinda likes gets killed in front of her. Seriously, has she ever seen a happy day in her life? I feel so sorry for her… I seriously do. *muffled laughter*


	Then we have Near… Oh, sorry. Wrong series. I meant Five. The one who holds all the “why” in the series. Why is she so obsessed with Nine? Why did she team up with the ones who tormented her? Why does she look like a gender-bended Near? Why is she such a fucking bitch? Why is she such an extremist? And most importantly, why did she kill herself when she finally cornered Nine (it’s almost too funny that after she killed herself the first thing we see was Shibazaki saying “why”)? 


Five: I finally cornered you! I’ve won! I can kill you but that’s not what I should do. I should just kill myself just because lol I want to! *bang*


	WWWWWWWWWWWWHHHHHHHHHHHHHHYYYYYYYYYYYYY????????!!!!!!!!!!


Animation:


	The animation for the series was handled by a fairly new animation company in MAPPA. Though it was the first big-name anime that they put out, it really looked fucking amazing. It really makes me wonder where they pulled the budget to make the amazing things that they did in the series. From the banging explosions to the quiet, tranquil moments, I think it is safe to say that for their first project, MAPPA surely delivered. If I can give out an award for 2014, I’d probably give the “Best New Studio” award to MAPPA rather than to the other new “big-name” studios like TROYCA and Trigger. If I could produce a new series, I’d gladly give it to MAPPA. Just please don’t involve CG. CG made by MAPPA is just utter shait (Bahamut & Garo).



Sounds:


The soundtrack for this series is just heavenly. For a series that is covered by banging explosions throughout, it sure stood out during its quietest moments. Tranquil music plagues (in a good way) the entire series and it was just beautiful. By far, it is the only soundtrack that I have listened from cover to cover. I always tend to skip something when listening to OSTs but this one was different. I listened to every track there is and I was seriously asking for more when it ended. It was that good.



Its tranquility mixed with some variations of rock (lolol. It’s not “lol lol” it is seriously the title of the music) and techno (veat) is just too good for the ears. These are the type of music that is perfect after a long day at school or at work. When you feel down, just put on your earphones, press play, sit back, relax, and just soak everything in… it will just cure your heart, take away your fatigue, and make you feel good. 


 Amazing music like “von” (Used in the Ferris wheel scene. And is by far my favorite) and “is” (This one was used during the motorcycle scene) were really used well in the series. Though mostly used once, hearing it one time is enough for me to buy the soundtrack. It was so good that I bought it in order to give this section decent information because listening with just the couple of clips in the series might not give it the justice it deserves. If for some weird reason you don’t even consider watching the series, just listen to the music. Composed by the one and only Yoko Kanno, your money will surely be not wasted. Just don’t make the same mistake I did of playing it while driving after work. Fatigue, stress, plus relaxing music. Makes you wanna sleep, doesn’t it?


	Since I can’t really understand Japanese, I really don’t have that much to say about the dub. Though with an obvious dub by Funimation shortly incoming, it’s probably safe to not point you in watching it in Japanese first if you’re a dub lover, right? I mean come on! It’s a Funimation dub. I rarely see dubs they put out that are below average. Hmmm… I really wonder if Funimation will pay me for advertising them. lol. But if you are a solid sub fan, then you surely won’t be disappointed. Though I can’t understand what they were saying, I can certainly feel the emotions that the seiyuus wanted to portray. And with that, I say well done.


Verdict:


	Shinichiro Watanabe along with Yoko Kanno delivers once again. After watching the season 1 of Space Dandy, I felt that these two have lost their magical touch. I will now go down on my knees (and *toot* *toot*) and ask for forgiveness. You two are still the golden combi of the anime industry. I’m sorry if I ever doubted you because of Space Dandy. If you ever decide to make another series, be sure to make it like this one. Though episodic shows aren’t bad, I still prefer a story where characters can grow much better and a plot that I can fully get attached to. That’s all I want. It probably isn’t that much to ask right? *sparkling puppy eyes*


	And with all that said, and after computing some imaginary numbers, I’d gladly give Zankyou no Terror an overall score of 8.73 out of 10. Though not in the masterpiece level, it’s still a very good show with an okay story, fun characters, amazing animation, and heavenly soundtrack. Even if both the story and characters are really not that good, one can still look past that because of the unique premise it presents. Since it’s the only anime that fully tackled the concept of terrorism, it’s hard to find a good comparison to say that it is bad. 


As 2014 was a pretty good year of anime, I’d be proud to say that I consider ZnT as both Anime of The Season (Summer) as well as Anime of The Year. With all the amazing shows that come out last year, it was rather easy picking an obvious winner. Many may not agree with me but I personally believe that it deserves what I gave it. Though not that well received by others, I can vouch that this show deserves all the hype it got… unlike a certain show about “killing” which was just decimated by the fanbase in its ass. A bit disappointing towards the end but it’s passable. It’s like I always say: “It’s not about the destination. It’s about the journey.”


Alternate Anime Recommendation:


	For alternate anime recommendation why don’t you try Death Note. Both series revolves around a cat-and-mouse stereotype between the protagonists and antagonist… though it is really hard to determine which is which because both the series’ protagonist are anti-heroes so you’ll either cheer them or hate them. I personally don’t think this is a good recommendation since I believe that 95% of users here on MAL have already seen Death Note… more than once. But if you’re the other 5% then you will surely thank me for it.


	If you’ve already seen Death Note then there’s still Cowboy Bebop. Also made by the one and only Shinichiro Watanabe, you sure as hell know what to expect before even watching the show. Almost made by the same team, you can see some similarities between the two.


	I’m sorry if I can’t put out a decent recommendation this time since I can’t see much more suitable anime in my list that fits in ZnT’s premise. For a show about terrorism, it sure is hard to find a good recommendation since there’s only few of them. I can always point you to shows I haven’t seen yet but I can’t vouch for its authenticity. As a bonus, here are 2 more. Guilty Crown (a review might come out before the end of the week. I’ve finished 50% of it) and Code Geass. Though both show didn’t focus that much about terrorism like ZnT did, both these show have terrorism aspects to them. A bit similar since almost all of the protagonist are anti-heroes too.


	And that’s it for me. Thanks as always for reading. I might pull out a couple of reviews this week since spring break is coming and I’ll be busy working so look forward to it. Thanks as always and buh-bye!

Terror in Revenance... at first, I was a bit hesitant to dive into an anime about terrorism for fear of the creators being unable to properly execute a respectable storyline.
At the end, I owe a round of applause to the creators! Job well done!
The story is based on Japanese patriotism turning into evil, American helpfulness veiling horrible ulterior motives (a theme preemant in history as well) and the undeniable spirit of teenage boys. 
While the characters are sometimes hard to relate to (blame their tragic backstories), Lisa, the girl-next-door prototype will have most feeling as though they're experiencing the story first person... she's just thatgood.\n\n
Terror is Resonance is an amazing story. While hard to follow sometimes, the overall story is beautiful, gripping and will leave you angry and in tears.

Look, Im going to be perfectly honest with you . . . this anime isn't for Otaku who can't swim in the deep end of the pool yet.  If your still dropping '8 star' ratings on High School slice of life comedies where the main character can't tell which team he or she is batting for, then this anime ain't for you.  But if you grew up lighting your sisters barbie dolls on fire and smoking cigarettes behind your house while your dad watched WWE wrestling on primetime . . then this is where you belong.  Its not often you get ananime with three grown men, all straight, all over the age of 16, and all badasses in the same Anime.  The two main characters are dropping terror bombs all over Japan because they are pissed at the guvment.  The detective charged with tracking them down looks like a war vet who saw too much shit and drinks a case of Lone Star every day.  This anime is good, watch it.

It has been quite a while since I've watched a full series that I enjoyed, and Zankyou no Terror broke that predicament (curse?) for me. The series isn't one of the best out there that has a crime-terrorism-"anti-hero"-thriller aspect, but this is definitely something you can check out. I just stumbled upon this anime and had no idea what this is show is about, but I should say that both of the tags indicated in MAL are most accurate. It's a thriller/psychological anime alright.
Honestly speaking though, I feel that Zankyou no Terror has plot-holes all over the place. However, I found the whole experience--the gistof the story, the pacing of scenes, and other aspects--to be quite enjoyable. Characters aren't very unique, but some of them are somewhat likable. The artworks were nicely done, and the sound effects used were also appropriate. I also appreciate the sound tracks (BGM) in this series; they either symbolized something or amplified the current situation.\n\n
Either way, if you decide to not watch this anime, I wouldn't say that you'll be missing out on anything great. Still, in my opinion, it's a good anime overall.
