“Zankyou no Terror” is one of the most remarkable animes of this season. It was directed by Sinichirou Watanabe, who is known for animes such as Cowboy Bebop, Samurai Champloo or Sakamichi no Apollon.
.:: Story ::. 
The theme of two young terrorists in Tokyo isn't exactly a well-explored one. The premise of the series was entirely new to me and really fascinating. The first few episodes are really excellent and although the anime isn't quite able to keep up that quality throughout the course of the series it never becomes boring or dull. Although I'm not too fond of the ending, since I'm under theimpression that the only purpose the ending serves is to evoke an emotional reaction from the audience without serving any greater purpose, I still think that the series becomes better towards the ending again.


8/10


.:: Character ::. 

Both Nine and Twelve have intriguing personalities that complement each other very well. Personally, I believe that their relationship is by far the most interesting one. Finding out about their past and being curious about their future was the main factor why I kept watching. 

Detective Kenjirou Shibazaki, who started off as the antagonist of the series, plays an important role and is the essential component that keeps the story going. Unfortunately, I didn't find all characters to be fleshed out that well. While Lisa's storyline is not hindering the development of the story, I find her to be rather bland and boring. Moreover, I believe that she could be substituted for any other generic looking high school girl and it wouldn't make much of a difference.

[Spoiler]

One of the few problems I have with the series was Five. After her introduction midway through the series the story goes downhill and seemes to be going in circles for a while. Five was supposed to be an opponent worth of Nine and Twelve, both brilliant boys, but turned out to be overly powerful. Although I was interested in her past, only few of the man questions I had were (vaguely) answered at the end. I find it incredibly hard to take a liking to her and I was even relieved when she died, because I hoped the series would be able to pick up where it left before the introduction of Five. 


7/10


.:: Art::. 

The anime was produced by MAPPA, which is a relatively new animation studio, but there's no doubt that it has the potential to become one of the big powerhouses for animation in the future. The animation was well-executed and smooth. The animation style was clean-cut without being bland, simple but not ugly, realistic and yet dramatic. I personally would have liked it to be a bit more detailed, but the animation never failed to impress and entertain me nonetheless.


8/10


.:: Sound ::. 

The series' music is composed by Yoko Kanno, who has previously composed music for Cowboy Bebop, Ghost in the Shell, Porco Rosso and various other well-known animated series and movies. The soundtrack, and especially the opening theme song “Trigger”, was without doubt one of my personal highlights. The songs are wonderfully tailored to the anime's plot and really refreshing in a way. I bought the soundtrack to “Zankyou no Terror”, which I rarely do, and still enjoy listening to it.  


10/10


.:: Enjoyment ::. 

I watched the entire anime in one day, so even though it's short I think it's fair to say that the anime is quite enjoyable.


8/10


.:: Overall ::. 

The anime was overall very compelling, entertaining and surprisingly mature. Although there were some minor weak points they were overshadowed by the fascinating premise, the beautiful execution and most of all the beautiful music. All in all, I could recommend this series and see it as one of the best new animes of 2014. 


Overall: 8/10

**SPOILERS**
This isn't your typical protagonist who is going to save the world and defeat villains with plot-armor and character development. 
This is a blunt, creative, absolutely tragic and beautiful critique of how the US is the world's #1 asshole (I jest - but not really ;__;)
****
Let's be brief. 
Art was stunning. Absolutely gorgeous - it's been a while since I've seen anything animated as beautifully and the fluidity of the characters' movements was very nostalgic. 
Story had its flaws, but it was incredible. It was dark and straightforward. 
"Music from a cold land" - Sigur Ros anyone? Enhanced the show. 
Characters - I have somemisgivings on Five and Lisa mostly, but I'll get to that later. 


Enjoyment - I finished it in one sitting so major love. 


Overall 10/10. 



****


Thoughts:



Story:


The emotions were so cold, and the story was very bleak and being such a short series (only 11 episodes) there were instances when some plots were wrapped up loosely and I never got the closure that I wanted. However, this makes sense.


This anime is an earnest attempt at being realistic. There are events in our lives where we will never obtain that closure that we want and desperately need. Life is guessing game and we're always in the dark. Especially regarding questions dealing with society as a whole. Politics, social constructs - so many complexities that would take more than a lifetime to unravel. Various connections and an infinite possibility of outcomes. The lack of closure reflects our uncertainties, and the regret and misgivings attached to that is something that we've learned to cope with. Life goes on. 


I personally felt like the writing was a reflection on how society has recovered from WWII. The victims from Japanese war crimes (Unit 731) was touched with the Athena project. The atom bomb was a nod to Hiroshima. US government interventions and their approach at foreign policy was accurately portrayed (US just f**ks everyone over for our benefit). 


Also a nod at the rebellious spirit of youth and the changing generations. 



Characters:


Not much to say about Nine and Twelve (love them dearly) besides what drove their actions was that they want people to remember that they lived. Viewers can decide for themselves. I feel like I should address the characters that were hated. 


I loved Lisa. I understand the hate she gets because I was personally frustrated with her the majority of the story as well and how she seemed to have little to no character development. 


This makes sense to me in a twisted way. I view Lisa as someone I can relate to. An average girl, dealing with bullies and an emotionally unstable mother. Not to mention I'm a teenager which is already hard enough. Now I'm forced to be an accomplice with terrorists who blew up the government building and are actually geniuses because of human experimentations. Seeing how this show tries to be realistic, how many people mature and grow in such a short time span in a ridiculous setting such as that? Try as I want, I know I couldn't bring myself to blow up an entire airport or follow a plan that I'm not fully knowledgeable of when I couldn't even stand up to the girls bullying me. She's an anchor in the show, something that was constant in a whirlwind of political secrecy and explosions and someone I could relate to - and this show needed that, especially after they introduced Five. 


Five was vital. So vital. She was introduced as an antagonist, and I hated her. I hated how dramatic she was; how ruthless she was towards Nine, Twelve, and her perfect English speaking partner. However, when her arc neared the end I realized that I couldn't bring myself to hate her and I have to admit I cried a bit. 


She was necessary show the results of how the experiments affected the children. She had the capabilities of a genius, but in return she was socially impaired. She never fully understood her actions, and everything was a game that continued all those years prior between her and Nine. The competition between those two was her only enjoyment. She was the only one who survived, and the first one shown to die. From that moment on, you knew that the experimented children had a limited time frame. It's what Five, Nine, and Twelve all hinted at. 


The show also explains Savant syndrome where you excel in a certain area, but you also are affected in others. Due to her isolation she ended up like this and this is what the show wanted you to think. Also, when she dies, she chose not to kill Nine, and ended up dying herself which ruins her image as the ruthless villain. She was just a victim. Just like Nine and Twelve, she was used by not only the Japanese government, but the US as well. 


Which leads to the ending of the Japanese government being exposed and everyone deciding that the US was a major prick because of what they did to Twelve. 


****


Ending thoughts:


I feel like Twelve had the potential of living a long life. He was the one who knew happiness because of Lisa, the one who knew the feeling of betrayal, love, doubt, and fear that was not directed towards him, but someone else. He knew humanity. Twelve and Nine were so similar, so I feel like Twelve saw himself in Nine since they both suffered together. However, throughout the show you never saw Twelve suffer from the side effects of experimentation which makes me wonder if it weren't for 'Merica.....


All in all, I feel like this show could have been more and could have done more if there were more episodes. A part of me regrets that I couldn't know more. 


Why didn't they talk more about Twelve and Nine's past? Why didn't they show the reactions to their deaths immediately after or the process? 


But that makes sense. 


We unraveled their past along with the detective. Just like reality, we can only know about the bits and pieces. We can never fully realize the extent of their fears and desperation. We won't understand their entire past. We can't see the entire process of something happening. There will never be closure. 


However, there was closure with Twelve and Nine and just that little slice of peace is enough to make me content.


See You, Sphinx.

Zankyou no Terror is for sure one of the best anime i've ever watched, from the start when I first heard about it I knew I was hooked, the seemingly amazing plot and unique concept made me watch this anime right off the bat.
During your time watching this anime you will come in contact with the beautiful soundtracks that's heard during the anime, I even looked up some of these songs after the anime just to listen to them once more, an example of this is  "Von by Yoko Kanno", really amazing song.
The characters we see during the anime all have special influence inwhat's happening, the deep thought behind each character makes you really interested in what background they have and can't stop watching because the answers are unraveling during each and every episodes, there's always something to learn about them and you really just need to know what the next part is! The feeling you get when finally understanding the true motives behind the character(s) makes you want to.. no words.. It's simply just an amazing feeling and you will have a ton of emotions running though your body.\n\n
The graphics and art displayed during the anime was amazing, really nicely done. It had some weak cgi which was barely noticeable, but it was all great! I don't even think that the cgi had a negative effect here since it was so amazingly well made.\n
~\n

Okay lets start this. After finishing Zankyou no Terror or Terror in Resonance I spent half an hour thinking. 
Some people complained about not so much character development, but I consider that nondevelopment necessary. People who watch Psychological anime should understand that the development which is given is subtle and make you think good. It leaves you to think and find alone the meaning behind everything, not giving you the details, so you shouldn't wait for the ravens to feed you. Zankyou no Terror does exactly that. Gives the start the end and details, everything else is up to whoever watches the anime. Because Terrorin Resonance is pretty damn complex.\n
Story 9/10 \n
The plot was great, you don't see often an anime about terrorists. I might say and it was an excelently put together kind of story. Sometimes it looked like it lacked in an episode and a half... but it got back up at full force. So I don't have any specific complaints about the story.\n
Art 10/10\n
Om my god... the art... it was so accurate and beautiful, it was the perfect picture for this anime . It matched the plot and the characters up to the tiniest detail. So I would call this one of my favorite art style that I've seen.\n
Sound 10/10\n
It was kind the first time I actually kept such a strict measure of the soundtracks. They really were chosen and made specifically for this. The soundtracks and art together alone could get you from feelings of sadness, joy, to melancholy and calmness. They were really abstract and stuck me good. I never actually listened to these kind of perfect match OSTs.\n
Character 9/10\n
Fine, they kind of lacked a little of OBVIOUS development. But if you watched week by week all the episodes 3 or 4 times each like I did, you would understand that I can understand their mentality and their way of thinking. The characters are intriguing, mysterious and kind of strange. But they were a breath of fresh air for me. I didn't stumble on anime with these kind of characters in quite a while and they are really interesting characters to watch and try to understand.\n
Enjoyment 10/10\n
Well, here isn't much to say. Only that it was FANTASTIC. From the first episode you get a rush of excitement that flows through your veins. The first episode was really mad, and from there on, the things get more complicated and hard to understand. But it still was a thrilling unique kind of enjoyment. I think everyone should experience this kind of thrill. It's really different from the one you get while watching Kuroko no Basket or Haikyuu!! or even Death Note. Even if this isn't your type of anime you should at last watch an episode for personal reference and experience.\n
Overall 10\n
I give it a ten because they way the story was told, the way the psychological part merged with the rest of the story and with the characters. I think I don't have anything more to say. Only one more thing, when watching this anime pay close attention to details, they say more than you would imagine.

From the director of Cowboy Bebop and Samurai Champloo comes a new story from Watanabe, Shinichiro, "Terror in Resonance".  Admittedly I was quite skeptical as to how this show would turn out. From the beginning a lot of questions are raised and a build up from the first episode commences. The story for the most part isn't very original, it has a strange background but nothing unique. If you've seen a lot of shows or anime in general you will understand what I mean by that. It does try to create new ideas into a common theme but it's really nothing fresh. I seenthat somebody compared this to "Eden of The East" which would probably be the best comparison. Definitely more emotion than Eden but very similar in many aspects. The pacing is what somewhat disappointed me. A lot more of this story could have been flushed out in the 11 episodes of  Terror in Resonance. The artwork in this show features dark colors and a simple character design. It wasn't visually stunning but I enjoyed it because it fit the tone of the story. The music of Terror was fantastic. Had it not been for this soundtrack composed by Yoko Kanno a lot of emotion would have been lost. The OP and ED are so good that you won't even want to skip them. This show could not have been as good as it was without it. Believe me when I say that the first couple of episodes are not the best but what unfolds is a mystery that  leaves you wanting more. Terror in Resonance may not be the best anime of the season but it certainly is worth the watch. I give it an 8/10

Story: This show's greatest strength is how it unravels the truth behind Nine and Twelve's intentions. We begin with a setting in modern day Tokyo where 2 boys make off with what we know to be a heavily guarded and secured object. You can tell that moments up until revealing the protagonists' mission were paced very well up until the very end. The story writers did a damn good job of setting up each of the events, and making sure that we as the audience knew enough to know what was going on, but not give us the entire explanation just yet. 9/10
Art: It seemsthat ZnT was going for a more realistic approach to its animation, which I found to add more to the story. The colors used and the graphic style paired well with the kind of mood that (I believe) the anime is going for, which is on more of a serious and darker tone. I understand that a psychological thriller probably wouldn't focus a lot on aesthetically pleasing aspects such as the hair color or backgrounds like most animations do. What I enjoyed was their use of feathers to off balance a lot of the psychological aspects of the anime. 8/10


Sound: I really like the opening theme and found that it greatly captures the feel of the animation. The lyrics of the song also sets up the mood of the anime quite well. I also really enjoyed the voice acting in the main characters and felt like they were chosen very appropriately. I also look forward to more of Saito Soma's work in a future  with him voicing Twelve and Tatsumi from AgK, who have very different personalities and characteristics, very we'll. I retract a point due to the "Engrish" that was spoken throughout the show. I thought that the sloppiness of it took away from the sense of hostility and excitement that the producers want us to feel during intense scenes. 8/10


Character: I consider the unveiling of Nine and Twelve's past to part of their character development because it allows us to understand why they have done the things they've done and chose the choices they've made. I also enjoy that Nine and Twelve have made an enemy of themselves in order to unveil who the true enemies are. Talk about a double negative creating a positive. The inclusion of Risa in their affairs didn't particularly draw out to her development, but more so to our protagonists instead. I would have liked to see her character play a stronger role, where she was not in need to always being saved or taken rare of by Twelve. 8/10


Enjoyment: I very much enjoyed it. The beginning, where clues and riddles were being laid out was a great way to entice the us viewers to keep watching and anticipating for me. The tragic moments highlight how well thought out the plot was, and the final scenes made me feel sad, but at peace at the same time. 8/10


Overall: Great psychological thriller! I enjoyed how much research and realism that was put into this anime. I think it's pretty daring to put out an anime about terrorism considering all the current events happening lately, damn, Zankyou no Terror carried the task very well. I'd definitely recommend this to anyone looking for something interesting to watch that shoujo and slice of life can't give to their viewers. 8/10

Hey, first review here! Please feel free to give me feedback!
Zankyou no Terror is one of my top favorite anime of this summer season, and even if just for the experience, it should be watched.
--Story (8):
The plotline is refreshingly different from many other anime of the same genre. The concept of terrorism is not necessarily anything new, and the actions taken by our main characters seem to remind most people of Death Note. 
This isn't going to become some kind of comparison essay of ZnT to other anime, but it certainly feels very different in relation to other shows. Even if you can predict theevents that occur throughout, the execution of such events is clever and leaves you satisfied. There was definitely room for more backstory, which is where I had to refrain from giving this section a full 10. Overall, though, the story is great to follow.


--Art (10):

Loved it. The art is very clean and detailed, with cooler tones that give ZnT a feel unique to itself. The explosions from bombs are wonderfully animated, too.


--Sound (9):

ZnT has some of the most unique yet beautiful soundtrack music of any show I have ever watched. Mostly the music very poignant and fit the emotion of the scene extremely well.


--Character (7):

If there were one thing that I would say the anime fell short of doing, it was character development. I didn't find many problems in most of the characters that stayed generally the same, and it was also easy to get attached to almost all of the cast, but at times I still feel a little disappointed in how static they are.


However, what development existed was usually both forced and rushed, and often I would be confused: I found that there was almost no reason for some of the changes that occurred to certain people. Given that the show is only 11 episodes, I can understand why the writers could not find the time to fit in very crucial development; but they DID change specific characters in ways that almost estranged me. Although not huge, I did feel this was the most prominent flaw in the anime.


--Overall (9):

Overall a very nicely-made anime. Often it could easily manipulate my emotions and bring me to tears, anger, or the occasional laughter. It was a pleasure to watch it over the course of several weeks and I hope many others find it as wonderful as I do!

Zankyou no Terror was an anime  that I had my eye on before it was airing, the plot seemed interesting and the animation looked different. In fact, I admit it - I was a bit hyped up for it. Perhaps those high expectations lead me to disappointment, lead me to feel this emptiness (and not the good kind either.)
Zankyou no Terror establishes it's plot earlier on but it's actual execution was (annoyingly) flawed. The audience watches two boys, who calls themselves only by numbers - Twelve and Nine. 
We are represented with no information on them. To us, these are just two good lookingguys with high intellect appearing as terrorists to the public, to the police and to the government. They call themselves the "Sphinx" and make a number of violent acts that appear to have the intent to harm. To kill. But as you may guess, things are rarely what they seem. And what is portrayed in the exterior may not completely stand for who those people are.


The fact that the audience is given such little material and substance, we are left grasping on tiny hints they show. There is a shadow of mystery and fog between us, the audience and the characters. Which certainly adds a different kind of thrill, you try your best to somehow humanize these characters. To attach ourselves and make ourselves sympathise. (Which takes a lot of patience - seriously.)

But we are only given glimpses. Only reflections they want us to see and I think it is up to you to how you wish to react to it. But certainly, for a good portion of this 11 episode show - we are kept in the dark.


Being in the dark, kept away from the truth and hidden secrets is a prevalent theme throughout the show, everything is complex, everything is tied and twisted into another. Nothing is ever clear, even to the end. Which, in one aspect makes the anime tackle such difficult issues of mistrust and lies in such a refreshing and brilliant route. But this show isn't only about that. Which is why things get blurry and it deliberately pushes us away that we have to make more of an effort to make sense of it all, to connect the dots and to somehow grab all the little pieces to make a full puzzle.

Which, actually, is what the police try to do when they cross paths with these boys who send different messages and mysteries which they try to solve. Try to understand. But underneath these "terrorists" who look like they have way too much time on their hands, there is a tone of plead. Almost as if they are trying to say something, trying to get away from the darkness.


And while it may seem Nine and Twelve have this whole game planned in the palm of their hands, someone who also goes by only a number, Five, - screws the whole score board and so begins the game of cat and mouse. 

Both opponents playing a series of witty moves to trip the other one over. It's push and pull. The prey playing with it's food before it goes in for complete destruction.

Unfortunately, you'd think a formidable opponent for these two boys would allow the story to step forward and not on a downward spiral.

Of course, every episode has uncertain feeling of doubt. Of tension. It's suspense to the max. 

But personally, the middle of the show lost its spark and way. Like it got lost and tumbled over.


However, hope is not all lost as - slowly but surely, things start to connect and though the veil is not always lifted full way. We get answers and we get motives - a twisted and saddening story of children who are treated as objects before human beings. As numbers before their name.

But the question... that I think is pretty subjective - is it enough? In my opinion, since the anime did such a good job in isolating the characters both literally and figuratively that it forgot to let us in. To let us feel with them. I loved the characters, but I felt like I could not attach myself to them and like there was no sense of emotional investment. And if anything, was the most disappointing factor of the show.

I'm going to keep an open statement on Lisa's questionable use as it's going to be an ongoing debate for, ever.


Honestly, I found that in the end, the show relied on telling us it's plot. Lecturing us. No one like's to be spoken at - they like to be spoken to. To be shown things. People want to see actions, not to be told words. Words mean nothing if they do not hold depth by characters we care about.


For a show I found very promising and different, it was undeveloped and sadly, anti-climatic IF you weigh against it's wasted potential.


If judged by its own on a stand point of view, you realise that it is an anime jampacked of fantastic components of a "good" anime. Diverse and colorful characters, unique plot. It's an enjoyable and timeless thriller that you certainly won't regret watching. 

And not to mention, probably one of the best animation and OST in a long time.

Zankyou no Terror is tragic. You can TELL what they were trying to do, it just… didn't work. I think it failed the same way Death Note did: it kept trying to 1-up itself until it went to far. In fact, it has a lot it common with Death Note - from the genre, to the overall story (government vs. criminal), to the fact that we're rooting for the for the ones doing the most harm.
   Five was somewhat pointless. It got to the point where it felt like she was only there to be filler, which is bad for a 12episode anime.


   I even have issues with Lisa. They kept saying she served no purpose - she even admitted it herself - but she never truly finds one. It would have been much better if she had admitted it, then found a purpose within the trio. But she never truly finds one.


   Zankyou no Terror had a lot of potential. But there are so many flaws that it falls on it’s face. Which is tragic, because the first few episodes are astounding and the soundtrack is flawless. 


    I would recommend skipping this anime and watching Death Note instead. It did what Zankyou no Terror was trying to do - give you a suspense-filled psychotic thriller that leaves you guessing at every turn.

After hearing lots of great comments of the anime, Zankyou no Terror, I finally had the chance to watch it. However, I was disappointed and realised how much of an overrated show this was. 
You may or may not disagree with this review. 
Story: 5/10
Zankyou no Terror has a good premise, the first few episodes got me hooked. However, there are many illogical instances. 
How does a bomb that explodes an entire building cause few casualties? How do people not get suspicious of the two students that stopped attending school after their first day? 
Although this is an anime, I think that it should stillbe logical. The way that the explosions were made were obviously for that 'boom' effect. The investigation were too easy. How the heck does Shibazaki know Greek mythology at the back of his hand? Maybe, if they had played it out and the police took a few wrong turns here and there, the show would have been more interesting. 


The show disappointed me even further, with the introduction of Five, the primary antagonist of the show, which I will write about in the 'Character' section. 


I'm glad that in this anime, the policemen are not brainless idiots, compared to Sphinx. Well, there was at least one smart guy. 



Art: 8/10



Colours and tone were appropriate for all scenes of Zankyou no Terror. I like how the rather dark colours reflect the grimness and sense of isolation in the show. 



Sound: 9/10


The soundtrack fits the anime. Intense and fast-paced soundtracks increased the tension and this builds up very nicely to the scenes. The slower paced tunes were powerful and had left a great impact on me. Again, possibly the most redeeming factor in the show. Voice acting was on point. 


Character: 4/10


Characters. This was the main reason why I had given the show a poor score. The characters of the show are rather one-dimensional and their goals are not fleshed out in the show. 


Nine and Twelve were fine personality-wise. The anime had failed to develop their roles and they were reduced to the roles of two boys who commit terrorist acts. I hoped that the anime would develop Nine and Twelve but it did not. 


An example would be Five, the primary antagonist of Zankyou no Terror. Five is a terrible villain and exists to be evil for the sake of being evil. She was another character who was thrown in to foil Nine and Twelve's plans. Five barely serves any purpose and is there to fill in the 'psychotic bitch' role in the story. 


Another character whom I would like to discuss would be Lisa Mishima, a character whom I feel very conflicted over. Lisa Mishima is the love interest of Twelve and the girl who messes everything up. With a sad backstory, one cannot help but feel sorry for Lisa. Her personality is barely developed and she is a rather unnecessary character. 


I think that the character who was the least one-dimensional would be Shibazaki. He had some character development but his personality needs more work. 



Enjoyment: 6/10


The first few episodes were promising. The beginning was decent and drew me into the show, which was different among the many shoujo anime that were common in 2014. However, as I continued watching, I enjoyed it less. The lack of character development and the piss-poor characters was what decreased the enjoyment levels. 


Overall: 6/10


Zankyou no Terror was a major disappointment. I would recommend you to watch the first three or so episodes, but after that, things start to go downhill. If you want to watch Zankyou no Terror for the plot and characters like me, you would be greatly disappointed. 


To sum up my review, 

Strengths: Art (8/10) and Sound (9/10)

Weaknesses: Story (5/10) and Character (4/10)


Hope you found my review helpful. Thank you!

Zankyou no terror is one of the few Gems i've awarded a 10. 
Its a short anime about terrorism, or so it would seem, but its actually not about terrorism at all. Terror in resonance (in english) is a heart wrenching story about 2 young boys who escape a governmental testing facility, and cause havoc to bring forth a greater message.
The two main characters are very interesting, both being brilliant but with different personalities (cool and collected vs spontaneous and fun).
The artwork is very unique done in a slightly more monochromatic fashion to add eeriness to the scenery and the people. The sound was reallywell done, and you really do feel for the characters, while trying to solve riddles and uncover the truth. \n\n
If you want a touching story of people trying to express the world they live in, and shed light on larger problems through explosions, riddles, and inter connectivity, give this show a try.

This is an almost impossible anime to review without spoiling.   But since so many other reviews cover with full spoilers why to avoid it, I'll give it a try.
The show has a fairly strong first episode that builds up a lot of mystery... but also already starts with a fairly large level of implausability.  While suspense of belief is part of any show... one that tries to deal with such important, dire topics like terrorism and government overreach, you have to have a reason to keep making it more extreme.  By the end of the show, they push this to farextremes with absolutely no purpose.


The characters remain uninteresting, undeveloped, and keep creating more and more implausible plans for no strong reason.  A villain is introduced half way through the show that acts completely erratically, and does a full about face for no reason so that... we can reach the stories conclusion that it was heading towards without the introduction of said villain in the first place? Really it's a filler arc that runs for a little over half the show's runtime.


And finally, really the most important, this show has absolutely no consistent theme.  Terrorism can sometimes be cool and productive, and sometimes bad?  There's really nothing interesting Terror in Resonance is trying to say.  It has strong visuals and music, and an edgy attitude... but at the end of the day they use backstory to justify a bunch of completely bull**** acts of terror, and it has no meaning, allegory, or anything to real life.  It's a lot of spectacle for no reason.


Also... literally the worst use of english in a show I've ever seen.  Seriously, find a youtube video of it, it is absolutely hilarious.

Anime is a medium in our society that deals with many sensitive topics such as incest, rape and terrorism and there have been cases where the topics are treated with care and understanding and other ones were it is just in there without any proper thought given on the topic. For example, Koe no Katachi handles the theme of bullying with a lot of care by showing what happens from the victim's and the bully's point of view. But, that sometimes works against it, because the victim who is deaf is treated as a person to feel sympathy and no other emotion. This example showsexactly how even serious topics like this can be unintentionally sensationalizing the events around them and create problems with the story and the characters. Thus, treating such issues as a main topic in a show can work for and mostly against it if not treated properly.


In Zankyou no Terror's case, terrorism is the issue in discussion. From the outside, the show exudes extreme amount of potential since it is directed by Shinichirou Watanabe and the music is by Yoko Kanno, who is undoubtedly the best music composer in anime. Tackling with such a current matter, especially in Europe and Western Asia, can be trully brilliant. Also, the fact that the story is told from the terrorists' side is even more intriguing, since we get a view from what happens from the other side of the spectrum and why. The motive could be something noble or something appalling but it could give further insight in what led them to believe in such extreme ways to make their opinion clear to the people.


Initially, the show starts pretty good. The first three episodes introduce the main cast and the surface of the reason why the terrorists act in a way that there is no casualty. Nonetheless, after 5 comes into the mix and the logic of the show is thrown out of the window, it becomes like a monstrocity created from a failed exepriment. It is exactly like Dorian Grey. He starts being pretty and young as his portrait but towards the end, the portrait turns even more monstruous and ugly. Similarly, ZnT starts strongly with a great first episode and as it reaches its closure, it becomes worse and more nonsensical and hollow. 


The story is the reason why I was initially intrigued by the anime, since it is rare to see anime dealing with this kind of heavy issues. But, the story is like a tablecloth and as time passes, it becomes dirtier and filled with holes that cannot be sown back. A lot of backstory is left untouched and anything about 5, 9 and 12's past is said by infodumping a la Hitchcock but in a more vague and incomplete way. Personally, the last episode was one of the most racist, illogical and terrible final episodes I have seen the past few years. 


The worst thing about the whole show was actually the characters who are damn straight horrendous. The story is partially at fault here because we do not get time to actually care about them or even like some of them. Lisa is the worst above all since she is your typical damsel in distress with the depth of a Michael Bay character and a personality of a rice cake. 5 is 1D psycho bitch. 9 is drier than Atacama Desert and colder than the Arctic. 12 is the most unstable character in existence. He changes character whenever the plot wishes for it.


Fortunately, in this soulless piece of an anime, the animation and the sound are excellent and where the reason I watched this self-destructing piece of art crumble to its demise. The animation was handled by studio MAPPA, which was a newfound at the time company by the original founder of Madhouse and for their second anime, they passed the test with flying colours. The character designs are really well-done and the atmosphere and setting is also fluid and beautiful. Thanks to Watanabe's expertise in directing, every frame of the show was close to perfection. Especially the OP and ED of the show were both really beautiful and I never skipped them after watching them for the first time. As for the soundtrack, it was done by Yoko Kanno who is truly a genius. This woman has amazed me a lot of times. All tracks from the ost are great and there is a wide variety, but my personal favorites are lolol, birden, is and nc17. The ED is sung by Aimer whom I hold very dearly in my heart since her songs always gives you ear-orgasms, recently ninelie. As for the OP, it is sung by the singer of Galileo Galilei and his voice fits perfectly since there is a slight sadness, eeriness and despair in his voice which fits the anime. 


In conclusion, Zankyou no Terror is like a blank canvas decorated with majestic borders that flaunts its concepts in the shallowest and hollowest manner. It is like having a pharmacy shelf in a museum. It may be considered beautiful and highly acclaimed, but it cannot hide its hollow nature.


Overall: 5.72/10


Alternative Recommendations:

-Ghost in the Shell (1995) & SAC: Yoko Kanno does music in SAC and both versions are deep and handle terrorism in a more detailed-oriented manner.

-Psycho Pass S1: Does not reach the level of goodness of GitS but it is still pretty good and the ost kicks ass, especially its endings.

STORY - 8
ART - 10
SOUND - 9
CHARACTER - 7
ENJOYMENT - 8
Boom! The shockwaves from the explosion resonates thoughts within me, sending thematical fragments such as isolation and societal fear everywhere. Zankyou no Terror is not a show that is all about terrorism. It integrates a branching set of sociopolitical topics handled in a mature yet compelling fasion.
After the first episode, the story intrigued me as it followed two unknown boys who picked a fight against Japan. This is not just a story about the acts of terror. Yes, there were society, terror, and panic, all creating a parallel to the bigger issues of our realworld. Combined with the presence of media and this anime enchanced realism which was evidenced by the first few episodes. We get a plot that can be thought as a split, one on a methodical approach that focused on the two opposing forces, with the planning and executing or the solving and responding. The other part was on a deeper level that took place during the establishment of backstories and characters, creating an aura of mystery that surrounded the MCs. However, as the story progressed, a couple of issues started appearing with the introduction of the main antagonist. While she can be entertaining, she was too lackluster, seemingly serving as a contrived plot device barrier that led to the breakdown of the integrated realism. And the terrorist boys along with girl they 'recruited' had a bland motive that were only answered towards the end, and even then, it wasn't fully explained to conclude satisfyingly. But that said, they served well in the story with their personality. Not terrorists just for the sake of terrorizing, they harbored a multilayered personality, having a caring and antagonistic side to them. The police side was handled well, adults shown as people who strived to protect society from danger, using their intelligence and skills as effectively as they could though at times I did find some to be too favorable. I also find the scientific elements to be a nice addition. The interesting riddles informing a handful of Greek mythological trivia on their terrorist name, Sphinx, showed an interesting implication to think about on their actions.\n\n
The art was without a doubt the best part of the anime, with qualities that competed with that of a movie. Overlaying the scenes with the apparent vignette effect darkened the setting, generating a tonal feel in the art. This was a good complement to the sense of mystery enveloping the boys of Sphinx. Movement-wise for the most part, it had a good and fluid animation. Explosions and smokes were full of detail, showing the damaging power, a true essence of fear. Along with the city sceneries, the character designs were realistic, particularly in the diverse facial features of the character. Expressive attitudes were shown in their faces, presenting lots of emotions and thoughts coming out. For a thriller with suspense at its core, the audio slowly built up to the dramatic scenes very effectively. The seiyuus voiced each of their respective characters in a great way. While the terrorists had that almost treatening demeanor in their voice, the members of justice held frustration and anger under their breaths, taking me inside their thoughts during their investigations. Combined all together and the anime had an atmospheric vibe which were only heightened up by the moody background soundtracks that played frequently throughout. Another thing that stood out to me was the opening sequence. It felt mesmerizing and hypnotic, and totally contrasted to the darkness of the story's visual by taking on a brighter color pallete. Definitely a unique one that I've seen so far as it steered away from the tone of a lot of the openings in other anime.\n\n
As far as the narrative goes, it stood rigid until the explosion was dropped, becoming a shaky structure of unbalanced characters and slight forcefulness nearing the end. Though look from far away and the scorching orange-red clouds from the detonation turns into a beautiful mix of visual, with the shockwave boom that fills you with goosebumps. With the issues in mind, Zankyou no Terror still delivered an interesting take on the idea of terrorism, giving you a number of themes and questions to think about from an individual and societal point of view.

The anime was soo good! At first, I thought there won't be romance. Then later on, there really is romance but little of it. That I appreciated very much. Though the female characters of this anime can sometimes be annoying, okay, very annoying, but the male characters actually masked it, sorta. 
Story: 10
The plot and the tragic events are so well thought. There aren't any plot holes and I enjoyed watching as the Sphinx plotted their next bomb.
Art: 10
The artwork is really awesome. The male characters are drawn so beautiful and even their bombing scenes are just so awesomely awesome!
Sound:10
Can't really complain about the sound.I mean, there aren't much to say about it, are there?\n\n
Character: 9\n
Like I said, some of the female character are a bit annoying in the anime. Like how they faint just randomly everywhere and anywhere. But the male characters are all very cool and calm. They have super hacker skills and are the genius among the geniuses. \n\n
Enjoyment: 10\n
The anime is overall very enchanting. With very cool action scenes and detective moments that I enjoyed watching about. I would have given it a eleven, but no, the highest is ten. ^ ^\n\n
Overall: 10\n\n
Well, all in all, this anime is a must watch for anime fans out there that are just tired of the harem and highschool squealing fangirl club. It is a very sad yet realistic anime at the same time. Please do give it a try if you enjoy action and detectives stories! \n\n

this is one of the very few anime which mad me cry. I am a person who rarely cries and masks and hides emotions but Zankyou no Terror especially the ending to this anime which i will not ruin had brought my emotions out too an extreme extent of only of sadness but of questioning and wonder.
Story: 10/10
I found the story for zankyou no terror very interesting. The broad and shallow story was about terrorists. Nine and Twelve. However, the story goes much beneath what the eyes can see, it is a complex and very mature story which cannot be easily seen.
IMO Deeper Story: 9/10
Whati believe the story of zankyou no terror is the corruption of power. Nine and Twelve spent a lot of time just to spread news about what had happened which was the corruption of power which can be seen throughout the story with the covering up of the experiment for the children who were taken away from a young age to be cruelly drugged and mentally tortured by words and drugs. This is clearly so illegal but was easily covered up for a along time until somebody attempted to uncover the truth about this experiment. Soon to be uncovered once again by Shibazaki kenjirou.


IMO Secondary Story: The accomplice gathered along their way got involved into the plot of the attempt to reveal the truth of corruption without fully knowing as they were slightly forcefully dragged into their plot which lead to many complexes and stories. I once again believe that doing this and having them as a main character brought light to her slightly different "traumatic" experiences from Nine and Twelve both being very serious.

Five also had to deal with the trauma that Nine and Twelve had to deal with but she had to continue after they had escapes leading from a small extent of lack of sense to pure insanity towards Nine created by the mental torture and abuse and the drugs sideaffects.


Art: 9/10

the art which was created fits perfectly into the scenery and the style of the show which was very action-packed but also the very chilling, cold and slightly uneasy show.


Sound: 9/10

The music which was added to zankyou no terror was very good added almost another whole layer to this anime which was the side story and irony of their name being VON with what they did being "terrorists". The music was also very calming and quiet yet so fast paced and interesting at different scenes with suspense building scenes.


Character: 8/10

Nine and Twelve were obviously very different characters being polar opposites nine being smart, very cool, calm and collected, twelve being very childish and energetic. They both had their counterparts not being each other to an extent. Nine being Fives with Five being very smart, yet has a very short temper and easily looks down on other which is very different to Nice. Twelve's counterpart being Lisa who was seen to be fairly simple or bland, i believe that she was made to be that way with her up-bring with her being very shy and having a difficult time having no one to talk to, once again being very different to what i believed to be their counterparts.

Unfortunately i believe Five was portrayed on the bad side but her personality was very hard to create which i believe was made to at least a decent extent. which lowered my character rating by a very so little. Other than her all the characters had their down and upsides but they were, IMO very well done.


Enjoyment: 10/10

Wow. that's all i can say, this was an extremely well made and sought through anime which was astonishing in my eyes, however i tend to be a very easy rater for anime. What i thought of the anime is up to you to agree with!

The last episode and ending has confirmed it for me... That show is now my number 1. all around favourite anime of all time.
It had everything that I want in an anime and it presented every element so well! Down to the last frame of the ending credits, this show was stylised / animated immaculately, had its characters fully developed, kept its plot interesting and fully engaging and the soundtrack was absolutely perfect.
I will preface the rest of this review with the fact that this anime is not the 'pop' anime that appeals to a wide audience... the story, characters, art and sound of Zankyouno Terror are subtle, engaging and very artistic. I wouldn't go as far as to say it was art house, but every aspect of this anime was stylised just how Watanabe intended.


The themes of this anime, even without the violence are very mature, I would not recommend this to anyone below the age of around 16.


I know some people weren't a big fan of the 11 episode structure and the pacing that it brought. I was a little also skeptical, however, I never found the story rushed or so slow that it was boring. It spanned the perfect amount of time for the story and allowed all of the characters to develop and unfold along with the developments and twists of the plot. I was worried that after I finished the last episode I would long for more, however, the ending was so perfect that I am happy with it being finished.


Speaking specifically about the ending (no spoilers) the final twist that was introduced added another dimension to the story that perfectly wrapped things up. Without the addition of this it would have left what was a very well spanned closed story much too open. I also love the fact that they give a final 'one year later wrap up' tying off ends with the few other main characters from the story.


The soundtrack was created to perfection by the incredible Yoko Kano! When I first heard that she was creating the soundtrack for ZNT I automatically thought it would be a very up beat 'bebop' style soundtrack, however I found that the the many subtle tacks (such as Lisa's theme) to be very beautiful, as well as still having exciting 'up beat' tracks for the action scenes!


This music tied in also with the art style. The art in this anime was very refreshing for me, as the integration of the CG and hand drawn elements were so flawless that it felt very reminiscent of classic golden or silver age anime. The details in everything from everyday objects to explosions of buildings were spot on and created a great sense of realism in this anime's world. The bleak, simple colours of the characters contested beautifully against the full saturated colour of the world around them.


The depth of the story and characters is incredible, with many subtle themes playing out through plot devices such as the constant mind games between the main characters. The main characters of the story are introduced with the audience knowing almost nothing about them. As the story progresses and the plot develops you learn more and more about the main two and grow very attached to them and their background. The use of only minimal characters in the story allowed for each character to be thoroughly developed without the pacing becoming to fast.


Watanabe and Yoko Kano have really outdone themselves with this one... I loved every second of it and will be waiting for a box set with 5.1 and then re watching this again and again and again!


10/10

The first thing you will notice about this anime, is the art. The second thing you will notice , is the music. And then you stop noticing things, because there isn't much after that. 
The story is good enough, it isn't something we haven't seen before, though it does surprise you from time to time. 
The characters aren't really that unique either. The main protagonists are your cliché super smart teens, the main antagonist is a super smart female teen, and there is an above average smart detective, and a not-so-smart girl that is not really useful in any way to the plot because theonly thing she does is get in trouble, forcing the protagonists to save her.\n
There isn't much character development (this being an 11 episode anime), besides the protagonists and the detective. Which is a shame.\n
The voice acting ( I saw it subbed) is great if you don't count the times they try to speak in english.\n
The whole anime gives me a Death Note feel to it, in parts regarding the police work and the whole cat and mouse chase, but it doesn't transmit it as well as Death Note.\n
Overall I think it is a good enough anime, but what really steals the show is the art and music, not to mention that the last couple of episodes are a bit disapointing and rushed.\n

To summarize Zankyou no Terror there is only one word: Awesome. One of the best animes I've ever seen.
Story: 10/10
The theme terrorism is really delicate and you have to treat it with great care. But Zankyou no Terror managed to do everything right. From the first moment I wanted to know everything, what's happening next and why it is happening. I really love stories who use intelligence and this story is using it perfectly. There were many things which came with great surprise to me. All in all I always wanted to see the next episode immediatley and were extremly impatient to know whats happeningnext.


Art: 8/10

It's nothing extraordinary, but it doesn't need to be, because there are so many other great parts who make up for it. Nevertheless it's pretty to watch.


Sound: 9/10

Oh, how I love the Opening and the Ending Song. It's really special and leaves you with an uneasy felling wich fits perfectly in the atmosphere.


Character: 10/10

I believed everything the characters did and say and I'm convinced the real people would do the same thing. I especially liked, that there were no character who just fullfilled a certain purpose. They were all very good characterized without having to use much time for explaining. The story also didn't try to make some characters espacially likeable. I somehow love everyone even though I really hate some of them.


Enjoyment: 10/10

I allready said everything. I extremly enjoyed every minute and in the moment I'm extremly sad, that it's over.


Overall: 10/10

What an incredible show - (it's 2am right now and I've watched the entire thing through from the beginning to end in one full gulp). Just to give a gist of it, Zankyou no Terror is an honestly intriguing and moving story about four teenage boys and girls (Nine, Twelve, Lisa and Five) who struggle to verify their existence in the world.
Yet, I do have many conflicting perspectives about the series. For instance, it has used terrorism as a plot device during a time when it has become quite a sensitive topic (in light of ISIS and what they're doing around the world right now).Nevertheless, this show is clearly not about terrorism and is definitely not justifying it either. It really looks at one reason of the many reasons why youth join terrorist groups: to make their mark in history.


But I cannot forgive one thing in this series, and that lies in its gender ideology. The character of Lisa Mashima is the most frustrating female lead that I have ever encountered in light of all the shoujo manga that I've read in the past 6 years. The constant crying, sobbing and asking "What should I do?" to Twelve and Nine is hugely problematic to say the least, and offended me at many points throughout the series as a female. Of course, this series was clearly aimed for men, but with the villain also being a female, and the way that both major female characters are over-sexualized was taking it too far.


There was also an issue with the depiction of America. The incorporation of English was daring and admirable, I will admit. But the series didn't have to go as far as depicting the United States as the ultimate villains; the finale was also taking things too far in this respect.


Though, I suppose that you could also interpret there to be a parallel storyline, in which Japan tries to reassert its identity throughout the series. The police are constantly battling against the power of the USA offscreen; and you could also see Nine and Twelve as symbols of Japan instead, the city of Tokyo being an alias for 'the outside world'. 


Now this is why the series, despite all of its glaring flaws, is still considered to be one of the best I've ever seen. The number of layers of interpretation of this series grows as you reflect and think about it more and more - it's as if each one is like a single soundwave of an echo that keeps going through your head.


And it is this echo - this resonance - that's running through my mind at the moment; I'm still buzzing from finishing the last episode of the series. Altogether, it is heavy, powerful and telling; it makes you truly reflect on experiences that have past in a critical manner. I encourage everyone that is willing to go on both an intellectual and emotional journey to engage with these films as soon as you can. Don't be afraid of the title - which is named "Resonance of Terror"; it's quite a misnomer actually. Instead, cover the "of Terror", because this series will impact you one way or another, and you will be able to hear the echoes of these characters for a long time to come.

I went into this series attracted only by its premise and high scores on various rating platforms. Had I realised that WATANABE Shin'ichirō had directed and KANNO Yōko written the soundtrack, I would probably have gone in with much higher expectations—which probably would have had me a bit more disappointed.  As it is, I loved how the series was presented, in terms of visual and sound design and its thematic elements, but a few major elements did dampen my overall impression.
This series shines in its first five episodes or so and its ending. Its greatest strength is thematic: and despite the initial premise ofterrorism in an alternative-universe present-day Tōkyō, the core themes don't seem to be about terrorism at all. In this, I agree wholeheartedly with waluigia's analysis in a previous review. The story is revealed to the viewer primarily from the point of view of the characters 9 and 12; the terrorism they commit is portrayed from the point of view of the post-war Japanese national identity, the scars left by the end of WWII and the American occupation, which gave rise to the project through which and institution in which 9 and 12 were inhumanely raised; this is certainly a novel point of view of modern Japanese society to me, but being disconnected from modern Japanese society, I cannot particularly elaborate on this series's treatment of it. The much more personal themes of these characters' rebellion, both youthful yet mature and serious in nature, and their isolation from society and other people by their background also play a key role in this story, in particular in MISHIMA Lisa's role in the story—both in her own upbringing and isolation from society, very different from the other characters', and in her relationships with 9 and 12.


The mood and atmosphere of the series were exceptionally crafted. The combination of detailed, emotive characters, the use of contrast in foreground art, with beautiful background vistas, and colour palettes that always fit the mood of a scene made for a stunning visual experience. I am even more impressed at KANNO Yōko's sound design: she has masterfully married musical composition to scenes, to create sensations of relaxation, anxiety, foreboding, fear. I greatly enjoyed the breadth of musical influences, from post-rock and art rock, to Romanticism and Impressionism, to modern Minimalism, choices which were, of course, ever suited to the atmosphere.


The entire story, and the ending in particular, do not necessarily make the themes and messages passed through those themes evident to the viewer upon first watch. The ending reinforces the idea that their ultimate goal was to send a wake-up call to the entirety of Japanese society, which contradicts certain implications of vengeance against those involved in the project that created 9 and 12 as they are, which I read from earlier exposition. As I think more about it, the more I can harmonise the events of the plot with the thematic message of the series, but I feel as if this series deserves a re-watch and some time to reflect upon it: the interleaving of themes and nuance, I believe, gives this series a strongly literary quality to it, a characteristic that is shared among many of my favourite series.


That said, there are certain specific elements of the series that detracted significantly from the whole.


Development of character was, overall, subtle but appropriate for 9 and 12. Although they are characterised as archetypes initially, their background and hence their motivations are developed, forming the basis of their well-roundedness, and their changing relationship with each other, with Lisa, and with their mission allows the viewer to see a certain level of character evolution. However, the major failures in characterisation were Lisa and 5. Lisa, I admit, was far more interesting to me than either 9 or 12 at the beginning of the series: although her portrayal as a timid high-schooler who gets inadvertently caught up in events is fairly archetypal in anime, I was expecting her to evolve: on one hand to work through her emotional and social issues, on the other hand act as a foil to 9 and 12 thanks to their both being social outcasts. But that never happened, and she remained an ever-useless puppet to the plot.


The other failure, not only in characterisation but in plot, for this series was the antagonist 5. This, I noticed, was a common complaint for the series: the character's past and motivations are not significantly developed, and in her work with the FBI against 9 and 12, she acts childish and petty and takes incredible risks to carry out her plan, apparently with the FBI's full support for the most part. I felt as if I were watching a typical villain genius of the genre, who would stop at nothing to carry out some impossibly convoluted plot against the protagonists. The series failed to suspend my disbelief at that point, contrasting so starkly with the much more realistic earlier episodes. Ultimately, she becomes an emotional hook to the plot at the end of her arc, with little additional explanation of her past or her relationship to 12.


All in all, despite its weak points, the series remained mostly compelling throughout its narrative, bolstered by intriguing and well-presented themes, beautiful art and atmosphere, and exceptional sound design. While the plot and its focus on the antagonist 5 failed to be entirely convincing to me, and perhaps wasted time where other aspects of the narrative could have been more fully explored, the series managed to convey its themes well. It has left me a lot to think about, and perhaps a bit of reading to do on post-WWII Japanese history and the current social and cultural identity.

It really is hard for people to branch out and do something they wish to sometimes. For people who like to escape from the social norm and do what they find meaningful, sometimes society is unforgiving. They get labeled as freaks, undesirables, and even monsters. So you could imagine my surprise when a well respected director, Shinchiro Watanabe, decided branch out and cover a very, very sensitive topic in the anime “Zankyou no Terror.”
In this world, there is one thing that is widely considered one of the worst things a person could ever do, by both the types of social outcasts mentioned prior and “normal”people alike. That thing… is terrorism. Users on MAL, I bring you my rewritten review of the anime Zankyou no Terror, that instead of exploring terrorism itself and using it as paint, uses it as the paintbrush.



---PLOT---

There’s something horrible happening to the Kanto region of Japan. Two terrorists that go by the name of Sphinx have been setting off bombs in seemingly random public places, leaving only a vague riddle as a clue to why they are doing such a thing in the videos they post prior to their attack. But, instead of attacking the populace directly and demanding ransom, they make sure there are no casualties in their attacks, and don’t ask for any kind of compensation. 


The plot of Zankyou no Terror opens with an act of terrorism, and in todays world, covering such a subject in a public television program could almost be considered “taboo” because of just how many horrible things have happened in recent memory, things so heavily hitting to society that I don’t even need to say what they are, and anybody reading this will already know what I’m talking about. But instead of exploring this kind of terrorism directly, Zankyou no Terror, or as I will call it from now on, Terror in Resonance, leaves its true meaning shrouded in complete ambiguity for almost its entire run.


Terror in Resonance initially begins with a formulaic story; Sphinx, comprised of two young adults that go by the names Nine and Twelve, hide a bomb in a populated area. Immediately after, a riddle that usually involves euphemism of the Greek tragedy Oedipus the King is posted to Youtube, where the police division must solve the riddle and disarm the bomb. Their first attack, with a tremendous amount of planning, miraculously leaves no deaths, and very little injury.


The series’ appeal is propelled by the viewer’s burning desire to discover Sphinx’s motive. Why would they ever destroy buildings and then bother to save those inside? What could possibly be the reason behind their attacks? 


With the execution of Sphinx’s goal being so “hush hush,” it creates a morally undefined atmosphere where you don’t truly know whether to cheer the main characters on or wish for their devious schemes to come to an end. It’s so unclear as to whether they’re actually antagonizing Japan for a good or a bad reason that the anime allows itself to cover such a plethora of topics without ever outlining one specific message. Terror in Resonance explores the feelings of social outcasts and injustice, national pride, and the decisions between right and wrong not always being so clearly understood. In this sense the underlying theme or message of the anime is almost entirely up to the viewer’s perspective, and there is a choice of what you yourself wants to take away from the show, even if the message that was intended is set in stone. 


Terror in Resonance succeeds entirely at being the type of story where the whole point is up to interpretation. Its only real problem at accomplishing is the amount of plot devices the anime uses to get its points across. Sheer waves of “conveniences” glare in your face if you actually pay attention. How did Sphinx acquire the resources to actively invade a nuclear testing facility, and steal the one thing kept completely under wraps there? What about their ability to make and detonate explosives? Why does there seem to be only being one competent police officer in the task force? WHY DO THEY NEED TO GO TO HIGHSCHOOL? 

If the anime had bothered to shed light on so many of these questions then the realism of Terror in Resonance would be all the more terrifying, and for what the anime likes to pander through, realism is something that is far more than just necessary. It is what creates the tension in the first place. 


And not only this, but the plot seems to go off on a tangent as time goes on and loses its believability even more with ridiculous shenanigans and unrealistic police procedurals and legal reprehension.


But even if the suspension of disbelief for this show is so utterly ridiculous, it is still, after all of these contrivances, able to use terrorism as a ploy for recognizing other social issues really ****ing well. And at that, it is a fantastic metaphor, where instead of having realistic occurrences, has realistic emotion.

---Plot Score: -Great- ---




---CHARACTERS---

In the world of Terror in Resonance, the minds behind the terrorist group of “Sphinx” are two seventeen year old boys, who instead of going by their real names, or even plausible aliases, go by the numbers “Nine” and “Twelve.”


Sphinx’s backstory is quickly alluded to but never fully realized until much later in the anime. Their position of being terrorists comes off as a mixture of being curious and deplorable, and their personalities are the definition of contrast. Twelve is easygoing, and somewhat absent minded. He’s the type of warm, carefree soul who just really doesn’t give a damn, with a smile compared to the sun. Nine is almost the exact opposite of this. He’s easily concerned and never opens up, always keeping to himself. The type of person to become lost in thought, and is unforgiving, with eyes compared to ice. 


The duo shares the same goal but have completely different ways of wanting to go about accomplishing it. They are, for lack of a better explanation, two sides of the same coin. In all honesty it’s a phrase overused to elaborate on the two but it’s absolutely true. This portrayal of a distant, yet brotherly relationship is very well composed, when one considers their past. 


On another positive note, there’s Kenjirou Shibazaki, the detective who stuck his nose into business he shouldn’t have many years ago, and has since been moved to a different position in the police force. His past is one of resent, and his characterization is very solid overall, as he is demonstrated as the type of person who likes to take charge of a situation even if it isn’t really his place, and is a natural born leader with a “no nonsense” attitude. I’d even argue the possibility of him actually being the main character, and not Sphinx, simply because of his amount of screen time. And not only that, he seems to be the only police officer who can do his job.


These three are the ones who make up the “good” portion of the cast. But the anime has two other characters that pull the quality of the cast down, one of them being exponentially worse than the other. These two characters are the main antagonist, Five, and the girl who got caught up in Sphinx’s first attack, Lisa Mishima. 


Lisa’s serves as the “damsel in distress” character who can’t seem to do anything but get herself into trouble. She grew up in a home where her mother was so protective of her she regularly became hostile, and her father likely left because of it. Her actual personality and history are so relatable for many people and difficult to swallow that she ends up being sprinkled with some fantastic realism. But her whole purpose is just to be one gigantic plot device, and that utilization is an insult to her actual depth. She’s constantly in harms way, and is always having to be saved by Sphinx. I felt like she could have been used in a way that didn’t disrespect her as a person. But despite her shortcomings, the impact she has on Sphinx, especially Twelve, turned into a refreshingly warm interaction, one that made the sympathy that was hung over Sphinx’s head much more genuine. Because of this, I feel she is a fantastic character who was simply used incorrectly. 


-Potential Spoiler-

But one character that just cannot be redeemed is the lead villain, Five. Her schemes were almost entirely unnecessary and undeniably ridiculous. She came in and wrecked episodes six through ten, and is nothing but bland and unappealing, shoehorned in for the purpose of revealing more emotional trauma and backstory of the main characters. If she were to be subtracted from this story, the quality of the cast would ascend greatly, because the story would have been able to go in numerous directions.

-Potential Spoiler Over-


Luckily, the faults of the few do not destroy the entire experience. The other characters, despite Lisa’s poor role, were perfect for the anime.

---Characters Score: -Great- ---




---ANIMATION---

I have never seen an anime produced by Studio MAPPA before, and I have to say, they nailed everything they possibly could have. 


The art and animation is absolutely gorgeous. Explosions are intense, fast movement is outlined by different levels of light and darkness, and objects like metal and glass have some of the most realistic “glares” this side of the Fate franchise.


The color palette is filled with dull greens and blues and dark hues of gray and black, and some of the characters, like Twelve and Shibazaki, aren’t similar to anything I’ve ever seen before, and incredibly unique in design. Wood furnishings, buildings and fire look great, its like every scene is kissing your eyes.


There was a scene in episode one where it was all entirely shot from a first person point of view on a snowmobile, and the flurry of snow and speed fluidity was so convincing you could just feel the ice in the wind.

---Animation Score: -Amazing- ---




---SOUNDTRACK---

There’s nothing better in anime than being treated to A+ animation and a stellar soundtrack, and Terror in Resonance continues to deliver.


This anime has some of the most beautiful music that I’ve ever heard. There is not a single bad piece in it, and it has this relaxing, soft sound that occasionally delves into despair or pure eeriness. Not only that, but the ending song, “Dare ka, Umi wo,” preformed by Aimer, was really one of the only anime endings I didn’t skip; I sat there, and listened to it every single episode. It was fantastic.

---Soundtrack Score: -Amazing- ---


AFTER REPORT:


PROS:

- Unique and original; surpasses social boundaries of what can be covered in a television program

- Incorporates real world problems into narrative

- A few great characters and beautifully portrayed emotion

- Amazing animation, godly soundtrack

- Interpretable messages 

- Genuine mystery; you want to know what the hell is going to happen

MIXED:

- Could be off-putting because of subject matter (Terrorism)

CONS: 

- Poor utilization of other characters, sometimes not as fleshed out as they could have been

- Suspension of Disbelief heavily hinders a “realistic” setting

- Formulaic first few episodes (this problem doesn’t really fix itself, as soon as it loses its “crime of the week” it screws itself with Five


OVERALL: -Great-

With as many problems as this anime has, it doesn’t ever dip down below anything less than great in its performance. Even if it did have its fair share of messy script writing, its messages and mystery overshadow them as much as they possibly can, and sometimes the emotion demonstrated in the show throws the production values in the garbage, and ends up being the most impressive part.


Shinchiro Watanabe’s “Zankyou no Terror” is actually somewhat of a controversial anime, with many mixed scores. But with all of its Pros and Cons taken into consideration…


…I gratefully award Terror in Resonance with a well-deserved 8/10

Plot:
I thought this plot was pretty unique since it's not everyday you see an anime that has terrorists bombing buildings for a certain cause. 
Art:
I thought it was amazing but it doesn't reach up to Fate/Stay Night Unlimited Blade Works (2014) in the animation section.
Sound:
The music was pretty good and the opening for this anime was tied with the Tokyo Ghoul opening because both are just so good >.>
Character:
The characters are likable and they're pretty interesting. I thought Lisa was the most useless character in this anime (Sorry to the Lisa Fans). I also hated Five but didn't really know why (maybe because her sheep-likehair bothered me? O.O)\n
Enjoyment:\n
I really did enjoy this anime. It always had me on the edge of my seat and I was always impatient for the next episode when I finished one.\n
Overall:\n
This anime started well in the beginning, was kinda bad in the middle and amazing at the end. I recommend you watch it but it's your choice.

I'm a big fan of the Psychological genre. But not all Psychological anime can keep me satisfied.
This is one of those series that suprises me and many other viewers, again and again.
Story~8/10
We start our thrilling adventure in Tokyo, a great big city, where everyone can't get attention.
Little to no backround information about the characters is given in the beginning. We learn about the tragedies that will haunt our three main characters for the rest of their life.
Our three main characters that are bound together by friendship, blood, sweat and desire, are about to tell you their story.
Art~10/10
The animation in Zankyou no terror is very wellfitting to this anime. My first impression when watching this for the first time was that the creators used some type of gray filter. I'm really thankful for that, the filter is amazing in providing the mysterious and thrilling filled space.\n
The art is beautiful, realistic and fits perfectly with everything else in the anime.\n
Both opening and ending is well made with a gorgeous artwork.\n\n\n\n
Sound~10/10\n
The OST for Zankyou no terror is one of the highlights. The music is produced by our beloved Yoko Kanno, Known for making the amazing music for anime like Cowboy Bebop, Porco Rosso, Wolf's rain and much more. Music is something that connects us to the characters that we se on screen. So you haven't felt the connection between the characters and you? Well look no further,  Zankyou no terror shows you how it's done. The show contains a CD with eight teen well produced songs with excellent quality.\n\n
Characters~7/10\n
Zankyou no terror has one of the most unexplained characters that i've had the pleasure to watch.\n
They are realistic, unique, and convincing.\n
We have Nine who is a mastermind in his early twenties that is trying to escape his horrible and inescapable past.\n\n
Twelve is a young man that has two sides. A child-like one and an adult one. He treats Nine like a big brother.\n\n
Then we have Lisa, our most interesting character. Sadly we don't get to know much about her throughout the episodes. She is always in the way and is very often pushed away, at least that is how she describes herself. However she makes a difference and has a big effect on Nine and Twelve.\n\n
Overall/Enjoyment~10/10\n
It feels weird to rate ten out of ten here. But Zankyou no terror is probably the best anime of the 2014's Summer season, for me it was the best i had seen in years.\n
I have seen people complaining about the loose ends and the things that they left out.\n
Why not take the show for what it is? Maybe all the mysterious and unanswered questions is what makes it so beautiful.\n
It was a great ride.

Zankyou no terror, or terror in resonance, is the best anime I've ever seen. It beautifully depicts the story of 12 and 9 and really lets you see deep into each characters pain they all hold.Its a mature anime and its quite realistic in the sense of how common terror attacks have become.
 The soundtracks are all stunning, especially 'von' in the Ferris wheel scene-which was easily the best scene.
If you are looking for an engaging anime that will give you the feels, this is it, all of the different aspects in this anime add up to create a beautiful story of two high schoolboys trying to get recognised for what they've been through.
