Beginning was intriguing, but after several episodes it turned to shit. Idea to bomb for attention isn't really doable without some casualties, and that makes MCs quite contradictory... Whole airport thing was crap. I hate when something tries to portrait someone to as intelligent by using chess... Of course thing like this can't have happy ending...
Maybe there was something more deep to think about... the end justifies the means? Would work if means werent bombs and end wasnt some crappy story abou destroyed childhood... Maybe whole moral dileamma of just following orders ? Could that be it? Either this anime has no moral story behindit, or it has several, but too general to give you something more that you could get just form thinking about these moral dilemmas ...\n\n
To sum it up: Only surprising thing about story was MCs incompetence (there could be another paragraph about this...). The sound and visuals were quite good. The characters were 1 dimensional and inflexible. Just go do some thought experiment about "the end justifies the means (... to which extend)" and you can save 4 hours.

Spoilers
The anime showed a respectable dose of maturity. It did not spoil gravity of the plot with cheap fan-services and try hard jokes (Unlike some really popular animes *cough* fmab*cough* ). Nothing was out of place.
The plot was highly intriguing. However, in the end, it feels a little incomplete and did not quite quench my thirst (May be i had my hopes too high, especially after the first few episodes ). It is not a broken storyline, but it does leaves some questions unanswered (mostly about Five's involvement, like how did Five survive and how did she became so powerful in the US intelligence, whatis the real deal with her and Nine ). The conclusion was not as powerful as the beginning. And unexpectedly (,unnecessarily and un-subtly ) snipping off a favorite character seemed more like a frail attempt to shock you into a cathartic ending.


The art and sound really blended in with each other and the story. The music was really moving. And the art was neat was well.


There is little character development (but its understandable considering the length of the anime and the time-scope of the plot). However the characters were convincingly coherent. I really loved how they were close to life and not the that's-how-they-do-it-in-anime characters. May be the only exception is Five who felt life a textbook anime character (even by the looks). Lisa indeed seemed shoehorned into the plot (as i read in another review above), with a vague backstory to fit her in, but I liked her.


The enjoyment peaked in the first half and flat lined till the last episode with some spiking at the end. What I like most was how true the art style and anime as a whole stood true to the seriousness of the plot. The treatment was, in every way, what I wished to see in a anime with a serious plot like this.

The two main characters are bland. I don't even know if the second main character is even necessary. The heroine doesn't seem like the typical “we must put in a female love interest” in this one, but she still seems unnecessary and is pretty much useless most of the anime. When she does get used, its in an annoying and cliche way. The whole romance part of the story is like second dull story that should have been taken out.
Another ANNOYING thing about this anime is that it goes out of its way to put crowd pleasers that take away the seriousness from the show,like flashy/silly actions scenes, and ridiculous/lazy excuses so you sympathize with certain characters more.\n
The whole story ends up being rather dull and somewhat pointless. Its like little chunks of story too far apart in between this huge filler train. If you don't like the fist episodes then you should probably stop watching because there is little to look forward to in terms of reward. Basically, the story develops in a SLOW way and is overshadowed by A LOT of filler and useless stuff. And the story/mystery turns out to be a “really, thats it?” meh.

Ok so I honestly fell in LOVE with this anime (wanting to buy it). I mean there is so much detail with the art direction (Just look at the first episode and you can tell with how they animated the characters when walking to school, and when Lisa is running down the stairs while the building is falling. The blur and effects gives the animation more a live action theatrical look). This is an anime where you have to pay attention to what every character says and does to understand the whole story of whats going on...
Lets get started!: 
Story: 9
Ok I love the overallstory and idea. I mean the characters we are suppose to be rooting for are the "Bad guys"-which is a nice little twist. Although they never to kill anyone and even go out of there way to make sure people are out of harms way.

The problem with the story? There isn't enough episode! This isn't just me being a fan girl wanting more episode for my enjoyment (although that would be nice) but it seems like the anime just scratches at the surface. There are many mysteries and stores left untold...like what was it like in the lab? What was 5 relationship with 9 and 12? Specifically whats 5's relationship to 9? Why didn't 5 leave the lab with them?What was the big deal with the chest game?  Why happened between the years 9 and 12 after they escaped the lab? What happened to Lisa at the end, did she go back to her mother?

We get little bits and pieces of VERY short flashbacks and dialogue but never go deeper then that. It is like this anime is trying do SO MUCH, which isn't a problem it is the fact that is only has 11 episodes to tell the story.


Art: 10

The art and animation is AMAZING! The Ferris wheel scene and the bike scene are just perfectly done! Nothing else to say (which is why I gave it a 10)


Sound: 10

Again very well done it is not overdone and adds to the scene (Which I think is very important and why I also gave it a 10)


Characters: 7

Sadly the characters suffer the same fate as I stated with the story-although it suffers more only giving us basis of the characters personality. I think the two characters that suffered the worst were 5 and Lisa (with the character I found the hardest to understand was 5). You can TELL there is more to the character which is a shame. I mean I would have liked to see Lisa have interest or do something besides being clumsy (like having a hobby or doing something that she is actually good at to develop her character that is buried under all that self conciseness).

It is even worst for the side characters...where you don't understand some of why they do what they do. I mean the detectives go to a guy who was part of the research lab and he just tells them because....no real reason given besides he is old?

All I am confused as to why 9 and 12 join the school at the first episode..then never come back to the school (with it being summer break the next day? or something). What?


Enjoyment: 10

Even though this show had a hear wrecking ending I still enjoyed its interesting premise and story. This anime is defiantly one of a kind and almost had me crying (which I can say is a lot more then most anime done for a while-since the ending of Angel Beats). Why do I do this to myself? I don't know..haha but I still enjoyed the anime and can say that this anime has tons of rewatch value.


Overall: 9

This anime is the closest I can say to being perfect (-it is close but no cigar). A bold statement I know but that is my opinion on it. The only problem is the lack of episode to spread out-and allow for more in-depth look at the characters.

I mean I admit I do not like the ending but it's realistic (although I do wish the ending was different). The characters are interesting (despite not being able to go in depth on them), the art along with the music is amazing, and the overall story is intriguing. Posing some very philosophical questions. Is what they are doing right? Should they actually be considered terrorist?

The overall tone of this anime is dark (if you don't mind that) and as mentioned before I think it has great rewatch value.

It is clear that this one encourages many people can manage not to like. But let's be sincere. It is some encourage that it treats the topic of the terrorism? You like it or not this topic, you finish meeting the entire series. In my occasion I met of the pull and my mother. I come near encourage this to the soul. It is not one encourage of terrorism 100 % if not that is one it encourages of persons who in some moment of his life exploit emotionally. I recommend to you much this one encourage. Therefore to the general level we still havethe question of ... that makes that it is so good does this one encourage? My more sincere response: I have not even idea. It is one encourage very hypnotically and for which I cannot give reasons of because it is so brilliant. An aspect that I was charmed with was the music of this one encourage.

Certifications around the world: 
Australia:M  Canada:PG (Manitoba/Ontario) Canada:13 (Quebec) New Zealand:M South Korea:15 UK:12 US: TV-14
My rating:
14+  || Whilst Zankyou No Terrror contains little violence in terms of blood or gore, it is an anime that is virtually centered around terrorism and illegal activities. It does not glorify these activities, but considering the material and some blood and violence in places, I would say it should be a 14+. However also considering the storyline itself, I feel like it might be better enjoyed and clearly understood by more mature teens, so maybe a 15+. It also heavily hints at one of the maincharacters having a mental illness: depression. Take your own guesses from that and the official certifications.


Recomendation: Subbed, I believe the voice acting is better and has more emotion, however I have watched the dub all the way through as well and it is pretty good!


Genre: thriller/action/mystery, however it has many quieter and softer moments that are just essential for a good anime, that allow you to get to know the characters some more and just understand so much.


Review: 


Zankyou No Terror is a beautiful, exciting and engaging anime. While the first couple of episodes may be confusing and perhaps a little off-putting for some as you may feel as if you are watching criminals and understanding none of it, if you follow the general three episode rule (always watch at least three episodes of an anime to give it a chance. If you still aren't even remotely interested, then maybe it isn't for you) some small mysteries are explained and the excitement begins as you are allowed to see some more of what is going on. The soundtrack is absolutely beautiful, one of the best I have ever listened to and it adds so much atmosphere and feeling. It is timed perfectly with pacing and really does so much to match the mood of the scene - and change yours. The animation is realistic (for an anime, as in most everything is well proportioned, the faces and postures are drawn well, the landscape is amazing) and each character has distinct and different facial features and expressions that really say so much about their personality. The development of both the story and characters is very skillfully done and in just thirteen episodes this anime lets you feel like you know the characters. You begin to get a sense of who they are and what they want from episode one, and even the smallest details like how they smile in different situations or little things in their masterfully written and shown backstories just make them seem so much more real. Finally, before I start squealing about how much I love this anime, I'll just end on the fact that I think this anime is a must-see, whether you are a massive fan of anime or not. I think it has an ability to speak deeply to you in some way, no matter who you are, and I honestly believe that through the course of this anime your views and feelings will change from what you felt at the beginning.






FUN FACT: 

In an interview with Otaku USA Magazine director Shinichirou Watanabe stated that the music of Icelandic band Sigur Rós gave him visual images that inspired the series and its soundtrack. He also states that the team went to Iceland to record the music.

This anime was recommended by a friend of mine that's why I had high expectations. Before watching, I read its plot and to be honest, I really found it interesting so I checked it out immediately. The first few episodes were really good. It kept me wanting to watch more and finish it asap. The whole terrorism stuff got me. Didn't expect it would turn out to be bland. The show could've been something more. I didn't really see that much development on the later episodes? Also, I felt like the female protagonist was rather pointless???? Like she weren't really much of a help? Therewasn't any significance at all. Also, suddenly introducing a friend turn enemy without a properly explained reason turned me off. Well, there were a couple of flashbacks when the show felt like it but that's all it is. There were just a lot of unanswered stuff even though a conclusion was reached. Anyway, this show was such a letdown for me and again, it could've been something more.

What can I say about Zankyou no Terror. I finished the last episode and for the next hour or so I had this weird feeling that wouldn't go away. I was replaying moments of the show, especially the ending, over and over in my head. Then the theme song started playing on repeat in my head. I realized, this is something special that's only happened to me with a few other shows. Death Note. Tokyo Ghoul Season 1, Game of Thrones. And Doctor Who. 
The issue of terrorism is an interesting and different premise. But it's presented in a way that is flipped around. Thetwo main characters never actually hurt anybody.


The characters of Nine and Twelve are unique. Twelve seems to have this childish optimism at times, whereas Nine just wants to get the jobs done and is set on the mission. 


Shibuzaki, the detective assigned to the bombings case, is pretty much a basic brooding detective. Until the end. where you can see a little bit more normality in him. Sometimes he solves the riddles a little too quick to be realistic. But overall, he's just okay. 


Lisa had a really unique backstory set up. She has an abusive, controlling mother, and an eating disorder, which would have been neat to see the show try to explore. But after the third episode. Her character becomes a bland female protagonist that's only around to get kidnapped so that Nine and Twelve can save her. 


However. I do praise the animators on character design. They're very unique. Lisa has bushy brows and small eyes. (Unique traits that we usually don't see in anime) Twelve has a really friendly smile at almost all times. sometimes you can't even tell what he's actually thinking.


The sound effects are pretty crisp and realistic.

I adore the ethereal tone that some of the ost carries. 

The theme song is beautiful, stayed with me for days. 


Overall, I give this show a 9/10

Thrilling, yet lacking in overall fulfillment. It honestly had an interesting story, but personally, I felt that it ended abruptly. The potential it had to be a masterpiece was there though, so overall I would consider it to be an amazing anime that deserves a watch.
The characters were interesting, and the aspect of mystery made the show so much more interesting. The action scenes looked fluid and the art style is polished. It obviously can't compare to the production value of more recent anime, but I liked how stylistic it was, and I'm sure any anime viewer will be able to appreciate it. Interactions betweencharacters were a little awkward at the start of the show, but once you get to know more of their background, you'll be able to better appreciate why they are the way that they are. It's definitely an anime that is thought-provoking, so if you like that in your media, then you might find something enjoyable.


I found Lisa to be rather annoying, since she has the sadly, common victim mindset. This is however, mostly due to the circumstances of her life. The main antagonist's motives are questionable, but considering the background that the main characters share, I don't find it surprising. The main problem that I do have with this anime though is the ending that felt a tad bit rushed. I would have liked to see the story fleshed out more before the conclusion.


Overall, it's an amazing anime that I would recommend to any new anime-watcher, but I wouldn't consider it to be the masterpiece that several others regard it as. Do put it on your plan to watch list though, since it's definitely one that you shouldn't miss.


Thanks for reading this review!

Zankyou no Terror is a psychological/mystery thriller that will evoke memories of Death Note in the way that the two main characters "Twelve" and "Nine" play with the police. The story makes use of many riddles and mysteries to progress the story while also alluding to the past so the viewer can understand the characters' motivation. With that said, there was poor development of "Five" (one of the main antagonists) which ultimately felt a little rushed and brought the overall story of the anime down. The anime had excellent music which really brought the story to life and its worth the watch.
{Story} - The storystarted out excellent and I was engrossed in the mystery and psychological aspect from the very first episode. The problem the story ran into was their introduction of "Five" as an antagonist who was very poorly developed and really distracted from the main story. We are never given a reason for Five's interference other than she "is continuing a game from the past". The story did have a very interesting and complete resolution which saved it from its downward spiral.


{Art} - The art in Zankyou no Terror was nothing special but was certainly not bad. The only time it really stood out was in a moment when Twelve began to talk about his synesthesia (the ability to see sound). Other than that moment, it was pretty average but not bad.


{Sound} - Zankyou no Terror made excellent use of music throughout the anime and the opening and ending pieces were both excellent. I had no complaints about the sound or music and it definitely added to the flavor of the anime.


{Character} - Probably the weakest point of the anime. In an 11 episode anime, its difficult to give any depth to the characters and this really came through with both the two female main characters. Neither felt like there was any character progression and both felt poorly developed. I had originally planned to give the character section a 6/10 score, but ultimately decided to bump it to a 7/10 due to the development of the detective Shibazaki who was developed quite nicely.


{Enjoyment} - While the middle of the anime suffered due to the introduction of Five, the anime was quite enjoyable due to its incredibly fast pace and psychological/mystery aspect. I binge watched all 11 episodes in a row and never got bored (although Five definitely detracted from the show). 


{Overall} - Overall I gave Zankyou no Terror a 7/10. The show had excellent potential but suffered from poor character development, poor character motivation and a few plot holes. If the show had been given even one or two more episodes to flesh out the backstory on Five a bit further, it may have saved her entire "arc", but the lack of displayed motivation to the viewer really felt unnecessary and dropped this anime from an 8/10.

[English isn't my first language so sorry for any mistakes]
I had heard of this anime a few times but even so I started watching it with practically no knowledge about its plot. Also, I didn't have any particular expectations especially that there are 11 episodes only. Personally, I take series of such length under different criteria.
Right after the last episode I peeked at reviews out of curiosity. What astonished me was the quite repeating complain that Zankyou no Terror isn't exactly about terrorism (as the misleading title suggests). I mean, of course the two main characters weren't real terrorists (who have killing people in theirdefinition) and that's exactly the point. They don't mean to kill any people and to spread so said terror. I just want to point out that I don't consider this to be a disappointment.


Both main characters, Nine and Twelve, intrigue as their motives for planting bombs aren't specified at the beginning. Same goes to "the message" they are trying to tell. We get to know their personalities as well as glimpses on their past which led to their later actions.

Simultaneously, Misa is introduced. She may appear as another helpless girl in trouble but she was wrapped in plot nicely and had her five minutes. Psychologically, I could imagine how she could feel in certain situations and that's why I didn't find her actions annoying at all. Misa was really trying her best. Simply a lost soul in cruel world.

I like how the work of police was shown when it came to dealing with mysterious "Sphinx". They weren't simple dummies making shallow decisions. The highlighted character of detective Shirazaki plays his role well. I liked how he challenged Sphinx in their riddles and was trying to follow their way of thinking.

Then a true villian showed up. Five. Honestly, here is when I felt disappointed as her actions seemed chaotic and kind of unreasonable while she was playing the role of "the bad one". Although she was meant to have a plan I actually felt she did not (agh and that constant switching between English and Japanese). I didn't understand what her point or real grudge towards Nine and Twelve was in general.


Other thing which bothered me a few times was a bit unbelievable coincidences or mmm convenient incidents which allowed the plot to proceed smoothly. For example I was impressed with quite unprobable vast knowledge of Shirazaki when it comes to mitology. Unfortunately, it's very noticable in certain moments.


The show, in my eyes, is great when it comes to psychological aspect. Thinking about the main characters, you can immerse into their feelings and perhaps thoughts, too. The atmosphere is always held right so getting involved in what's happening in their hearts and minds is almost inevitable. To be honest this is the real beauty of Zankyou no Terror to me. Although there wasn't much space for character development, I found it satisfying and quite open to interprete. After all, it's 11 episodes. The story itself is bizarre and it may appear pathetic as a whole but I think it's more natural to focus on characters' personal experiences. It makes this series much more enjoyable and beautiful.


The animation itself was absolutely smooth and the way characters are drawn was very detailed. I loved watching this work. Also, the colours of (detailed as well) background were very atmospheric just like the lighting. Same goes to the music. Everything worked perfectly with each other.


I highly recommend Zankyou no Terror to those who would like something more serious, emotional and with high level aesthetics.

Zankyou no Terror (ZnT) was rather interesting. Admittedly, there were several inconsistencies and needs-for-improvement, but it brought about a different light to the nature of terrorism, politics, and how people are in general. 
To put it loosely, the series revolved around two young terrorists who staged riddles as to where they planted bombs around Tokyo. This usually serves as a hook for an audience, posing the questions: What are the answers? Who are these kids? What is their objective? Will they get caught? As the story progressed, it is revealed that there is more to these casualty-free attacks than just simple nationwide harassment. 
More characterswere gathered along the way: allies, foes, and the like. A problem was that although many of them may have been relevant, there was no substantial information on their backgrounds or reasons for their actions. Several silly loopholes, magic solutions/scapegoats, and confusion were also present. Examples of these are (will be vague to not spoil those who haven't seen ZnT): why is it that no one was really visibly afraid of the terrorism - after 3 explosions, I'd like to think that people wouldn't want to go outside anymore; the investigator magically had the solutions and his daughter just happened to be a physics major; what game settling; why chess; why, 5; why shoot; why... many things! 


There were also infuriating portions in the plot where it seemed to be confused whether it was a psychological thriller or a romance anime. I chose to believe that this was part of character development (or down-velopment, ahem), and that fulfilling mission isn't all there is to how a person lives. Moreover, our lovable terrorists chose a very roundabout way to prove their point. 


It must be mentioned that the art was above-average, satisfying. There was nothing too special nor bad about it. In terms of the music, I have the same opinion. 

The Engrish portions, however, were very upsetting. Seiyuu attempting to speak another language can be appreciated, but not at the cost of intelligibility. There was a vital portion at the end of the show that I completely could not understand, and this added to the disappointment. 


What proved interesting is what was highlighted during the close-ups of the police team investigating the terrorism. In a government bureaucracy, there is a usual dichotomy of what my conscience tells me vs the orders of the boss. The series takes this a step higher by adding how following this chain of command is affected by relationships on an international scale. Given all these factors, there are sentiments of hyper-nationalism (at whatever cost) from the recent world wars, which actually caused the terrorist movement in the first place. This provides an even more compelling twist.


Generally, ZnT was rather enjoyable. I may have rated it a little high considering all its loose ends and its lacking backstory. However, I find that the message the plot was trying to convey was unique and deserves special attention. With a little ironing out, it would have been an even greater anime.

It's rare to see an anime as polished as Zankyou no Terror because I had been putting this off for such a long time, I did not know what to expect and watching this is probably the best thing in a while.
The art, the music, the story, they intertwine so beautifully into this anime of twisted logic - a phrase so commonly used in a derogatory sense but for this anime, it's simply beautiful. A story of two kids taking on the world, a story where they had to grow up, that's the beauty of this anime.
The music from this anime is often sampled andthe art too, for indie music production and hearing so many of those bootlegs come to life on the screen is one of the best things about this anime.\n
If you like action animes, if you like animes with a plot, if you like animes with captivating music and storyline, this is for you. Do watch it.\n

**WARNING: THE "ITS ENDING" SECTION INCLUDES SPOILERS! IF YOU DON'T WANT IT TO BE RUINED FOR YOU, SKIP IT**
This is my first review so take it easy, no?
The way I got thrown into the show that is Zankyou no Terror, I was listening to its OST, and it had caught me right away. When I read the small description, I was actually quite interested in what the anime was about, and soon after I started watching it.
After finishing the show in one go, I can definitely say that it did have an impact on me to quite an extent.
- FIRST IMPRESSIONS -8.5/10


The first episode really did reel me in with a POW! It was wonderful, having been a long while since I haven't seen any anime with such a powerful start. Within the first episode it had some rather interesting dialogue that I will definitely remember. I can guarantee that it made me click onto the next episode.



- PLOT & STORY -

          7/10


For an original anime the plot itself wasn't as bad as I've seen people say, it was really refreshing to see something like this, but there were some points where the plot had become somewhat confusing and there were a bit of plot-holes within the story. But on the first go, they kinda blew over my head so it's not as noticeable unless you were to REALLY look at every nook and cranny of the anime. Nonetheless, I still enjoyed it! Overall it had a very strong premise, but the execution of it could've been done a tad better. (Perhaps there's a chance it could've been even better if there were more episodes in order to tell us a lot more information, but I digress.)


- CHARACTERS -

        6/10


I suppose one of the flaws in this anime were some of the characters. Although I really did enjoy them at the start and was hoping for quite the character development, it didn't really progress through the series. I'd say the extent of any character development would be on the last episode with Nine, but even that isn't very much.


Nine and Twelve - With Nine being the serious and mature one while Twelve being the exact opposite, I really did enjoy their character. One for the fact that they hint at something very big at first and two for them being polar opposites and yet companions. (It could've been taken into a different direction from what the anime had set up in my opinion) But although I knew their backstory, it didn't exactly tell us how they became this way. They were more like glimpses which doesn't help with development much. And I wanted to wish for a growth or maybe a tear in their bond together, to show what's deeper beneath them besides polar opposites. 


Lisa Mishima - At first she seemed more like a stereotypical shy type, and I was kind of skeptical to her character and her impact to the show. But at times she is pretty useful, but not useful enough. 

For example: It says the she is a main character, but most of the show focuses more on Sphinx and the Police. She doesn't do anything in particular that impacts the show as much as the others, even when Twelve tries to talk to her. But I wouldn't say she was a BAD character, per say. She actually had some potential with the relationship between her mother and the reason why she had run away in the first place. Looking at her as a whole she was at least a fair character, she just doesn't have much of an impact for me.


Shibazaki - He was not a bad character at all, really. To put it simply he was a very clever person who had always been doubted by the police force. I wish they had put more info into his backstory and himself in general since he from the get go, was already interesting from the beginning. 


Five - If I were to be honest, she was kind of annoying. What bugs me about her character (and could be classified as a plot-hole) is that she has gotten away with almost everything until someone FINALLY stands up to her after the damage has been done. Yes, she drove the story along but to me she was more like an obstacle than an actual character... She definitely had a lot of potential for developing many others in the show though. Sadly, that didn't happen as much as I'd hoped for.


Although not very developed, I did get rather attached to them.


- ART -

  9/10


As someone who loves to draw, I LOVED the artwork and detail that had been put into the style! The lighting was good, and it really brought me into their world. The character designs were sort of generic, but the style of the characters was something noteworthy in my opinion. Overall, it was quite a breathtaking experience!


- SOUND & MUSIC -

           9/10


For sound, I'd say the voice actors did a pretty fine job and it impacted me a lot. The music for this anime was on point, and when each track played it definitely fitted in with the rest of the scenes! (I recommend that you listen to all of the soundtrack by itself!)


- ITS ENDING -

       9/10


As it had built up, I was on my toes the entire time from episode 10 to 11. Finding out more about what "The Athena Plan" was and more foreshadowing of what's to come. I knew what was going to happen, but I didn't expect it to happen in such a shocking way. Nine breaks down to the point where he's crying, and I had burst into tears as well. Although it was heartbreaking (I was REAL attached to them, okay?) I really can't see it end any other way. But it did carry a rather deep message and reveals why Sphinx had done this. They wanted to be remembered for what they had gone through, because they were basically property that nobody could care less for. Used and thrown away. And so Shibazaki had granted their wish as they faded away. It had a bittersweet ending, but I was incredibly satisfied with it. 


- OVERALL ENJOYMENT + CONCLUSION -

                              8/10


As an original anime, it definitely is much better than most I've seen! The references to Greek mythology keeps you captivated, it has an interesting concept, fairly good characters, the pacing was excellent, and the sound and art is just fantastic! (It'll bring you right into their world!) 

Do I recommend it? I'd say so. But for those of you who are VERY into plot and development, there may not be much for you.

Zankyou no Terror is a good anime.
First of all, let's begin with this, so you're not tricked into thinking this is a show about terrorism and the morals around it. Because it isn't. It really isn't anything I expected when going into it.
Whether or not I recommend it, is a bit of a complicated question, but I'll ultimately say no. There are definitely some good - even very good - parts to this story, but I just can't recommend it. Or can I? I mean, fuck, it's difficult, alright?
Going to deep into what the story is actually about is kind of risking spoilers, but I'lltry a spoiler-free version: Zankyou no Terror is about connectivity. Not just between two people, or about someone who's on the outside of societal norms, but a society. Also, it's about the Japanese climate and generational gaps, in a post-war society (even if the show has a modern setting). It's just a shame there's so much in the way to actually get to that. Well, technically it's always there, but it's just not "stated" that that's what it's about. Sure, us viewers have to read into things as they happen, but sometimes it can't help to kinda lead us to what were supposed to get out of it. Eh.


Anyway, ZnT centres on a duo of young men, Nine and Twelve, who fashion themselves terrorists with a cause. Nine is the classic silently intelligent bad-ass you often see in anime. Twelve is another stereotype - the hyper individual, with a magnetism that pulls people to him. Initially Twelve seems to have the interesting twist of being a psychotic emotional manipulator, but that quickly goes away to reveal a pretty normal guy, minus the terrorism angle. I won't go too much into the attacks and repercussions themselves, but I will say that the show definitely veers hard away from very serious terrorism stuff - is, I guess, how I'll put it. They call themselves Sphinx 1 and 2, and the series starts with them stealing a nuclear device. After that, they go to record and upload videos with them forecasting bombings, and basically daring the cops to do anything about it. They challenge the police to solve puzzles related to Greek mythology. So, those of us who aren't read up on Sophocles' Oedipus just get to kick back and watch the story unfold.


Among the police trying to solve Sphinx' riddles is former detective Shibazaki, who got taken off the force in the past for investigating police corruption. He's the series' most interesting character, in that he actually has a fully developed character. He feels like a more mature L Lawliet, without the eccentricity. He knows what man-made disasters can do to a country, and will go far to stop Sphinx' plans.


Into this mess, Lisa Mashima is pulled. She's a schoolgirl that's bullied by the other girls and seems to generally hate life. Her mother seems incredibly  Twelve injects himself into her life, which has huge consequences on both of their lives. There is potential to the Lisa character, for sure. She could have offered another, but still parallel, viewpoint to the Sphinxes', and help to further explore all three characters. That doesn't really happen, though, or at least not soon enough. She plays the damsel in distress and is portrayed as being quite ridiculously useless. Her bad cooking is played for laughs, because anime stereotype. Her arc ends up in a pretty good place before the series crashes and burns at the end.


The story is excellently animated. Absolutely gorgeous. The music is also a stand-out, behind which is industry veteran Yoko Kanno. One song has guest vocals from the vocalist of one of my favourite bands, Agent Fresco (whom you should definitely check out, yo). The soundtrack does its job superbly well, and adds to some very good scenes.


You know what? Fuck it, I'll recommend it. If you can bear the really bad ("the bad", obviously being relative to what you enjoy from your anime) of this show, there's a story there that kinda deserves to be seen. To quote myself from earlier, because I can, "It's just a shame there's so much in the way to actually get to that." Cut a couple of episodes, especially the parts with the nonsensical and oh-so-uninteresting villain that you can see a mile away after watching the first episode if you've seen a couple of anime series' before (seriously, the villain and its cadre, and its actions and reactions from the local police are fucking terrible ends up being a ridiculously awful addition), and focus on the more personal and cultural story. Hell, it could have worked very well as a longer feature film at like 2 hours or so.


All in all, it's a troubled, yet good anime that has something to say , even if its message gets a bit lost in between its sometimes crazy antics. It's not getting a whole-hearted recommendation, but I think it's worth checking out. At the very least, it at least tries to stand out from most other anime released today, and that's worth something.

I wouldn't recommend this show to anyone in good conscience, except for pointing out how something can go wrong.
Starting out with a woobie extraordinaire and two possibly virtuous terrorists, I had high hopes. With each passing episode however, the plot became more contrived and became more driven by BS nonsensical ideals. Deus and diablo ex machina are abundant to the plot's convenience. 
I can remember each character's design quite well, so props to them. All I remember of the environments however were that they were darkly lit.
Overall, watch only the first couple of episodes until you want to quit because none of the show's problemscease. Or watch until the end to see how not to construct plot.

*SPOILERS* (I have a lot of questions I really need to get off my chest through a review)
I'd like to start by saying I really, really enjoyed this anime. It was extremely exciting and the art is really top notch in my opinion. That being said, there are some plot holes.
I can believe the story for the most part, until Five steps in. First off, holy shit her English. It just made me want to punch a hole in the wall. Also the chessboard thing at the airport doesn't make sense. So for Nine to indicate his moves, he just runs around the airport. Whatif there were two pieces that could move to the same spot? How would Five know which piece he meant?


On top of that, after all the crazy things she does (blow up a plane, etc etc.), it takes until the last episode for her command to be relinquished? There's no way the US government would take that long. 


Speaking of the US government, can you even snipe someone through a moving helicopter? And also, if Nine and Twelve wanted to live, they had ample chance to get away from the choppers. 


Which leads me to the part where Twelve dies. So we know that Five and Nine both had deteriorating physical condition, but Twelve didn't. If Twelve wasn't shot, would he have been able to live a normal life? Also Lisa didn't seem that sad that Twelve died, even though I thought they were lovers...


Just some food for thought. If you've read this far and haven't watched it, why the hell did you read it when I wrote spoilers? All in all, loved it and would recommend.

Zankyou no Terror – “Are you going to destroy the world?” Terrorism and extremism are now used almost one in the same as many believe it is only extremists who can be terrorists. That their only goal is pure destruction of society and it doesn’t matter what it takes and many lives it takes. So what happens when terrorists are highly calculating teenagers who will only set off bombs when there is no chance of a causality occurring? 
Story: 7
Lisa is constantly bullied at school and has an overly obsessive mother, so when one day two new students show up and one of them startstalking with her. Later she goes to mall where she runs into the boy again who gives her a present. After crying herself asleep in the bathroom she awakens to the fire alarms going off. Suddenly she gets a call from that boy, saying that she has two choices.  Either help them bomb the building, or die. \n
The developments keep us on the edge of our seats, just as any good thriller should. The riddles given to help the police are interesting, if albeit confusing for those without an extensive knowledge of Greek mythology. The whole story line really cannot be predicted as one would really need to get into the complex minds of Sphinx to figure out what the next plan is. But as Sphinx plays cat and mouse games with the police we start seeing an ongoing theme. That Sphinx will soon either be found out or tell the great secret they are hiding. Unfortunately most of this great build up is almost thrown out the window the moment Five shows up. Gone were the riddles, gone was the development as to why Sphinx was doing all of this. All for the pure reason of showing more explosions are creating more drama. These developments left the real reason for the bombings to only be discovered by a side character. And when the reasons finally did come to light they leave almost no time for a proper explanation of Sphinx’s actions.\n
Characters: 7\n
Sphinx, the terrorist duo who has captivated the attention of Tokyo as they await where they will strike next. They escaped from a research laboratory after setting part of it on fire and have since been on the run, all the while holding a strong hatred towards the government and others who worked with the laboratory. Nine is the mastermind behind Sphinx and thinks of the plans and how best to execute them. He is very cold and calculating leaving nothing to chance. Despite being shown as devoid of emotion he cares for Twelve as a brother, but states he would kill Lisa without a second thought if she gets in his way. Twelve is the “comedian” of the group, surprising really since his job is deliver the bombs that could potentially kill hundreds of people he is very light hearted and constantly making jokes and laughing, much at Nine’s expense. Unfortunately neither really develop into anything other than Twelve falling in love with Lisa. \n
After being recruited as an accomplice Lisa stays with the duo as she too wants to destroy the world. Lisa very much draws those that want the current world to burn to ashes, who are bullied every day, and have a horrible family life, and having no one to turn to. She constantly wants to help, but in the end usually causes the duo to rescue her. She becomes accepted near the end but isn’t till the very end that we see her change.\n
The detectives could of a better developed group of characters, but only Shibazaki gets the attention needed to make great character. He quickly starts to understand the riddles given to the police and soon takes the case very personally. Unfortunately as Five is introduced the fighting between him and Sphinx come to an end as he is tasked with finding why they causing all this chaos.\n
No terrorism show would be complete without a visit from the Americans. And the moment they get involved it escalates at an insane pace. The taskforce is headed by Five, another child from the laboratory. In order to fulfill a personal grudge she constantly engages in her own outlandish, and deadly, acts of terrorism as she knows fully well that Sphinx will stop her. By far one of the most insane characters I’ve seen. I kept asking myself would the American government actually permit an agent to potentially kill hundreds of people just to settle a grudge? The answer is no. Her character only adds drama and when the show comes to a close, she had no effect whatsoever \n
Art/Animation: 9\n
The art is shockingly good coming from a brand new studio. A lasting characteristic of anime is the big eyes and unrealistic faces. However we are starting to see a trend in creating more realistic characters so that we have a chance to relate to someone who looks like us. So the characters in this anime look very real. The looks add weight as we are more likely to take them seriously when we see the icy stare of Nine or the psychotic smile of Twelve. Apart from amazing characters the whole animation was beautifully smooth giving the explosions and collapses an almost “beautiful” look. \n
Sound: 8\n
Kanno Yoko once again reminds us just has amazing she is. She took control of every part of the music you hear and she did an absolutely astonishing job. The OP and ED just run chills down your spine as they give a sinister vibe that can’t be matched. The OST is also very amazing with all the songs fitting the whole atmosphere of the anime. The voice actors were also very good, though I do hate how they have to have the worst “Engrish” speakers ever. \n
Enjoyment: 7\n
The whole anime is very original, and since studio MAPPA was able to bring in most of the staff from the legendary Cowboy Bepop, the hype only increased. And I can honestly say they met the standards of that hype. It’s depressing when a hyped show falls short of what it could or should have been, just look at both Sword Art online seasons. I always say that whenever anyone makes anything they always strive for perfection, and Zankyou no Terror was close to touching. Yes they made mistakes here and there, the story could have flowed together more, and the characters could of more development. Yet despite minor fallbacks the show as a whole is something everyone will quickly agree as the best of the season. “Remember us, Remember that we lived” Don’t worry Sphinx, we will remember.\n
Overall Score: 6.7\n

Alright, so I want into Zankyou no Terror not really knowing what to expect. With a title like Terror in Residence I was a bit confused as to what the overarching plot and characters. One of my friends told me not to just expect EXPLOSIONS, but I was still curious.
That's why the show is so great. You go in not knowing what you are expecting and you come out surprised. The show is incredibly well made, with a great plot up until it's final few minutes (the last three minutes killed the ending for me), and the characters are quite complex as well.
The first thingI'll say about it is the art style. A lot of anime don't try anything different with their art style, and that's what shows like Zankyou no Terror do amazing, they make you pay attention to the art style as well, ensuring that it looks different and catches your eye over the generic anime art. The OST is also quite amazing. The music in the episodes fits perfectly and is amazingly done, and the opening theme is brilliant, alongside an excellent end theme (which are often not done enough justice).


Now lets get to the good part. The characters. All four... I guess you could call them protagonists... have some aspect about them that makes them feel a lot more human than someone like Natsu Dragneel or Naruto whatever his last name is. One of them has difficulty attaching himself to people because of his past and what he is doing now. Another always feels like they have messed up because of some action she took. Another has difficulty letting go of the past.


Each of the main characters are likable, and the antagonist is just that more frustrating. And there is an air of mystery surrounding (most) of the characters, even the antagonist. Each character feels unique in some way.


Now to the one thing that annoyed me. The last few minutes. The best way to describe it would be that, while the group was on a break, Gen Urobuchi snuck into the animation studio and put in some of his sadistic brilliance into the ending. It felt like it came out of nowhere, like it was a last minute decision that had now explanation whatsoever. While it is quite sad, it also left a bitter taste in my mouth from the greatness that was the rest of the show.


One thing I will say about Zankyou no Terror is that, once it gets going, it's hard to stop watching... Which really sucks when you have school and homework... But seriously, I recommend watching it.

This anime/story had a lot of potential. So much so that in the first few episodes people were comparing it to Death Note or at least shipping them together. However, when 5 came in the picture everything was rushed, confusing, and all over the place. The beginning was very interesting, mysterious, entertaining. I wanted to see why they were doing it, what was their goal, how did everything tie together. My problem is with how everything was coming together towards the end. It seemed like they just had to have an ending so they pulled that together in an hour. So 9 just dies outof nowhere we don't get to see it nor are given a reason? \n\n
Great idea and beginning, poor execution.

As I type this, I have finished this series less than 30 seconds ago. Though the minute details are still fresh in my mind, I am sure that over time, they will fade. The story, however, will likely remain with me for years to come.
I will start by saying that I waited to watch this show. I watched the first episode shortly after it aired, and though I was interested, I found my attention span waning over time, and did not watch the rest of the series until I began to marathon it a few hours ago. I think it was the best decision Icould have made, because watching this show on a weekly basis would have been incredibly difficult for me. I feel like the impact it made all at once was far greater than what it would have been had I watched weekly, and if possible, I would recommend others to watch the show in a single sitting as well.


Now, on to the actual review, which will be spoiler free.


Story (10):


This is not a story to be taken lightly, and is certainly not for the faint of heart.  There are many parallels to be drawn to past events, such as September 11th, the bombing of Hiroshima, and many others that can hit very close to home for some. I leave this warning because if you are able to handle the grim nature of this show, you will come out on the other side a changed person from having seen this show. Combining a beautiful dose of both drama and mystery, "Zankyou no Terror", or "Terror in Resonance" tells the story of two teenaged boys that, by all accounts, don't exist. They go by the names of “Nine” and “Twelve”, but more on them later. As we quickly learn, these seemingly innocuous boys are actually a duo of terrorists by the name of “Sphyx”. Their first mission, bombing a government building, is successful and they quickly gain notoriety from the media. One of their main goals is to prevent any deaths by their own actions, and their first mission results in no fatalities. Lisa Mishima is drawn in by the two after accidentally seeing their plans in action, and becomes an “accomplice” rather than face certain death. As the story progresses, we watch as Sphynx and the Japanese Police Department, among other groups, fight to carry out what they believe is right, or in some cases, to stop other parties from doing as they wish. The dynamic of the back-and-forth between all parties is a unique concept not often seen well (or done well) in anime. The ability to always stay two steps ahead of other parties while also completing their missions is a fascinating thing, as well as Sphynx’s repeated riddles, giving the viewer the chance to feel as though they are an investigator as well. It is an interesting take on the very realistic issue of terrorism in our world today.



Characters (9):


There are four characters that I will note here (there are other important characters, but as this review is spoiler free, I will not mention them here): Nine, Twelve, Lisa, and Shibazaki. Nine and Twelve, our infamous duo, offer a dynamic not unlike that of ice and fire. Nine sees the world with dark shadows looming around every corner. He is cold and harsh, but is also very caring towards Twelve. In contrast, Twelve often wears a smile and has a demeanor much like that of a child. The two, together, are incredibly smart, with planning, building, hacking, and many other abilities not often seen. Lisa Mishima is a high school girl who meets both Nine and Twelve when they transfer into the same high school. She is an outcast, often bullied and struggling with problems at home. Given a sudden choice of life or death, she decides to become an “accomplice” of Sphynx, and becomes the only person who knows of their plans. Shibazaki is a former detective with the Japanese Police Department. He follows the case closely as it happens, and becomes the one to solve Sphynx’s riddles. He chases the terrorist duo with no regard for his own well-being, and is relentless in his search for answers.


Though all of these characters are strong and well thought out, I almost feel as though there was something missing from many of them. I still have questions about some of the characters that, while not essential to the progression of the story, still remain to nag me. I feel that their personalities could have been further delved into, explored in a deeper capacity. But alas, it did not happen. What I received, however, is far more than I could have asked for in the first place.



Animation and Sound (9/9):


At first, I was rather put off by the animation style of this show. It was different from anything I had seen in the past, and therefore, quite uncomfortable. However, as I watched, the style quickly grew on me and I began to realize the real beauty within it. It is a hard feeling to describe, but for me, it evoked a sense of danger within me. Something telling me that this show was not going to be easy to stomach. And it was right. This unique style of animation fits the feel of this show perfectly. The sound is quite similar. The opening is quite unsettling, yet mesmerizing at the same time. It never failed to draw me in. There are also many other tracks within the show that are beautiful on their own, and the voice actors certainly deserve praise, but my expertise in sound and animation are both rather limited, so I will spare you of any more of my confusing analogies.



Enjoyment (10):


This show forced me to ask myself this question: What really is enjoyment? At its simplest, it is a feeling of joy evoked by an outside source. But this show did not make me feel joyful. If anything, it made me feel almost depressed. However, the fact that it could create such a feeling within me on its own is quite impressive, and the fact that my eyes were glued to the screen every moment cannot be ignored. This is a strong show, one that will make you feel things you may not have believed an anime could make you feel. Though I did not feel much in the way of joy while watching this show, the many other emotions that swelled within me as I progressed can justify my reasoning for giving this show a 10 for enjoyment.



Overall (9.5/10):


As I’ve said before, this show can absolutely not be taken lightly. It is an experience that can change a person, one that makes you question the difference between right and wrong, good and evil. If you are prepared for such a changing journey, albeit short, you will not regret your decision. This show has the ability to move mountains, metaphorically speaking, and is something that those who have seen it will remember it for years to come for its beautifully disturbing and realistic tale.

This anime pulled on my heart strings so much! I watched it all one episode after another without being unglued from my TV screen. The art is beautiful and the storyline heartbreaking. Character development unravels at a good speed and the two official OST cd's are incredible, so good in fact that I bought a copy of each. For me, I found this anime superior to others I have seen as it wasn't cliche, was enjoyable from start to finish and has left me still thinking about it  a long time after. A truly remarkable show that I always recommend to friends.

Lately I have been mostly reading manga, and have been reluctant to go back into the world of moving pictures, but Zankyou no Terror had managed to get me excited about anime once more. Now lets start with the review itself.
Zankyou no Terror tells us the tale of two seventeen year olds, who are determined to exact revenge upon Japan, for the horrors they have experienced during their childhoods. They resort to terrorism, blowing up buildings and such in Tokyo.They operate under the name Sphinx as they give out riddles to the police, so they have the option of preventing the accident from happening, ifthey get it right. On one occasion, when they are blowing up a large commercial building they happen to involve a girl, to whom they give the choice to either join their organisation, or die in the explosion. She naturally chooses to live and from there on the story then follows the trio on their quest.


This has to be one of the best realised story I have seen in a long while, and what is even more impressive is that they manage to pull it off in only eleven episode. The story begins harmlessly enough, with the main character presented as just two runs of the mill terrorists, but the development of the story afterwards, shows us everything, their backstory, motives, and much more. Here we encounter the first problem as some of these explanations come on far to late, and while in the end everything becomes clear, you are left in the dark for most of the anime. Throughout there were many thing that threw me off initially, however everything was brilliantly explained in the end.


The pacing unfortunately is nowhere near perfect, as the anime seriously looses its pace in the middle when the initial action calms down. Fortunately the pace picks up soon and the the ending episodes are nearly perfectly done. Speaking of the ending, there are a few other anime that manage to conclude as well as this one. There is a logical conclusion following the events of the anime, and while the ending itself is not exactly cheerful, it brings peace to the watcher. Well anyway the story is great, and while there are still flaws, it manages to tell us a compelling tale, that shows us an unique outlook on terrorism, and also handles many more important themes.


The characters could have been one of the highlights of the anime, but unfortunately there are a few problems, that that made me unable to enjoy the anime as much as I would have been able to otherwise. 


As I have mentioned before, the anime is really stingy on information it gives us, so while the story as such is not overmuch impacted by this, it is extremely hard to grow attached to characters, if you are given little to no information on the basis of their actions. This might have been done to invoke some kind of mystery, and on some level it accomplishes that, however the anime is not built upon that, so in the end it comes off more as a distraction, than anything else.


The other problem comes from the lack of personality of the some of the characters, especially our main terrorist duo Nine and Twelve, as well as their nemesis Five which joins the party in the middle of the series. They even lack normal names, being called only by numbers, which sounds strange, especially in the sub version, as the English words stick out far too much, but at least they manage to pronounce them correctly. Other then the lack of a true name they do come out a bit too artificial, which has to be attributed to their upbringing, even though it still does not make make them any easier to get attached to.


Now that I have finished with my complaints, it is time to give the characters some praise. Lisa our female lead, is absolutely amazingly portrayed. First shown as a lonely high school girly, dealing with a broken up family and constantly being bullied by her classmates, she slowly evolves with the help of Nine and Twelve. I have to say I felt companion toward her and that is more than I can say about the rest of the characters. The thing is she never becomes a full out terrorism god, but becomes more and more confident and useful, without ever becoming unbelievable.


Another highlight is the police force lead by detective Kenjirou Shibazaki, who is leading the investigation against Sphinx, and who I consider to be the fifth main character. The police managed to actually pose as a serious adversary for our heroes, but at the same time they are not presented as all-knowing, so the conflict comes out as quite balanced. That all changed when Five entered the picture, but I wont go further then saying that her presence becomes overbearing quickly, as I don't want to spoil anything. The supporting cast is great as well, if a bit underdeveloped, but what can one expect to get out of eleven episodes. We got many characters that appeared on screen only for a few minutes, but still managed to get stuck in my memory.


I have to say I’m split on the art, as for the majority of the time it was mediocre at best, but there were moments where the animation really shone. You see the character’s themselves are nothing special visually as well as the backgrounds, however there were points where everything changed, and the anime puts forth some of the most beautiful scenes I have seen in a while. This is all the more pronounced, as these parts are accompanied by some really great music, but more on that in the next paragraph. The anime’s colour palette is a bit subdued, focusing more on greys and blues, but still there are some bright colours thrown into the mix. The action sequences are done well enough, but sometimes the choreography leaves a bit to be desired. Fortunately for an anime such as this there is no fan service at all, as that would distract us from the story and that would be a shame.


The anime sounds fantastic. No matter how you look at it, the soundtrack is nearly perfect, it might not be able to match up to something like Noir, but it is still downright amazing. The opening track Trigger, by Yuki Ozaki is a fantastic electronic number, featuring some great vocal work backed by some interesting instrumental music. The song manages to provide the perfect mood for the anime that follows it, and the intro animation also fits the music neatly. The ending, while not as good as the intro is also impressive. Dare ka, Umi wo performed by Aimer, the band that made the unbelievable ending for the anime No.6, is a nice relaxing track that helps us reflect on the events of the episode and calms us down. The rest of the soundtrack is mostly mostly instrumental and fits the events onscreen perfectly. Surprisingly there is next to no repetition, and no track overstays its welcome. Now all of these songs are going directly into my iTunes library when I manage to get my hands on them.


To sum it all up, Zankyou no Terror an outstanding anime, that manages to tell us an interesting and unique story. While there are a few points where further improvement would be welcome, such as some of the characters and the animation quality, its positives outweigh the negatives easily. As such, I can wholeheartedly recommend the anime to anyone looking for some quality viewing, only beware as this is not the happiest anime out there. My final score for it would have to be a 9 out of 10 (however I have been thinking of changing the rating system so this rating is not permanent). 

I would really like to get some feedback as to improve my further writing efforts, and feel free to check out my slowly growing collection of reviews.

first of all i really liked this anime and it is one of the greatest of all time in my opinion why you say? i am going to tell you why in this review ok lets start

well the main characters are 3 you can say and each character has a special touch thats what i liked,and for me my fav character was 12 why?well because i think he was cool and the way he does stuff is pretty awesome and what about 9? 9 is pretty awesome too but he's a bit cold thats why i liked 12 more and for the last main character lisa well to be honest lisa doesn't have much, well my other fav character was shibazaki cuz he's understanding not like the other police.

The story is very interesting, and includes many plot twists and wandering questions that will be answered at the end. It includes lots of strategical ideals, which makes it more thrilling. However, the main female character is the only thing I don't like about this anime. She is annoying, hinders in the main characters affairs, and only serves as fan-service love interest. Even at the end I hated her! If you ignore her, than you'll definetly enjoy this anime!

Story: 10/10
Yeah,I knew it would be a good Anime because of the influence of Watanabe (one of my favorite Producers and Story writers) but i have to admit i didn't expected it to be that good, it was actually like a masterpiece to me. At the start i was thinking that 11 episodes can't be enough to make a story really good (or they let it finish with a cliffhanger) and i was expecting that i will see something good but only the beginning of it. Then i realized how fast and intense the story goes, one action after another, with not boring scenes, justpure important story scenes which were perfectly balanced, with much drama,action but also sad and deep parts in it and i think that's what made me like this anime so much.

This Anime reminds me a lot of Death Note which is probably a Masterpiece for almost every Anime lover out there. The fight between people, genius people, showing their dreams and hopes in the things they do (I would like to call it Art) - It all was just like it was in Death Note, one more aspect to say that Zankyou no Terror is probably also a Masterpiece.

I already said i added some influence of my personal enjoyment to the RATING, but i haven't done that without reason - so if you want to understand what i mean, watch the series.


Characters: 9/10


There are some characters i really like in this series, more than 3, and that's really rare for me - i usually like only one character in a anime and support him to the end, but here it was a bit different, good ones or bad ones, it didn't matter to me, i supported both sides because each side had a character with some important background story and can feel with the character trying to understand what he is thinking and why is he doing some things he does in the anime.

There are also characters which i liked just because of how they act, it was a little crazy kind of acting which was really interesting for me and i really enjoyed to watch them.

Also Nakazawa Kazuto made a really good job designing the characters, like always!


Animations: 9/10


To the beautiful part - The animations had that special art which is much more used in Animated Movies rather than in TV series and this was perfectly fitting with the story, the characters and everything else. The people who made all these animations did a really nice job, the characters and the surroundings are really beautiful and had many different colors which made the "movie" style even more movie like.


Music: 8/10


The Opening and Ending theme - it was good, but compared to the anime itself it was far away from being even close to "that good"

But what i really like is the background music, with all that jazz and blues music, with random drum blasts at random moments - just great!



This is one anime i will surely watch again in a few years, and not many anime series get that option to be in my "plan to watch again" list.

Zankyou no Terror...I'll give you a quick review of what I thought of this anime!
First Impressions: After watching the first episode. I knew that there was a reason why this became my first priority anime to watch before the Summer Animes were aired. The trip only got better throughout the episodes.
Story --------- 23/25 ---------
Really unique story here - we have two young boys that are terrorists - bombing various places in Tokyo, but guess what? They aren't regular terrorists. No, not at all. They not only have a reason for doing this, but they have a unique method of how they do this, and it'sdone in a way where no one gets killed. Or is that so? The story is really deep, and the arc lasts throughout the whole series, which is why this anime doesn't feel too rushed in any ways. It's something unique, and I was very interested in the plot here - being the first anime I found that was announced back in winter 2013 or spring 2014 that I added to my to watch list.


Animation & Art --------- 14/15 ---------

I love the art in this anime. It's subjective of course, but I feel that the art here is very well done - and it fits the situation of the anime very well too. The animation is smooth, though the art for a large mass of people may be a bit less clear and clumpy. Fortunately, everything that's actually important is well animated! The explosions are pretty, the movements are smooth, and the emotions on people's faces are well shown


Sound --------- 19/20 ---------

The music in this anime is incredible. I've been listening to the soundtrack for a while now after finishing the series, and just...Wow. Some of the music is especially unique, including the disturbing "lolol," a quick-paced "saga" (my favorite), a strange sounding, "ess," and some really relaxing songs like the ending used for the last episode, "bless," etc. Another great thing about it is that the names for the tracks are really strange, which fits the atmosphere of the anime and the song itself really well. The opening really caught my attention and subjectively, I love listening to it - though it definitely may not seem like something everyone may love. The ending is similar in a way, but it also gives the impression that the other songs and tracks gave - strangeness, and uniqueness.


Characters --------- 22/25 ---------

This is where things get a bit deep. Since the main character list is kept down at a minimum, you actually get to learn a lot more about each particular person. Considering that this was one arc through 11 episodes, we got to know the characters pretty well - those including The boys, the detective, and the girl, and the white haired girl (Avoiding names for now). We got some decent supporting characters as well, those being the people in the government as an example. I thought that the development could have been a bit deeper, but it was really pleasurable to see all the characters grow and change their feelings throughout the anime. It was also interesting to see the connections they would make with each other when they met.


Enjoyment --------- 15/15 ---------

I had a great time watching this anime. The second I started watching, I knew that this would be a great trip, and I know that you will be feeling that as well. The scenarios were really well done here, and the trivia that you can learn from this anime is very interesting.


Final Verdict: I highly recommend this anime to you because of its originality, music, art style, and wonderful characters - and bombs of course!


Overall: 93/100

Zankyou no Terror is about a duo of terrorists who are called Sphinx.  They are terrorist and such they blow stuff if their riddles aren’t solved but while watching this show they didn’t even killed anyone.  
Yet they are terrorist. And the question here as I watch the anime, why are they doing this? What is there goal?  Let’s take a closer look in this anime.
The story of this anime is simple. Its about a duo of terrorist who tells riddles but if not solved then KABOOM!!!  Since Watanabe is the director who directed Cowboy Bebop I had high expectations. AndWatanabe didn’t fail me. The execution of the plot of the anime is almost entirely flawless. With the blend of OSTs in the scenes, the story itself becomes more like psychological and thriller. The mood of the story is angry and it ended well according to the mood. But there are many questions raised in the story. What is Sphinx? Why is Lisa so useless? Why Sphinx is doing all this things?  As I watch this anime, I felt the anime is becoming a riddle itself.  


The most intriguing thing in this anime is the characters. 9 and 12 are well-made characters. They convey emotions and has a big background and development. 9 and 12 form the duo of Sphinx and since they tell riddles, they become the actual embodiment of a Sphinx like in the myth. So if there is a Sphinx then there must be a Oedipus. The Oedipus in this show is none other than Shibazaki, a detective. Shibazaki is my favourite character in this show, he done his role on the show excellently. Lisa is perhaps the most useless character others say but in reality her uselessness makes her complete as a character. Her role and actions in the story as a useless character made a great impact in the closing episodes. Lisa’s uselessness symbolizes Sphinx’s weaknesses because her actions made Sphinx a little vulnerable. Five, in my opinion, is the worst character. Her character has not much background and dimension. Her final acts proved that. But her presence made a great impact in the anime. 


The OSTs of the show is simply undeniably amazing. Yoko Kanno has surpassed my expectations. OSTs were played in the transcendental peaks of the show which makes me awe.


Animation-wise, ZnK is one of the best this year. Its animation is entirely flawless. The visuals and artwork are amazing. The story makes its use of its gloomy setting. It has realistic character designs (unlike Yu-Gi-OH) The animation among the best, anime has to offer. It has fluid movement even in the background that is not degrading. Its very detailed.


Zankyou no Terror is a solid 11-episode anime not perfect but its great. Although the anime has shortcomings but the peaks of the very anime justifies the shortcomings. Watanabe made another awesome anime, not his best work, but its better than most animes with the same genre

8.9/10

Comment your opinion about my review ^_^

While not exactly about terrorism, Zankyou no Terror has an artistically brilliantly story line. The calming music clashes with the tense nature of the anime in a beautiful sophisticated way. I actually studied the soundtrack before watching the show, as it came up in a music analysis class i take, so my opinion may be a tad biased. However, it is some of the most poetic piano music you can find in an anime. 
The animation wasn't lacking but was nothing special. The character development sadly was lacking. While the characters were indeed unique, you don't really find out that much about the mainduo. They lack depth and you never truly get a sense of who they are. They also don't really get the chance to grow as the series progresses.\n\n
The story was unique and well-balanced. The plot was well constructed and thought out, including twists when least expected and an appropriate usage of flashbacks. This story is distinct, complex and extremely compelling and was by far the selling point of the anime.
